Joseph Biden, D-Del., who was swayed to side with Mitchell by a last-minute telephone call from White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. After the vote, Byrd avoided criticizing Mitchell and gave credit to the White House for swinging votes. ``I have no regrets, no recriminations,'' said Byrd, who can try to help the miners later with other legislation. Byrd said three of his colleagues said they would vote with him, but did not when it came down to the crunch. He'll remember who they are. And as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, he'll have plenty of chance for revenge, if he so desires, when those senators seek money for projects in their states. As for Mitchell, he still can expect Byrd's help in the future. Byrd knows that a majority leader must sometimes take stands and stick by them even when many in his own party think he's wrong. ``Byrd's not going to go away. He's got his own power and you can't ignore it,'' said a top Senate aide after the vote. Mitchell and Byrd ``need each other,'' the aide said.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Finally Beginning on Chapel at Camp David
DOC.TEXT: After a two-year delay, construction is about to begin on an interfaith chapel at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Western Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. The privately financed wood and glass building is expected to be dedicated sometime around Thanksgiving, said Kenneth Plummer Sr., president of the Camp David Chapel Fund. ``I have staked it out and we are ready to go,'' said Plummer, a semiretired Chambersburg, Pa., building contractor. He said earth moving would start this week. Plummer, immediate past president of the National Lay Leaders Association of the United Methodist Church, first announced plans for the chapel early in 1988. At that time, he said the board hoped to start construction in a few months and have the building ready before former President Reagan left office in January 1989. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, took part in ground breaking ceremonies for the chapel on July 2, 1988. At that time, the White House said it was scheduled for completion early in 1989. Plummer said the main reason for the delay was that funds have not come in as rapidly as he anticipated. Now, however, he said that between $850,000 and $900,000 of the $1 million goal has been raised or pledged. He said this enabled the board to give the Navy, which runs Camp David, the surety bond it required before construction could begin. ``I agree with that,'' he said. ``We didn't want to get the building half up and then stop on it. Now there is no question we are going to be building it this summer.'' Plummer said fundraising accelerated after the original five-member board, dominated by Protestant church officials, was expanded. The present 15-member board includes leaders of Jewish, Roman Catholic and Greek Orthodox faiths. Sean Walsh, a staff assistant in the White House press office, said President Bush now attends religious services in an auditorium at Hickory Lodge, one of the camp buildings, when he is at Camp David on Sundays. Other presidents also have either joined Navy personnel at services at the camp or visited nearby churches when they used the presidential retreat. Nancy Reagan, who gave one of the first contributions to the chapel fund, a check for $1,000, wrote in her book, ``My Turn,'' that it ``will be nice for the men stationed there, and for the president, whoever he is.'' Mrs. Reagan said that after her husband was wounded in an assassination attempt in 1981 ``the increased security measures made it virtually impossible for us to go to church without causing an enormous disruption.'' The Reagans have resumed attendance at Bel Air Presbyterian Church since returning to Los Angeles. Plummer said he first visited the camp as a Boy Scout and a Scout leader before it was taken over as a presidential retreat by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1942. He later did construction work there during several administrations.

DOC.HEAD: House Armed Services Chairman Trying More Combative Style
DOC.TEXT: Les Aspin, whose credentials as a Democrat at times are suspect among his colleagues, is keeping peace in his House Armed Services Committee with a new, more combative style. ``Politically he's keeping the administration in check, the Democrats in check and the budget committee in check,'' observes Republican Rep. John Rowland of Connecticut, a member of the Armed Services panel. Aspin fired the first shot at the White House earlier this year when he rejected the Bush administration's attempt to shift Pentagon funds to military personnel accounts to avoid massive layoffs. President Bush had a chance to exempt the personnel accounts from the budget-cutting law last August, but decided against it. Pentagon officials said they did not propose the exemption because they assumed Congress would grant them the authority to transfer the funds. ``Budget brinkmanship,'' Aspin said of the administration's action in a letter earlier this week. The Wisconsin Democrat also has been highly critical of Bush's $307 billion fiscal 1991 defense budget _ a military blueprint that cuts some conventional programs but calls for increasing funds for strategic weapons. Aspin believes the budget fails to reflect the rapid changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. All this comes from a Democrat whose hold on the chairmanship appeared tenuous just one year ago. Aspin angered his colleagues then by urging them to accept Cheney's fiscal 1990 defense budget _ but when the House approved a bill that cut Bush's strategic programs, he referred to the legislation as a ``Michael Dukakis'' budget. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior committee member, says the chairman has ``got a better pulse on it this time.'' Aspin points to a series of events that he says made 1989 the transition year for defense, including the increase in warning time for a Soviet invasion of Western Europe and the intelligence community's confirmation that the Soviet Union is reducing its troops consistent with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's December 1988 announcement. In addition, there were Moscow's concessions in U.S.-Soviet talks to reduce conventional arms and the collapse of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance. Having adopted those arguments for cutting Bush's budget, Aspin then chose witnesses for his hearings who would make the same points. First was CIA Director William Webster, who said the changes in the Soviet Union will be difficult to reverse _ a contradiction of statements by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Cheney bristled at Webster's comments, saying the testimony ``was not helpful'' to Bush's policies. Aspin also discussed a classified report and said the Joint Chiefs had concluded that the United States and its allies could fight and hold off the Soviet Union in Europe without resorting to nuclear weapons. Aspin said Thursday that he plans to hold hearings on the disintegration of the Soviet army, saying he was ``building toward making a case to cut the Cheney budget.'' Issues irking members of Congress include Cheney's candidates for base closings, which drew charges of partisanship, the Pentagon's request for authority to shift funds, deferral of funds for pet congressional projects, and proposals for funding the aid package for Nicaragua. The Nicaragua aid package would be partially funded by closing some of the military construction projects at bases on Cheney's list of proposed base closures. A senior member of the panel, Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., said Aspin has a ``responsibility to fill the policy void this year.'' ``If he doesn't move and we don't move, we're wasting a valuable opportunity,'' McCurdy said.

DOC.HEAD: Census Questions: Why They Ask All That Stuff
DOC.TEXT: Why do they want to know all that stuff, anyway? That's the question on millions of lips now that most Americans have sent in their Census forms. But government officials say there's a reason for the questions they're asking. The Census has grown from its original intention of counting the population so seats in the House of Representatives can be distributed among the states. Knowing that the nation was going to be counted every 10 years, officials couldn't resist the urge to ask some questions. And once the questions were being asked, officials started using the answers to design social programs and distribute money. ``In many respects the Census is an index to our quality of life,'' said John G. Keane, dean of the business school at Notre Dame University and former head of the Census Bureau. ``The Census shows us anew where our nation hurts and needs help. ... Recite the national agenda and we realize how its resolution is directly or indirectly rooted in Census data.'' Nonetheless, each Census finds opposition to answering the detailed questions, evidenced this year by resistance from the American Civil Liberties Union and the Libertarian Party. ``They already know too much about the citizens,'' complained Leslie Williams of the Vermont ACLU, who objected to questions about household relationships, whether a home has complete plumbing and whether anyone in a home is disabled. The Libertarian Party urges that answering the Census be made voluntary. It is encouraging people to send in cards with their Census forms stating either that they refuse to cooperate, are doing so under threat or law or will only answer some questions. Census officials point out that the law requires people to answer the Census, although prosecutions rarely occur. The more detailed questions on the long form _ sent to one family in six _ are necessary, the bureau said. In fiscal 1988 there were 82 federal programs that allocated $38.7 billion in money and other assistance based on Census information. The programs are based not just on the number of people, but who they are, their ages and incomes, jobs and relationships to one another. The Transportation Department topped the list at $16.6 billion, the vast majority of it highway planning and construction money distributed according to Census results. The Education Department hands out $7 billion based on Census figures. The $5.5 billion from the Department of Health and Human Services helps illustrate changes in social trends. The agency used Census population information to distribute $26 million to aid runaway and homeless youths, $269 million for services for the aging, $345 million for nutrition programs for the elderly and $239 million for child welfare programs. Census population data provides statistical proof when city officials apply for money to establish day care centers. Racial and ethnic information can be used to determine if communities comply with voting rights laws. For example, minority residents of a city could use Census data in a suit seeking to redistrict local city council seats to provide more balanced representation. During a severe summer heat wave, officials in St. Louis, Mo., used census data to locate areas with large numbers of elderly residents. City workers then went door to door, telling the elderly about cooling centers where they could go for relief. Outside the government, Big Brothers of America has used census information on the characteristics of city populations to estimate where it might best find volunteers for its programs to help youths. In Newport News, Va., a church official used age data in planning a new church building. A high proportion of elderly in the area resulted in a decision to build a one-story structure instead of two. Many businesses have become avid users of census information, using it to design products and services to specific audiences, locate stores and plan for future growth.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Recipe for Grain Self-Sufficiency: Spend Big Bucks
DOC.TEXT: No wish list of American farmers comes even close to the incredible saga of how Saudi Arabia turned from a wheat importer to an exporter in a single decade. All it took was a decision, big oil revenues and some fantastically high farm subsidies, says Agriculture Department economist John Parker. In 1980, Saudi Arabia decided to become self-sufficient in wheat by offering domestic producers $1,032 per metric ton, or about $28 per bushel. At that time, Parker said, U.S. wheat was selling on the world market for $175 per ton, or $4.78 per bushel. The result was startling, he said. Saudi wheat production doubled in 1982 and nearly doubled again in 1983. By 1984, Saudi Arabia was self-sufficient in wheat. ``Surprised at the rapid gains, Saudi officials reduced the price by half in 1984,'' Parker said. ``But $530 per ton was still a very rewarding figure, and production continued to climb.'' Then planners in Riyadh, the capital, tried to encourage farmers to shift from wheat to less-profitable barley. Those efforts fizzled last year when Saudi farmers harvested a record wheat crop of 3.1 million tons. Exports, meanwhile, rose to 2.4 million tons in 1987-88, more than double the level of the previous year. But Parker said USDA is forecasting some decline in those exports for 1989-90. Last year, he said, wheat accounted for about $310 million of Saudi Arabia's $400 million in agricultural exports. As a key member of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Saudi Arabia ships about 200,000 tons of wheat to other council members: Kuwait, United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman. Parker said the Saudis lose about $300 per ton on those shipments. Other Mideast countries get Saudi wheat, including Jordan and Turkey, which received 200,000 tons last year. Previously, Turkey was the Mideast wheat leader but has suffered from drought. Parker, writing in the April issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said Saudi wheat also goes to Indonesia, China, the Soviet Union, Portugal, Norway, the United Kingdom and Colombia. Despite the government's price cuts, domestic wheat prices and production subsidies are still high enough to allow Saudi farmers and investors to afford the best imported U.S. seed, farm tractors, combines and irrigation systems, he said. ``Alarm at the depletion of underground water reserves, especially near Riyadh, has not yet stopped the wheat production boom,'' Parker said. ``Some farms still have land area to develop, although new licenses were prohibited 18 months ago.'' The concern about water reserves helped prompt the government's reduced wheat price guarantees and curtailing some of the other subsidies. ``But removing the seed subsidy and cutting the price still left a hefty profit margin,'' Parker said. ``Many Saudi farmers earn a profit of $600 per acre, compared with $60 to $80 earned by U.S. farmers.'' Parker noted that despite the program's cost of more than $1 billion annually, the Saudis' main objective _ self-sufficiency _ has been achieved. Overall, the country's dependency on net food imports has been reduced to about 50 percent from 87 percent in 1980. During the oil embargo of 1973-73, when Saudi Arabia and other petroleum exporters sent prices soaring, there was some talk in international trade policy circles of linking the price of oil to the price of wheat. ``Now, this is very unlikely to happen because Saudi Arabia is no longer a wheat importer,'' Parker said.

Another record for exports of wood products was set last year, with Japan accounting for nearly half of the total 1989 value, according to an annual report by the Agriculture Department. In all, slightly more than $6 billion worth of solid wood products were exported last year, a 14 percent increase from 1988, said the report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. Hardwood sales rose 23 percent to more than $1.2 billion, and the value of softwood products increased 9 percent to $4.1 billion. Other products made up the remainder. Japan, the biggest customer of U.S. solid wood products, boosted its imports 27 percent to $2.8 billion. Other major buyers included Canada, $645 million; South Korea, $354 million; United Kingdom, $233 million; and Mexico, $224 million. Softwood logs were the largest seller at more than $2.1 billion, with Japan accounting for $1.6 billion of the total. Softwood lumber was next at $1.39 billion.

There are more than 1 billion head of cattle and buffalo in the major livestock countries, according to Agriculture Department statisticians. The most current estimates published by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service show the U.S. cattle herd at 99.3 million head. Brazil's is slightly larger at 100.3 million, and China's is 101.4 million. The Soviet Union was shown at 118.3 million. All are dwarfed by India's cattle and buffalo inventory, estimated in 1990 at 273.5 million head. Most of the buffalo are the domestic buffalo used as work animals in much of the world, particularly in Asia. But when it comes to putting beef on the table the Soviet Union is expected to slaughter 41.5 million head of cattle this year, followed by the United States at 36.6 million. Brazil's 1990 cattle slaughter was shown at 12.2 million, and China's at 10 million head. India's cattle slaughter was estimated at 6.5 million head.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Rattled by Reunification Price Tag
DOC.TEXT: Rainer Korkow leaned back on a park bench in a grassy square called Marx-Engels Forum and pointed to the stark, gray apartment building across the street. ``One hundred and nine marks a month it costs for my four rooms,'' said the 32-year-old window washer as he lounged in the sun with his wife and two children on a beautiful Sunday in East Berlin. ``How much will it cost after reunification? Six hundred marks? Seven hundred? And how much will I make? Half as much!'' The 109 marks that Korkow pays monthly for a three-room apartment is officially about 36 West German marks ($21). The same modest apartment in West Berlin, one of the world's most expensive cities, could go for 1,000 marks ($600), perhaps 1,500 marks ($900). East Germans who can barely follow the labyrinthine political wrangling that is a prelude to merging two economically disparate countries, got a serious dose of price sticker shock during the weekend. The Bundesbank, the government institution that controls the West German money supply, said it was proposing East German marks be valued at a 2-1 rate against West German marks in a planned monetary union. That would appear to be a good deal, since East Germany itself has only an official 3-1 rate. In truth, the currency is non-convertible and virtually worthless in Western markets. But for many East Germans, some of whom fear a Western-style cost of living as much as they hope for Western-style wages, the news was disturbing. ``I think it's terrible. I work for 600 marks (monthly) now. I cannot live on 300 marks,'' said Miriam Jonas, 20, an employee at the government travel bureau in East Berlin. ``All prices, for rent and groceries, will go up. But our savings and salaries will go down.'' ``We were very optimistic. Now, I don't know if we can live with such conditions,'' she said. The idealism that brought down Communism last year has been quickly replaced by shock over the cost of capitalism. Some blame West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for promising them Western prosperity while campaigning for his political surrogate in East Germany, Christian Democrat leader Lothar de Maiziere. De Maiziere's conservative coalition easily won East Germany's first free elections on March 18. Now, he is trying to negotiate an even larger alliance with the left-leaning Social Democrats so he can have two-thirds control of Parliament and push through Kohl's plan for swift unification. Kohl said Sunday that he never promised a 1-1 money conversion rate, but he also did not say whether he supported the 2-1 formula proposed by Bundesbank Chairman Karl Otto Poehl. Kohl's sidestep triggered a deluge of criticism in East Germany, and even de Maiziere responded by saying he was against a 2-1 conversion. Lame-duck Communist Premier Hans Modrow told the West German Bild newspaper Sunday that East Germans are ``increasingly upset'' they will be short-changed by the monetary merger, which West German leaders have been seeking to realize this summer. He said Kohl would bear responisibility for any strikes or demonstrations. The head of East Germany's Labor Union Federation, Helga Mausch, told the official news agency ADN the organization was telling its 8.6 million members ``to fight for their rights and demonstrate next week,'' against the proposed exchange rate. Kohl, facing his own elections in December, is trying to walk a thin line between living up to election promises to East German voters without placing too great an economic burden on the West German electorate. West German financial experts say it will cost of billions of dollars annually to improve obsolete industries and repair roads and communications in East Germany over the next five to 10 years. Much of the burden is expected to hurt the wealthy West German economy in the short-term, resulting in a rise in inflation, a decline in the value of the powerful West mark and even new taxes. But some officials have predicted that anything less than a 1-1 conversion could cause a new exodus of East Germans to the West. East Germany's collapsing economy and the nearly 500,000 East Germans who emigrated West since January 1989 were main factors in the revolt that ousted the hard-line Communist regime. Many say a straight 1-1 conversion is necessary to allow East German workers and elderly people living off savings accounts to maintain adequate living standards in a unified Germany. East Germans currently depend on heavy government subsidies for housing, food and employment. The subsidies would be phased out in the new free-market economy under unification. Because of its outmoded factories, unemployment would also rise quickly. On Sunday in downtown East Berlin, thousands walked through the historic heart of the old city. A 55-year-old man in a wheelchair said he misses the old regime. He receives a disability allowance, cheap housing, and buys beer for the equivalent of about 16 cents. ``In the first World War, all was lost. In the second World War, all was lost. Now, even without a war, all is lost,'' said the man, who would not identify himself. Others are angry that East Germans may be consigned to second-class status in a unified Germany. ``Some people think that the East Germans are stupid. But we're not,'' said Sabina Plesser, 20. ``A lot of people will be unemployed, but it will only last a little while. We will learn and things will get better.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Try to Save Bus Driver's Arm, Police Look for Sniper
DOC.TEXT: Incensed by a sniper attack that could cost a bus driver his arm, Greyhound says it won't bargain with its striking employees until a week has passed without violence against the company. ``No American worth his salt negotiates with terrorists,'' Greyhound chairman and chief executive Fred G. Currey said at a Greyhound terminal Sunday on a visit from Dallas to see the wounded Southeastern Trailways driver. David E. Bryant, 58, of Cincinnati, was critically wounded by a shot fired through the front window of his bus Saturday night from a pickup truck that pulled alongside, police said. None of the 46 passengers on the Louisville-bound bus was injured. Southeastern Trailways is carrying passengers on some Greyhound routes under a pooling arrangement that existed before the strike, said a company official. ``It's an open-and-shut case of terrorism,'' Currey said at a news conference. Striking drivers said they don't believe any of their members would shoot another driver. Doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center operated for six hours trying to save Bryant's left arm but won't know for several days whether they succeeded, said Wayne Wood. ``If everything goes perfectly, his arm will not need to be amputated,'' Wood said. Currey was not able to visit Bryant, who was recovering from surgery when the executive arrived. About 6,300 Greyhound drivers went on strike March 2 over wages and job security. The company has reported 29 shootings of buses, 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents since then. The company had said it would meet with the union today, but on Friday canceled the session, citing continued violence. No arrests were made in the shooting. ``Let the facts speak for themselves. Whatever comes out of it, if it ends up being strike-related it is; if it isn't, it isn't,'' said Bill Holt, spokesman for the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation. Joe Semmes, a local union executive, blamed ``demented people.'' ``They hear Mr. Currey won't negotiate while this violence continues and they say, `Here's a good chance I can stir up a lot of trouble,''' he said. ``I can't say with absolute certainty that it wasn't one of our drivers, but I don't believe it was'' because Southeastern Trailways drivers are honoring Greyhound picket lines, said local union spokesman J.R. Green. ``By that, I mean not crossing them. They pull the bus over on the street and a supervisor has to drive it into the terminal and bring it out again,'' Green said. Holt called the idea of police escorting buses ``premature.''

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Who Owns Millions in Gold From the Ocean Floor
DOC.TEXT: Cmdr. William Lewis Herndon left the deck of his foundering SS Central America and went below to don his dress uniform. With that last act of decorum 133 years ago, Herndon went down with his ship. On Tuesday, U.S. District Judge Richard B. Kellam hears opening arguments in the dispute between treasure hunters and insurance companies over the millions in gold that sank with the sidewheel steamer on Sept. 12, 1857. On one side are more than 100 investors in the Columbus America Discovery Group that used space age technology to locate and recover the treasure. They claim the gold was abandoned and belongs to them by the rights of salvage. On the other side are 45 insurance firms that have filed suit contending they have ties to the 19th-century companies which paid more than $1.2 million in claims after the ship sank. Lost in the legal wranglings over the fortune is the story of the SS Central America and the valor of its sailors and passengers. The ship left from what is now Colon, Panama, after picking up passengers and mail from California. Among its cargo were gold bars and freshly minted ``double eagle'' gold coins from the San Francisco mint. Four days later, the ship ran into a hurricane and sank in 8,000 feet of water 200 miles off South Carolina. Reports at the time put the number of dead at between 362 and 423 of the 578 people aboard and the value of the gold at $1.6 million. Not all the ship's gold was recovered in salvage expeditions last year, and its exact value has yet to be determined. The ship was carrying about three tons of gold, which would be worth about $450 million at today's prices. In addition, many passengers were carrying fortunes they had made in California, so the total treasure could be worth up to $1 billion, experts have said. Herndon had rallied his crew to keep the vessel afloat through the two days the ship tried to ride out the storm. He kept order on the deck as the women and children were loaded into the four lifeboats. A nearby ship took on survivors. When a lifeboat returned to the sinking ship, a witness said that Herndon ordered the boat to keep off, fearing it would be swamped by the Central America. It was his final order. Among the passengers were Capt. Thomas Badger and his bride, Jennie. Badger and his brother John had left Virginia years earlier to find their fortunes in California, said Curtis Badger, a great-great-grandnephew. ``Apparently, he was returning with about $20,000 in gold. The story goes that when the women were put in lifeboats, Jennie wrapped the gold in towels and packed it in a carpetbag. She threw the carpetbag into the captain's cabin and left the ship,'' Badger's descendant said. Jennie Badger survived and was taken to New York City. Her husband later was pulled from the sea, having clung to a piece of wood for many hours. History may hold a lesson for the current gold seekers, Curtis Badger said. Thomas and John Badger found their fortunes in the gold fields and both lost them in their lifetimes, Curtis Badger said. ``After the war, (John) returned to the family farm and lived out his life as a farmer and fisherman along the barrier islands. Thomas lost it all and died without much,'' he said. ``Perhaps it was John who found the only true fortune.''

DOC.HEAD: US Regains Spot As Leading Exporter
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund says the United States regained its position as the world's leading exporter last year, three years after losing it to West Germany. U.S. foreign sales were worth $364 billion for 1989, compared with $341.4 billion for West Germany, the IMF said Sunday. Japan was third with $273.9 billion. West Germany had toppled the United States from the No. 1 trade spot in 1986. Both West Germany and Japan had trade surpluses last year, while the United States had a deficit of $128.9 billion, down from $137.1 billion, according to the IMF's trade calculations. The deficit is due to the fact that the United States also is the world's greatest importer and its imports grew rapidly, to $492.9 billion from $459.5 billion. The fund reported that the West German surplus, now the world's largest, amounted to $71.4 billion. Japan's was 63.9 billion. The Commerce Department, using different means of calculating the trade imbalance, has put the 1989 merchandise trade deficit at $109 billion. Of six major countries, the United States had the largest increase in foreign sales, 12.5 percent, the IMF said. West German exports also rose, by 5.6 percent to $341 billion. Since East Germany also is an important trader, a reunified Germany may take over the world's first place as exporter once again. As a group, the 22 countries the fund classifies as industrial increased their buying faster than their sales last year, with many of the imports apparently from the Third World. Led by the United States, they imported $2.2 trillion worth of goods in 1989, up 8.7 percent. Their exports also rose, to $2.1 trillion , but that was an increase of only 6.5 percent _ a widening of their overall trade deficit. But the West Germans imported only $270 billion dollars worth. Japan imported $210 billion worth in 1989, up from $187 billion the year before, under heavy pressure from the United States and other trading partners to buy more of their industrial goods. For the other 130 countries reported by the fund, which does not include the Soviet Union, figures for the year were not complete. The fund's monthly IMF Memorandum said their overall trade surplus in the first three quarters of 1989 rose to $11.7 billion compared with $8.8 billion in the same period of 1988. Latin American countries were an exception in the Third World. Struggling to find cash to meet the interest on their debts, they increased their surplus to $13.1 billion from $10.8 billion for the nine-month period in 1988. The fund noted that Latin America was reporting record inflation: a price increase of more than 365 percent in the July-September period over the same period in 1988. The largest rate was Nicaragua's 4,267 percent: that is, prices more than 42 times the previous year's rate. Nicaragua's rate affects a population of fewer than 4 million, however. Brazil's 144 million people suffered from 1,287 percent annual inflation. Brazil accounts for a third of Latin America's economy. In Asia, many countries are under pressure to buy from the West. As a group, Asian Third World countries increased their excess of imports to $9.9 billion from $2.6 billion for the first nine months of 1989. South Korea still had a $1 billion surplus of exports in 1989, down from nearly $9 billion in 1988. Others, including China, contributed to the increasing deficit of the group by selling less than they bought. Asian countries as a whole nevertheless continued to show the fastest growth in both imports and exports, the fund said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,002.07, down 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Will Reject Environmental Bill, EPA Head Predicts
DOC.TEXT: Environmental Protection Agency chief William K. Reilly predicts that a threatened veto by President Bush will stir the Senate to reject a House-passed effort to establish a politically independent bureau for collecting and analyzing environmental data. ``We do not want an independent agency that we have no control over'' as part of a proposed Cabinet-level Department of the Environment replacing the EPA, Reilly said Sunday. ``We are confident the Senate will not have a provision of that sort.'' President Bush in January endorsed a congressional effort to elevate the EPA to Cabinet status. But the House in approving the bill last week said it wanted an independent Bureau of Environmental Statistics in the new department headed by a civil servant who could be dismissed only for malfeasance. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater immediately raised the threat of a veto, saying the House bill ``gives a degree of independence to this unit of the agency which we feel is unconstitutional.'' Reilly, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, called the proposal for an independent data agency a ``slight'' to the EPA. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., who as chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations is the chief sponsor of the independent data agency provision, said it would put a halt to ``conflicts of interest'' that had raised questions in the past about EPA analyses.
DOC.HEAD: Three Senators Urge US Crackdown on Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The United States should crack down on Iraq for allegedly trying to dodge American restrictions on nuclear technology shipments and for using chemical weapons, three senators say. ``I think ... there should be sound and fury and all we're hearing now is the sounds of silence'' from the Bush administration, Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, the ranking Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee, said Sunday on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. ``I don't think we've done enough,'' Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., agreed, saying on the ABC program, ``I think we need to get tough, not just with those Middle Eastern countries, but also with those that are supplying them.'' McCain said the Iraqis must be forewarned that the United States ``will exercise all options, including that of military, if necessary, to prevent this enormous threat from continuing if they acquire the nuclear weapons we think they are maybe three to four years away from.'' Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, must be stopped on his ``messianic mission'' to become a dominant force in the Middle East, McCain said. U.S. and British intelligence forces broke up an alleged Iraqi smuggling ring in London last week. Officials claimed the Iraqis were trying to obtain U.S.-made nuclear triggers for atomic weapons. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, denied his country was trying to build a nuclear bomb.
DOC.HEAD: Government Requires Proof of No Fungicides in Wines
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government is requiring some French and Italian vineyards to certify that wines imported by this country do not contain traces of a fungicide not approved in the United States, a spokesman says. ``We have found a little bit of Italian sparkling wine and some French wine that contains traces of a fungicide not approved in the United States,'' Food and Drug Administration spokesman Bill Grigg said Sunday. There is no ban on the wines, he said, but the vineyards involved must retain independent testing labs to certify the wines are fungicide-free before shipping them to the United States. The FDA will conduct spot tests on the wines to reaffirm the certifications, said Grigg. The fungicide, procymidone, is made in Japan and is applied to grapes while they are growing rather than to the wines themselves, said Grigg. Grigg said only a tiny percentage of total exports from the two countries to the United States was affected. He said there is no indication the fungicide _ approved for use in Europe _ constitutes a health risk, but it has not undergone U.S. clearance procedures.

DOC.HEAD: Hondurans Hunt Suspects In Attack On U.S. Servicemen
DOC.TEXT: This country's top military officer has vowed to capture the gunmen who wounded eight U.S. airmen in an ambush, and a nationwide manhunt for suspected leftist rebels was under way. ``We already have concrete leads on the identities of the authors of these crimes,'' Gen. Arnulfo Cantero Lopez, the Honduran armed forces chief, said Sunday in San Pedro Sula, Honduras' second-largest city. ``We will capture them and apply to them the full force of the law.'' Hours after the three gunmen opened fire on a bus carrying 28 U.S. airmen an anonymous caller to a radio network claimed responsibility on behalf of the leftist Morazano National Liberation Front. U.S. Embassy spokesman Terrence Kneebone said the Honduran military was assuming the front, which has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on U.S. soldiers, was behind Saturday's attack. All U.S. military personnel in Honduras were confined to barracks, and Kneebone said the U.S. Embassy advised U.S. citizens to keep a low profile and avoid public places where they could be targeted for attack. The wounded servicemen, in this Central American nation on a mission to build roads and airstrips, had been returning from a trip to the beach when they were attacked outside Tegucigalpa, the capital, U.S. officials said. Two of them were in critical but stable condition at the Medical School Hospital in Tegucigalpa, said a news release from the U.S. Southern Command in Panama, headquarters of U.S. troops in Latin America. It identified them as Airman 1st Class Jerry D. Mallard, who suffered gunshot wounds to the stomach and back; and Senior Airman Dean A. Dark, who was wounded in the head. Airman 1st Class Brian W. Miller was in stable condition at the Southern Command's Gorgas Hospital with chest wounds, the release said. Airman 1st Class Todd M. Groeschel and Senior Airman Brian R. Domsch were treated for minor wounds at a U.S. military clinic in Soto Cano air force base in Honduras. The news release said the five airmen were from the 820th Red Horse Civil Engineering Squadron at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada. Also being treated at Gorgas Hospital in Panama for leg wounds were Airman 1st Class Patrick J. Kelly, Sgt. Todd H. Fewell and Sgt. Kevin A. Flint, the release said. Kelly is from the 33rd Combat Communications Squadron at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma. Fewell is from the 4th Security Police Squadron at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base in South Carolina. Flint is from the 833rd Security Police Squadron at Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico. The news release said the eight wounded soldiers had been on temporary duty at Jamastran, a town in southern Honduras. All U.S. military personnel in Honduras have been confined to barracks and ``all trips are canceled'' under further notice. The embassy has advised U.S. citizens in Honduras to keep a low profile and avoid public places where they could be targeted for attack, Kneebone said. The United States keeps an average of 1,200 troops in Honduras on a year-round basis and additional soldiers are sometimes brought in for joint exercises with the Honduran military.

DOC.HEAD: Historians Howl as Peoria Group Eyes Historic Missouri Houses
DOC.TEXT: Planners of Peoria's tricentennial celebration are going shopping across the river for a little history. The group, the Peoria 1691 Foundation, has proposed buying four old houses in Missouri and moving them to Illinois to reconstruct a French colony of the banks of the Illinois River just like the settlement that evolved into Peoria. The original village in what is now downtown Peoria was destroyed by fire in 1812, so civic leaders have set their sights on the French colonial houses built in the late 18th and early 19th centuries in Ste. Genevieve, Mo. But what might play in Peoria doesn't play well in Ste. Genevieve. ``This is just like the rape of antiquities in the colonial days,'' said Melburn Thurman, a Ste. Genevieve anthropologist. ``This is a totally unethical and reprehensible action by the city of Peoria. They are trying to steal our great prize, our historic jewel.'' But Dorothy Sinclair, administrative director of the Peoria Historical Society, views the action as one of historic preservation. ``We came along and expressed an interest in them after learning they were being sold and threatened with possible destruction,'' Mrs. Sinclair said. ``We did not go down there in the night and carry them away. We think it's better they be saved and preserved in Peoria than being torn down in Ste. Genevieve.'' Ste. Genevieve, a town of 5,000 situated 75 miles south of St. Louis, was once part of France's Louisiana Territory, bought by the United States in 1803. The historical society estimates it would cost $500,000 to buy and relocate the houses. The non-profit group would raise the money through donations and doesn't need Peoria officials' approval. Ste. Genevieve city commissioners could block the plan since the houses are on the National Registry of Historic Places, but they have taken no action so far. The Peoria group has yet to sign an agreement to buy the houses. Royce and Margaret Wilhauk, who own three of the houses, said they contacted the state of Missouri after officials in Peoria made an offer last fall. ``We have given the state an option on the houses and they've asked for an extension,'' Mrs. Wilhauk said. ``We'd like the houses to stay here. But if we can't work something out, we will consider the Peoria offer.'' Frank Myers of Ste. Genevieve's Foundation for Preservation says the houses should stay. ``We'd like to share our knowledge with Peoria, but we don't necessarily want to share our buildings with Peoria,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Bronx Club Fire Victims Had Sought Better Life
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Jose Ambrosio Alvarez left for the United States three years ago with cooking skills learned in a hospital kitchen and an immigrant's dream of a better life. On Sunday, his body was returned in a plain wooden box along with the bodies of 47 other Hondurans killed with him in a blaze at an illegal New York social club. ``You leave here with such high hopes of better things,'' said his 32-year-old brother, Gerardo Alvarez. ``This has been a terrible blow to us.'' At least 79 of the 87 people killed in the March 25 fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx were Hondurans. Authorities have said a Cuban immigrant set the blaze after being spurned by his girlfriend, a club employee. The Happy Land club was a home-away-from-home for Honduran immigrants, who went there to dance, chat and drink. The coffins on Sunday arrived in the northern industrial city of San Pedro Sula aboard a DC-8 transport plane chartered by the Red Cross. The victims, mostly young people in their late teens and early 20s, were largely poor immigrants from San Pedro Sula and towns dotting Honduras' Atlantic coast such as Puerto Cortes, Tela, La Ceiba, Trujillo. The story of 27-year-old Jose Alvarez is familiar in these parts of high unemployment, low wages and wide poverty. Clothing and furniture factories and food packing plants are San Pedro Sula's backbone. But the jobs they provide are far fewer than the numbers of poor from outlying areas who flock to the city looking for work. At the airport early Sunday, family members clung to each other for support as an orange forklift unloaded the coffins four at a time. The coffins were laid in rows on the airport tarmac before the grief-stricken families. Wreaths were laid atop each box and the Roman Catholic bishop of San Pedro Sula, Monsignor Jaime Brufeau, said a brief Mass. ``Most of them went to the United States with high hopes, and they come back dead. We are very sad,'' said President Rafael Leonardo Callejas, who came to San Pedro Sula to be with dozens of mourning relatives. Army helicopters were to fly some bodies to the victims' home towns. Others were simply carried away by their families. Many relatives, who stood at the airport under a hot tropical sun for more than two hours, collapsed and were carried away by Honduran Red Cross volunteers. One man's grief broke into fury toward the suspected arsonist. ``Damned Cuban, I'll kill you!'' shouted Juan Alberto Pena, 19, clenching his fist. Pena, of Progreso, was at the airport awaiting the body of his brother, Jeremias. On Friday, Cuban immigrant Julio Gonzalez, 36, was indicted by a New York state grand jury on 178 counts of murder, arson and other charges. Authorities say he set the fire at the Happy Land club with gasoline from a nearby gas station. Some relatives said they were preparing to file lawsuits. ``We have made our decision,'' a grim-faced Gregorio Hernandez said. His nephew, 24-year-old Jose Manuel Marquez Hernandez, was a victim. ``We're going to sue the city (of New York), the gas station and the owners of the building,'' Hernandez said. Wakes and funerals were scheduled for today and Tuesday in surrounding towns.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Plows into Neighborhood; At Least One Dead
DOC.TEXT: Investigators worked to sort auto parts and lawn equipment from a pieces of a small plane that crashed and exploded in a neighborhood, demolishing a home and garages and killing at least one person. The twin-engine plane flew out of control from the foothills at up to 150 mph Sunday afternoon, plowing into one of the most densely populated sections of this city of about 100,000 situated 30 miles from Denver, authorities said. ``The plane hit a good-size tree and disintegrated,'' city spokesmsan David Grimm. ``I heard the sound of trees snapping and the most incredible sound I had ever heard ... and I realized that no one could have survived that crash,'' said John Mink, who lives across from the crash site. ``The whole center of the block was on fire.'' One body, burned beyond recognition, was pulled from the wreckage, and authorities were working to determine whether the victim was Bill Layne, listed on the flight plan as the pilot, Grimm said. The flight plan indicated there may have been a passenger, but investigators saw no immediate signs of another body. The crash destroyed a vacant home up for sale, six parked cars and at least four garages, authorities said. One person on the ground was injured. Harold Parks, 54, had been working in his garage and was thrown some 40 feet by the explosion, authorities said. He was listed in good condition with a broken hip at Boulder Community Hospital. National Transportation Safety Board investigator Verlin B. Tranter said said it was ``pure luck'' there weren't more deaths and injuries. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Grimm said the plane was experiencing some sort of engine trouble before the crash. Tranter said it will be difficult to make sense of the wreckage. ``The aircraft struck a garage and spread the equipment and junk from the garages around so it's mixed in with the aircraft parts,'' he said. ``I've been doing these investigations for 12 years as a civilian and six years in the military before that and I've never seen such a mess. We've got a real sorting job ahead of us.'' Tranter said the flight plan indicated the Cessna 421-C aircraft took off from the Denver area to take a passenger to Granby, west of the Continental Divide in the Colorado Rockies, then return to Denver. Tranter said he didn't know whether the plane had made it to Granby or how many people were on board the plane when it crashed. The plane, which seats six or seven, was owned by Skyways Associates of Raton, N.M., he said. Mink said he watched from his balcony as the plane came in over a rock outcropping, banked with its wings almost vertical. ``He leveled out, but was losing altitude rapidly,'' Mink said. ``I saw him go down across the street.'' Witnesses aid flames climbed 20 to 30 feet high. Utility crews worked restore telephone and electricity to two blocks that were left without service when the plane clipped overhead lines.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Produce Hail in South, Skies Dry in West
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms produced hail and high winds in the South, and skies were dry most everywhere west of the Rockies. Storms were severe Sunday in portions of Texas, Mississippi, Alabama and North Carolina, the National Weather Service said. Hail the size of golf balls fell in Andrews, Texas; Highland Home, Ala.; Wheeling, W.Va., and De Kalb, Miss. High winds downed trees and power lines in Alabama. Winds gusted to 58 mph in Montgomery and a trailer home was overturned near Ansley in Alabama. Charlotte, N.C., was whipped by gusts of 78 mph. The weather service said thunderstorms spawned a tornado near Winters, Texas. Virginia and Louisiana also received thunderstorms. Light rain and drizzle fell over New York state and Vermont. Light rain ahead of a cold front extended from Illinois to upper Michigan. Showers were scattered over Arizona and Aouthern California. Dry weather prevailed elsewhere in the West, with fair skies over much of the Central Plains. The high Sunday in the Lower 48 states was 89 degrees in Miami. Marie 38 cloudy; San Antonio 63 foggy. _West: Albuquerque 45 fair; Anchorage 30 fair; Boise 53 fair; Casper 36 fair; Fairbanks 31 fair; Great Falls 51 cloudy; Honolulu 72 fair; Las Vegas 60 fair; Los Angeles 55 fair; Medford 56 fair; Pendleton 58 fair; Phoenix 63 fair; Portland, Ore. 52 cloudy; Reno 55 fair; Salt Lake City 51 fair; San Diego 58 cloudy; San Francisco 50 fair; Seattle 49 cloudy; Spokane 48 fair. _International: Calgary 46 partly cloudy; Montreal 41 rain; Ottawa 37 cloudy; Regina 32 fair; Toronto 39 showery; Winnipeg 23 fair; Mexico City 66 partly cloudy; Acapulco 81 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Resort Disdains Spring Break Revelers, But Beaches Beckon Youths
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Palm Springs and its mayor, singer Sonny Bono, don't want the spring break crowd anymore. But neighboring Orange County is working hard to lure young sun-seekers to shores freshly scrubbed after a big oil spill. ``We're ready for them! We're excited to have our beaches ready for Easter vacation. I know the merchants are gearing up for them and we expect a good crowd,'' said Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays. The 400,000-gallon spill by a tanker Feb. 7 is now just an unpleasant memory, the crude gone and the shoreline between Huntington Beach and Newport Beach cleaner than ever, Mays said. ``Come witness one of the finest surfing schools on the West Coast. You don't have to hang 10 or shoot the curl to have a good time,'' reads a $73,000 full-page color ad in today's USA Today. There is no mention of the spill. But 100 miles inland, the sunbaked Palm Springs oasis notorious for spring break madness has bluntly declared it doesn't want the teen-age exercise in excess. Libidinous high school and college students, bent on celebrating booze, sun and each other, traditionally descend on the desert resort with one motive in mind _ to party down. But now, said Palm Springs spokesman Frank Cullen, ``We don't see any value in having all these kids here.'' ``This has been a growing sentiment ever since it started getting out of control in the 1980s and after the riot of 1986,'' Cullen said. Some of the estimated 15,000 students in Palm Springs that year went on a rampage, harassing motorists, pulling clothing off women and hurling bottles and rocks at police. Since then, law enforcement has been bolstered during spring break. The 81-member police force, supplemented by Highway Patrol officers and sheriff's deputies, begins a week of 12-hour shifts on Friday. ``We mean business when it comes to enforcing the laws,'' Cullen said. ``Mayor Bono feels very strongly about this.'' It appears that Bono himself may intervene in enforcing local laws. Just last weekend, while riding his motorcycle, his honor chased down a speeding biker. The mayor, who became famous singing ``I Got You Babe'' with ex-wife Cher, said he told the biker, ``You'd better learn to read real fast unless you want to spend the night in jail.'' That's when the young rider noticed ``Mayor Sonny Bono'' printed on the T-shirt. It costs the city about $350,000 to beef up the police force to keep order during Easter week, a time when the city's population swells from about 40,000 to more than 100,000. ``It's just a real drain on our resources,'' said Cullen.

DOC.HEAD: Square Opens Under Heavy Police Surveillance
LaserPhoto BEJ1
DOC.TEXT: Tiananmen Square reopened today with armed police maintaining a conspicuous presence among sparse rainy day crowds. The vast square was closed to the general public on Sunday, a day overseas dissidents had asked students and others to ``stroll'' through it in a silent protest over the military suppression last June of the pro-democracy movement. On Sunday, the city instead brought in some 5,000 schoolchildren who banged cymbals and beat drums as part of ceremonies to encourage civic enthusiasm for the Asian Games to be held in Beijing in September. Chinese offices and factories told people to stay away from the square on Sunday and warned they should not go to Tiananmen on other anniversaries of events highlighting the April-June democracy campaign. The 100-acre square, China's symbolic political center, was open as usual today, but with a heavy police presence. About a dozen police vans and jeeps were parked on the square, and at least 10 pairs of police armed with pistols and walkie-talkies were seen patrolling the plaza. People were not allowed to walk around the base of the monument to revolutionary martyrs in the center of the square. The monument, normally open, was guarded by about 15 police, up from the usual four sentries. Fire trucks with water cannons were parked on the east side of the square next to the history museum and outside the Great Hall of the People to the west. A dozen plainclothes police were seen gathered next to the Great Hall. Small groups of Chinese and foreign tourists wandered around the square and long lines formed as usual to see the body of Mao Tse-tung in Mao's mausoleum on its south end. Crowds were thin, however, because of the wet weather. Heavy police surveillance is likely to continue through April 5, the annual Qingming festival when Chinese honor their dead. Dissidents have also called for a ``protest stroll'' through the square on that day to honor the hundreds of people killed June 3-4 when the military stormed the city to wrest control of the square from pro-democracy students. The capital's beefed-up security forces will also be on alert on April 15, the first anniversary of the death of former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang, the event that touched off the biggest show of resistance to China's political system in the party's 40-year rule.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: For a while, it looked like the joke was going to be on the pranksters at the 11th Annual St. Stupid's Day Parade, which got off to a late start because half the participants forgot to set their clocks ahead. But once the gang gathered nearly an hour after the official starting time, the ritual celebration of April Fools' Day was under way. One participant wore a wedding dress and carried a drum. Patrick Campbell wore a blanket and a Donald Duck safari hat. Founder ``Bishop Joey,'' a fat, balding man in red leotards, arrived to a drum roll and handed out kazoos. ``I am Bishop Joey, head of the Church of the Last Laugh, the world's fastest growing snack religion!'' yelled the bishop, who is also known as actor Ed Holmes of the San Francisco Mime Troupe. ``Wise up! It's later than we think!'' he said, leading the crowd down Columbus Avenue.

George slept here, but he's not in now. Dozens of people received telephone messages Sunday with a number and instructions to call George back. Upon dialing the number, they learned the George they were looking for had left _ quite some time ago. That's because ``George'' is George Washington. And the messages to call him were left by practical jokesters up to a traditional April Fools' Day ruse. The phone number belongs to Washington's Headquarters State Historic Site in Newburgh, north of New York City. George and Martha Washington lived at the site for 16{ months as the Revolutionary War drew to a close. ``When people call for George they don't know it's George Washington they're asking for,'' said site manager Tom Hughes. ``We try to gently clue them in that George is George Washington and that he hasn't been here for a long, long time.'' Hughes said the calls have been pouring in every April Fools' Day for 20 years. He said some callers are slow to accept they have fallen victim to a practical joke. ``There are many people that are convinced that there must be a George here and want to speak with him,'' Hughes said.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Arbor Votes on $5 Abortion Fine
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this college town today weighed a proposal by abortion-rights activists to make abortion punishable by a $5 ticket. Advocates said the largely symbolic act could give local authorities an alternative to criminal prosecution should state or federal laws change to outlaw abortion. ``What it says to police is don't go looking for abortion criminals, go look for murderers and rapists,'' said Sabra Briere, a student services coordinator at the University of Michigan who led the drive to put the measure on the ballot. The president of Right to Life of Michigan said abortion foes in Ann Arbor, rather than fighting the $5 plan, have been concentrating on a statewide petition drive to require parental consent for anyone under 18 to have an abortion. ``We're putting our energies where they're more needed and more effective,'' said Barbara Listing. ``Ann Arbor is a rather unique community,'' she added. ``Even if it does pass, it's really not going to have any effect. Abortion is still legal.'' Voters in this city of 108,000 also were to decide today whether to increase the penalty from $5 to $25 for selling and possessing marijuana. The $5 fine has been on the books since 1974, when the student-backed Human Rights Party petitioned to place it on a ballot and voters passed it. Opponents of the fine said this has created a perception of the city as a haven for drugs, a perception reinforced with the annual April 1 ``Hash Bash'' _ a big marijuana party _ on the University of Michigan campus. Sunday's Hash Bash, billed as a rally to retain the $5 fine, took place only after the American Civil Liberties Union went to court to force university officials to honor a permit issued earlier but then withdrawn. More than 3,000 people attended. About 15 percent of the voters today were expected to be students.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Rivals Shatter Truce
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces clashed with artillery and tanks in east Beirut and mountains to the northeast today, setting fuel tanks ablaze in an inferno that threatened a liquor factory's alcohol stocks. The fighting in the city's Christian sector and fog-shrouded Kesrouan highlands broke out around midnight, shredding a cease-fire brokered by Vatican-backed mediators only a few hours earlier. One person was wounded by sniper fire in the fighting between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's 19,000 troops and the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea, a police report said. At least 839 people have been killed and 2,290 wounded since Jan.30, when Aoun attacked the militia in a bid to crush the main challenge to his authority in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Police said both sides pounded each other's positions with 155mm howitzers, tanks and multi-barreled rocket launchers in the latest flare-up. The shelling set fire to fuel tanks in the Aoun-controlled area of Jal el-Dib in east Beirut before dawn, turning the night sky red as flames shot up over the Christian enclave. The fire threatened to engulf a nearby factory that makes Arak, a licorice-flavored Pernod-like liquor that is Lebanon's national drink. Associated Press photographer Eddy Tamerian said firefighters were battling to keep the blaze from reaching the factory, ``but the fire is so big it could continue to rage for days.'' Witnesses said a dozen other fires burned in the Christian enclave. The short-lived cease-fire negotiated by a three-man committee of neutral Christians on Sunday was the 15th such truce since Jan. 30. So far, neither side has been able to score a decisive victory. But Geagea's forces control two-thirds of the Christian sector, including the ports in Beirut, Jounieh and Byblos and all airfields. Aoun must secure at least one port to open a seaborne supply route. Hostile Syrian troops and their Moslem militia allies ring the Christian sector on its landward sides. Sunday's truce halted two days of fighting in which Aoun tried in vain to break through the Lebanese Forces' defenses in Kesrouan and Geagea's east Beirut strongholds in the Ashrafiyeh and Karantina districts. Beirut's leftist as-Safir daily quoted a source close to Aoun as saying of the cease-fire: ``The committee has failed ... There will be no more mediations.'' Police estimated that up to one-third of the 1 million Christians living in the enclave have fled to safer areas since Jan. 30. Those who remain in the battle zone seek to retain some semblance of normality. Salim Abu-Samra and Rita Zgheib took advantage of Sunday's lull to get married in the Aoun-controlled Zalka area. But they took no chances. Both wore flak jackets over their wedding outfits. Aoun has refused to recognize Hrawi, who was elected in November to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan, and rejects the plan because it does not provide cast-iron guarantees of a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. He considers the 40,000 Syrian troops deployed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate an army of occupation. But there have been signs that Aoun, his forces isolated, is softening his anti-Syrian stand. He confirmed a report in Kuwait's Al-Qabas newspaper Friday that he told Arab leaders he was ready to accept an amended peace accord. He did not say how he wanted the treaty changed, but he has said before his main concern remains getting the Syrians out of Lebanon. Previous mediation efforts have foundered. Hrawi, 64, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun and Geagea, dismissed Aoun as interim prime minister and army commander in November. But Aoun refuses to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Rally For Soviet Jews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT spelling of Sharanksy; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `The ``Solidarity ...'
DOC.TEXT: Former refusenik Natan Sharansky told an estimated 120,000 protesters outside the United Nations not to ease pressure on the Kremlin despite increased Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union. ``When you hear that there are wonderful leaders in the Soviet Union, don't believe this,'' said Sharansky, who left the Soviet Union in 1986. ``It is you who made all these changes possible, it's your struggle to change our future.'' The ``Solidarity Sunday Rally Of Response'' came six days after Hungary's airline, Malev, halted flights to Tel Aviv because of Arab terrorist threats. The airline resumed limited flights from Budapest to Tel Aviv on Sunday. ``To stand resolute against these terrorist threats is to defeat their cowardly perpetrators,'' President Bush said in a statement read at the rally. ``Soviet Jews must be allowed free and unimpeded transit as well as direct flights to Israel.'' In recent years, Soviet authorities have let thousands of Jews leave the country. In 1986, only 914 were allowed out. Thousands of Jews are trying to leave the Soviet Union for Israel. But there are no direct flights between the Soviet Union and Israel, so emigres must travel via third countries, such as Hungary or Czechoslovakia. Arab nations have asked the Soviet Union to slow the tide. Arab nations fear that Israel will settle Soviet emigres in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where thousands of Palestinians are protesting against Israeli rule. Speakers at Sunday's rally expressed alarm over reports that anti-Semitism is growing in the Soviet Union. ``Jews are terrified over threats to their life and limb,'' said Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, chairman of the Greater New York Coalition for Soviet Jewry, the rally's sponsor. ``We say to Mikhail Gorbachev: We have nothing against you or the Soviet Union. But we demand that you crush the anti-Semitic savages in your country.'' Police estimated the crowd at 120,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Territory Drops Charges Against Anti-Abortion Attorney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to restore dropped word `woman.' Changes category code to `i'.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors today dropped charges against an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer accused of violating the nation's most restrictive abortion law by encouraging others to seek abortions. The charges against Janet Benshoof were dropped by territorial Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson. She said she acted in part because of a lawsuit that she considers bigger test of the new abortion law than Benshoof's case. Benshoof, director of the ACLU's Reproductive Freedom Project, was arrested March 21, two days after the law was signed, on charges of solicitation to commit abortion. Benshoof, who came here from New York in hopes of persuading Gov. Joseph Ada to veto the measure, had publicly encouraged women seeking abortions to have them performed in Hawaii. The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. The law has not been enforced since a restraining order was issued March 23. The order is to remain in place until a lawsuit challenging the law is heard in federal court May 8. The lawsuit was filed by ``Marie Doe,'' a pregnant woman who wanted an abortion, the Guam Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Guam Nurses Association, an Episcopal priest and three doctors.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. To Guerrillas: Stay Out of Drug Business
DOC.TEXT: The United States has told Afghan guerrillas to stay out of the drug business or risk losing support in the fight against their country's government, a senior American official said today. ``What we have made very clear to the mujahedeen commanders is that they must stay out of drugs and that they must discourage production of drugs,'' said Melvyn Levitsky, an asssistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters. ``We cannot accept a situation where we are giving assistance to the mujahedeen and they on the other hand are encouraging drug production and drug trafficking,'' he said at the end of a three-day visit to Pakistan. The major mujahedeen groups, which are based in Pakistan, have acknowledged that some of their local commanders are involved in poppy cultivation. But the groups' leaders deny they condone it. Levitsky is touring Thailand, India, Pakistan and Turkey as part of President Bush's efforts to involve more countries in the fight against drugs. Afghanistan produced an estimated 750 tons of opium in 1988, making it the world's second biggest supplier after Burma. The decade-old war between the Soviet-backed government in Kabul and the Moslem guerrillas has destroyed much of Afghanistan's agrarian economy. But the fighting has turned the small centuries-old tradition of poppy cultivation into a multimillion dollar industry and spawned what many Pakistanis call ``the heroin and Kalashnikov culture,'' referring to the preferred automatic weapon of the region's drug lords. The poppies yield a sticky substance that is refined into heroin powder in makeshift laboratories along the rugged frontier and then spirited through Pakistan to markets in Europe and the United States. The United States provides an estimated $300 million in annual assistance to the mujahedeen, or holy warriors, who are fighting to replace the Communist-style government in Kabul. Levitsky said Washington would not support any government in Afghanistan that tolerated or encouraged drug production and trafficking. ``The point we have made to the mujahedeen is that if there is considerable evidence that there is ... support for drug production and drug trafficking we would not be able to assistant that government,'' he said. Opium production and to some extent export have existed for centuries in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Poppy cultivation has declined steadily in Pakistan, but it has risen sharply in Afghanistan, where tribal areas along the mountainous frontier have become a haven for drug lords. The United States has only recently started working with guerrilla leaders to discourage poppy cultivation and launched a program to promote drug awareness among the insurgents, offering incentives to substitute poppy with other crops. But most are unattractive to poppy growers accustomed to huge profits. According to U.S. officials, about 80 percent of the heroin sold in Europe and 25 percent sold in the United States comes from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Iran _ the so-called ``Golden Crescent.'' The rest comes from Mexico and the ``Golden Triangle'' of Thailand, Laos and Burma. ``We are now beginning to look very seriously at a counter-heroin strategy,'' Levitsky told a news conference. ``Many experts believe that the crack-cocaine epidemic may not last so long based on the history of epidemics centered on stimulants like cocaine being rather short-lived and often being followed by an epidemic based on depressants like heroin,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Society of Professional Journalists Announces 1989 Awards
DOC.TEXT: The Society of Professional Journalists has awarded its 1989 Sigma Delta Chi Award for deadline reporting to the San Francisco Examiner staff for their coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake that rocked the California city. The award was one of 26 for print and broadcast journalism announced Sunday by the Chicago-based society, which has issued awards annually since 1940. This year's winners will receive plaques and bronze medallions at a banquet May 5 in Tulsa, Okla. The society's judges said the Examiner's coverage was the best of several entries from newspapers that reported on the disaster in the San Francisco Bay area. ``The lead was exceptional, telling and thorough, as were the pages and pages of articles in the special 16-page all-news issue the day after the earthquake,'' the judges said in a statement. They noted that the special edition was put together without electricity and with only five telephone lines operating. Two San Francisco radio stations and a television station also received awards for their earthquake coverage. KCBS won the award for radio spot news for its 84 hours of continuous commercial-free news and information after the Oct. 17 earthquake, while the television spot news reporting award went to the staff of KGO-TV. The award for public service in radio journalism went to KGO for a retrospective on the Oct. 17 earthquake. The other awards announced by the society were: _ Non-deadline reporting: Tom Hallman Jr., Dave Hogan, Holley Gilbert, Julie Tripp, Fred Leeson, James Long and Lauren Cowen of The Oregonian in Portland for a 12-part series on the impact of drugs in their city. _ Investigative reporting: Bob Paynter, Keith McKnight and Andrew Zajac of the Beacon Journal of Akron, Ohio, for a series of exposes on Ohio House Speaker Vernal G. Riffe Jr. _ Feature writing: Tom Archdeacon of the Dayton (Ohio) Daily News for an account of a 13-year-old boy's accidental slaying by a friend while the two were playing with a handgun. _ Editorial writing: Lawrence Levy of Newsday for ``Killer Taxes,'' a series of editorials on Long Island's economic problems. _ Washington correspondence: Bill Lambrecht of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch for ``Trashing the Earth,'' a series on the toxic waste trade and its effects on the residents of developing nations. _ Foreign correspondence: Nora Boustany of The Washington Post for her continuing coverage of the war in Lebanon. _ Public service in newspaper journalism (circulation greater than 100,000): the Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader for an examination of the politics of education in Kentucky, a series which prompted more than 1,400 letters from readers. _ Public service in newspaper journalism (circulation less than 100,000): a tie between the Washington (N.C.) Daily News and The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass. The Daily News was cited for a deadline story and follow-up on carcinogens in the area's water supply. The Patriot Ledger was honored for a series on the influx of Asian immigrants into the area of Quincy, south of Boston. _ Magazine reporting: Daniel Golden for two articles in The Boston Globe Magazine on the Oglala Sioux of the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. _ Public service in magazine journalism: a tie between Common Cause Magazine and The New Yorker. Common Cause was honored for a series of articles on the corrupting influence of money on the political process in Washington, D.C. The New Yorker was cited for a series on the possible health hazards of low-level electromagnetic radiation. _ Photography: Patrick Davison of The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune for photographs accompanying a series on the exploitation of elk. _ Editorial cartooning: Don Wright of The Palm Beach Post of West Palm Beach, Fla., for a cartoon on the role of the U.S. Supreme Court in the controversy over abortion. _ Editorializing on radio: WBBM-AM in Chicago for editorials by Editorial Director Catherine Cahan on the issue of access for the disabled in the workplace. _ Radio investigative reporting: Phil Rogers of WBBM-AM in Chicago for reports on security gaps at O'Hare International Airport. _ Public service in television journalism (networks and top-40 markets): WITI-TV in Milwaukee for a report on the problems of teen-age sexual activity and pregnancy. _ Public service in television journalism (all other markets): KSAT-TV in San Antonio, Texas, for a story on the impact of uranium mning on Karnes County, Texas. _ Television editorials: Ed Quinn, Paul Sands, Don Lundy, Judy Vance and John Beatty of KGTV in San Diego, Calif., for three editorials on local topics. It was the second year in a row that the KGTV editorial crew won the honor. _ Television investigative reporting: Mark Feldstein, reporter, and Diane Sperrazza, producer, of WUSA-TV in Washington, D.C., for their investigation of allegations of drug use by Washington Mayor Marion Barry. _ Research about journalism: Gregory Gordon and Ronald E. Cohen for ``Down to the Wire: UPI's Fight for Survival,'' their book on the recent history of the news service.

DOC.HEAD: Two Use Extension Cord To Escape Jail
DOC.TEXT: Two inmates climbed down an extension cord taken from a floor polisher to escape from a federal jail, authorities said. The two men, citizens of Colombia, climbed through a window and down the cord Sunday to flee the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan, prison spokesman Alan Stiefel said. They had been using the floor polisher on the second floor of the hospital area of the jail just before they vanished, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. Stiefel said the men cut one of the bars on the window and broke the glass before shinnying down to the street. They were discovered missing at about 7:40 p.m. German Velez, 33, was facing charges of conspiracy to distribute cocaine, Stiefel said. The other prisoner, Maricio Melendez, 32, was awaiting trial on charges of money laundering, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mugabe Takes Election But Result Indicates Dissatisfaction
DOC.TEXT: President Robert Mugabe said his party's sweeping victory in elections gave him a mandate to push ahead with one-party rule, but many said the poor voter turnout indicated dissatisfaction with the government. Mugabe's Zimbabwe African National Union won all but three of Parliament's 150 seats in three days of elections that ended Friday. ``It is a mandate for all our policies, including a one-party state,'' Mugabe said at a news conference Sunday. But the three seats lost to the opposition were two more than after the last elections in 1985. Mugabe had urged voters in this nation of 9.2 million to send no opposition legislators to Parliament and permit his party to amend the constitution to institute one-party rule. That would require a unanimous vote. Also, election officials said only about 54 percent of the 4.8 million voters cast ballots. In the last elections, turnout was more than 80 percent. Most observers said this year's poor turnout raised the question of whether Mugabe, 66, received the strong mandate he was seeking. They said voter apathy was a result of feelings that none of the parties could bring down the nation's record unemployment and soaring inflation, and deal with transportation problems. Mugabe indicated his party would not immediately outlaw opposition parties or bar the three opposition legislators from taking their seats. ``As we get to a stage when we feel the moment has come for us to establish a one-party state, we will do so. They can continue to operate until that moment comes,'' he said. Two of the opposition victories were in eastern Zimbabwe, the traditional stronghold of Edgar Tekere's main opposition party, the Zimbabwe Unity Movement. Tekere, 52, declined to comment on the outcome of the elections. The third went to a member of the Ndonga party, which represents the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, who founded Mugabe's party but now lives in exile in the United States. Mugabe accuses Sithole of plotting to overthrow him. Mugabe led the former British colony of Rhodesia to independence a decade ago after a seven-year guerrilla war.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wanted In Wife's Stabbing Hit By Lightning
DOC.TEXT: A man struck by lightning while police sought him for questioning in the stabbing of his wife was in serious but stable condition today, a hospital official said. Kevin Callahan, 32, was found Saturday, lying semiconscious on a fishing catwalk of the Gandy Bridge, the causeway between Tampa and St. Petersburg. He was barefoot and had suffered injuries to his right hand and left foot, said Marianne Pasha, a spokeswoman for the Pinellas County Sheriff's Department. He managed to tell his rescuers that he was wanted by the police. At Bayfront Medical Center, physicians determined that lightning had hit Callahan's hand and exited through the foot, Ms. Pasha said. His wife, Janet, 28, also was listed in serious condition at Bayfront Medical Center. On Thursday, a neighbor found her in the Callahans' home here, stabbed in the throat and back with a butcher knife, police said. Saturday afternoon, as he lay in a hospital bed, Callahan was charged with aggravated battery. Deputies don't know what Callahan was doing on the bridge's fishing catwalk during a thunderstorm early Saturday. Investigators said he apparently drove there in his mother's car, which was found on the causeway.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes, Man Fatally Shot In Pre-Election Violence
DOC.TEXT: A bomb wrecked two vehicles early today and a gunman killed one man at a political rally in pre-election violence on the southern Aegean island of Crete, officials said. Despite the presence of extra police units flown to Crete to prevent further violence between conservatives and socialists, the atmosphere remained tense as the country headed for crucial general elections next Sunday.
