The bomb was planted in a private garage near the home of Vangelis Kefaloyannis, whose brother Manolis is a ranking member of the conservative New Democracy party, a police spokesman said. No injuries were reported in the blast. None of the cars destroyed in the blast belonged to the Kefaloyannis family, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Shots were fired from a moving car Sunday, killing a supporter of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) and wounding four others. PASOK supporters had set up barricades to prevent conservatives from attending a political rally in which New Democracy party leader Constantine Mitsotakis was scheduled to speak. Police said no arrests have been made. In Athens, a firebomb slightly damaged the suburban political headquarters of George Birdimiris, a socialist candidate for Parliament. Birdimiris, contacted by telephone, said vandals also smashed the window of a PASOK election center in the same suburb of Haidari. A branch of the Ionian bank in another Athens suburb was slightly damaged by a firebomb but the police spokesman said they were investigating to see whether it was connected with the elections. President Christos Sartzetakis dissolved Parliament on March 12 and set elections for April 8 after two inconclusive elections since last June.

DOC.HEAD: Police Smash Computer-Hacking Operation
DOC.TEXT: Federal police today smashed a computer-hacking ring and arrested three young men following complaints from the FBI about illegal intrusions into university computer systems in the United States. The three were charged in Melbourne Court with damaging data in government computers, which is punishable with a maximum of 10 years in jail. Their identities were not made available but police said they ranged in age from 18 to 21. A police spokesman said the suspects were arrested following raids earlier in the day in which computers were put out of action to prevent the destruction of software. The arrests followed a six-month investigation conducted jointly by Australian federal police, the FBI and police in the state of Victoria. Federal police alleged the three hackers _ using the codenames Phoenix, Electron and Nom _ hacked into universities and laboratories in Australia and overseas. Police said it was the biggest Australian-based computer hacking operation uncovered so far. U.S. investigators first discovered an Australian-based hacker was at work in 1988 when it was found the Citibank system had been illegally entered. Further reports of extensive illegal entry to U.S. computers followed throughout last year. A Federal Police spokesman said their investigation began in earnest only six months ago after the Commonwealth Crimes Act was approved last July covering offenses on illegal computer use.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: City Owns At Least 52 Buildings Housing Clubs
DOC.TEXT: New York City's government has been branded the largest single landlord of illegal social clubs. At least 52 social clubs listed by the city as ``nuisance'' establishments are on city-owned property, according to reports published in weekend newspapers. A police crackdown on the clubs started after 87 people, mostly Hondurans, died March 25 in an arson fire at the illegal Happy Land Social Club in the Tremont section of the Bronx. The bodies of 48 of the victims arrived Sunday in Honduras for burial. ``Most of them went to the United States with high hopes, and they came back dead. We are very sad,'' said President Rafael Leonardo Callejas, who joined dozens of mourning relatives at the airport at San Pedro Sula. Wakes and funerals were scheduled in 11 towns in northern Honduras. The New York Times said Sunday that police documents list at least 52 clubs as ``nuisance'' establishments in properties owned by the city, including two in city housing projects. That would make the city the largest single landlord of such clubs. In late editions Saturday, the Daily News reported that as many as 46 illegal clubs are located in city-owned residential buildings. It based its report on a review of Buildings Department and real estate records as well as inspections by city agencies. Lee Jones, a spokesman for Mayor David Dinkins, said the city inherited the clubs along with vast numbers of tenants and abandoned buildings. ``Is it embarrassing?'' Jones said. ``It's something we're going to have to deal with.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Remove Grenade From Guerrilla's Arm
DOC.TEXT: Doctors working for six hours in a sandbagged bunker outside a hospital removed an unexploded grenade imbedded in the right arm of a teen-age guerrilla for three days, officials said today. A U.S.-made M-79 rifle grenade the size of a large egg accidentally entered the right arm of Jayee Khoen, 15, when guerrillas fired the weapon during a training exercise near the Thai border Wednesday, a police officer said. The Bangkok Post newspaper, quoting unnamed border patrol policemen, identified Jayee as a guerrilla working with Khun Sa, the Burmese opium warlord indicted last month by a U.S. court for heroin trafficking. The police officer said Jayee was rushed to Maharak Nakorn hospital in Chiang Mai Saturday after doctors at two other hospitals refused to operate for fear of detonating the grenade, a hospital spokesman said. The spokesman, who could not be identified, said a police surgeon aided by three bomb disposal men removed the grenade Sunday in an operation in a sandbagged bunker on the lawn outside the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Sends Delegation To Moscow; Protest Outside Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with delegation sent to Moscow, protest outside prosecutor's office. Pickup 10th graf ``I fear...''; EDITS thereafter to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania sent a delegation to Moscow today in hopes of beginning talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and President Vytautas Landsbergis said he hoped for a peaceful settlement despite a Kremlin demand he back down. About 1,000 pro-independence demonstrators rallied outside the Lithuanian prosecutor's office in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius against the occupation of the building Friday night by Soviet soldiers, sources said. Both a prosecutor appointed by Lithuania's breakaway government and one sent from Moscow were working in the building today, and employees reported no direct conflicts between the two. Spokesmen for the Lithuanian Supreme Council said legislator Egidius Bickaukas went to Moscow in hopes of starting talks with Soviet leaders, and that three other people including Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas were following. Bickauskas has spent much of the past two weeks in Moscow trying without success to begin talks with the Kremlin on Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Official Radio Moscow quoted Landsbergis as saying Lithuania ``will do everything ... to regulate relations with the Soviet Union.'' Landsbergis ``does not view the present situation as hopeless,'' it said. The republic's Presidium of the Supreme Council legislature met Sunday night, and Landsbergis was expected to address the full legislature during a session this afternoon to discuss a statement late Saturday from Gorbachev. The Soviet president urged Lithuanians to renounce their declaration of independence and then enter into talks with the Kremlin on the basis of the Soviet Constitution. He warned that a refusal may result in ``grave consequences for all of us.'' Gorbachev has promised Lithuania and other independence-minded Soviet republics to establish a constitutional mechanism on secession, but the measure presently before the Soviet legislature gives the Kremlin final authority in such issues. Landsbergis rejected Gorbachev's appeal, saying the Soviet leader was demanding ``impossible things.'' ``It cannot be now demanded that we annul everything that we bore in our hearts,'' he said in comments carried Sunday by the official Soviet news agency Tass. At the republican prosecutor's office, secretary Henrika Pocei said by telephone that the chief prosecutor approved by the Lithuanian government, Arturis Paulauskas, and a team sent from Moscow both had appeared for work today. Soldiers occupied the building Friday night after a failed attempt by the Moscow team to make employees obey their orders, but the workers returned Monday, she said. ``Absolutely everyone is at his workplace,'' she said. About 1,000 pro-independence demonstrators rallied outside the prosecutor's office in support of Paulauskas, sources said by telephone from Vilnius, speaking on condition of anonymity. The last Western correspondents were forced to leave Lithuania on Sunday night on orders of the Soviet government. Last week, Gorbachev said he would use force only if lives were threatened. But Soviet troops subsequently rounded up several dozen Lithuanians who had deserted the Red Army, and seized several buildings, on Friday taking over the Lithuanian prosecutor's office and the main newspaper printing plant. ``I fear they are going to start shooting,'' one middle-aged Lithuanian woman said Sunday. Western reporters counted nearly 30 armored vehicles being unloaded from trains that arrived near the Vilnius airport on Sunday. Others drove through the city, their treads slicing into the asphalt, apparently on their way to a nearby base. On Friday, neighboring Estonia pledged to join Lithuania in its drive to regain independence lost in 1940 when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed them along with the third Baltic republic, Latvia. Latvia is expected to pursue independence next month and possibly move with the caution exhibited by the Estonians, who opted to defer declaring a formal break from Moscow until after an unspecified ``transition period.'' Algimantas Cekuolis, a Lithuanian newspaper editor who has become a de facto spokesman for his republic's government, compared the Kremlin's strong-arm tactics with those of Soviet leaders of the authoritarian past. ``It's the same Brezhnev doctrine at work as in Czechoslovakia,'' only this time, Gorbachev is moving ``with a smile, slowly and easily,'' he said, referring to the premise used by the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev to justify the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. Despite the pressure, Lithuanian officials said they are confident Moscow will become less hostile as Gorbachev presses on with his transformation of the Soviet Union into a more democratic state. ``Our tactics are to hold on a couple of months,'' Cekuolis said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Chief Concedes That Japanese Make Better Cars
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese make better cars, the chairman of Ford Motor Co. says. ``If you look at the Japanese, I think we're equal to some and not as good as the best,'' Harold Poling told The Detroit News in a story published Sunday. ``Our objective is to get there.'' Poling said operational costs, not technology, put the Big Three automakers at a disadvantage. ``Can we get plants in the United States to produce vehicles as inexpensively as the Japanese do? You bet,'' he said. ``But that requires shutting down your plants and starting from scratch. We can't do that. ``We have a work force, we have retirees, we're committed to pensions and we're committed to health care. And that gives us a serious noncompetitive disadvantage going in. We have to deal with that somehow.'' Poling's comments contradict Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca, who has appeared in television commercials and vigorously attacked claims that Japanese cars are better than American-made cars.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Capture Jordanian Infiltrator
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers today captured an armed Jordanian soldier who infiltrated into the occupied West Bank, then approached an Israeli collective farm and hid near a Palestinian village, the army said. A resident of Kibbutz Naaron, a collective farm about five miles from the Jordan frontier, said the farm was alerted by the army and residents stayed awake all night to guard against attack. The resident spoke on condition of anonymity. An army communique said soldiers found evidence of an infiltration Sunday night and followed the Jordanian's trail as he approached Kibbutz Naaron, then went to the Arab village of Auja, about two miles south of the kibbutz. It was unclear how near the infiltrator came to the collective farm. He was captured in a banana grove outside Auja, about five miles north of Jericho. The infiltrator was armed with a U.S.-made M-16 assault rifle, an ammunition belt and extra cartridges, but he surrendered without firing any shots, an army spokesman said. He said the infiltrator was being questioned. An army colonel, who was not identified by name, said on Army radio: ``He had a bullet in the chamber of his gun and tried to escape, but he had no time to shoot because he was surrounded immediately.'' It was the fifth incident along the Jordanian border reported by the army this year and the second involving a Jordanian soldier.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopters Bomb Foxes With Anti-Rabies Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: Helicopters today began bombing the French countryside with thousands of frozen fish balls laden with rabies vaccine, aimed at wiping out the disease among red foxes. Two choppers began the seven-month operation in southeastern France near the Swiss border. Others may be added later this month as the campaign shifts to the Paris region and the north. Hundreds of groundworkers will join the $2.6 million campaign, the nation's largest ever, to stamp out a disease that still strikes thousands of French citizens a year. Officials say no European has died from rabies in 10 years. French attempts to exterminate foxes with guns, traps and poison gas were criticized by animal rights groups. Officials undertook more humanitarian methods four years ago by sowing vaccine around infected areas. The frozen packets are composed of a rabies-vaccine capsule planted in a ball of fish powder. After they thaw, the packets give off an odor that even the craftiest fox finds hard to resist.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots, Airlines, Community Groups Agree on Airport Noise Reduction
DOC.TEXT: Pilots, airlines and community groups have agreed on a drastic noise reduction plan for Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. Irene Jones, a community leader participating in the talks, said the accord could cut noise at the airport, known as ``Sea-Tac,'' in half by 2001. ``This is the most comprehensive noise-control program of any major airport in the country,'' said Paul Dunholter, a noise consultant with Mestre Greve & Associates of Newport Beach, Calif. The agreement was reached late Saturday after 17 months of information-gathering and negotiation. Dunholter's firm provided technical assistance to the Sea-Tac Airport Noise Mediation Committee, a panel of representatives from airlines, community groups, the Port of Seattle and other organizations. The plan will be submitted to Port of Seattle commissioners on Thursday. The port owns the airport. It would establish a steadily shrinking noise ``budget'' for airlines, narrow flight corridors over heavily populated areas and restrict noise during plane maintenance. The agreement is unusual because it was designed by representatives of all groups working together, instead of piecemeal by lawsuits, said Jerry Cormick, a mediator in the talks. ``I'm sure that if any airport tried to to impose the various things these groups did they'd end up in court in a moment,'' said Cormick, who is northwest director for The Mediation Institute. Cormick, who helped referee the talks, predicted the plan would serve as a model for airports around the country. He said the plan's strength lies in its direct, detailed changes to reduce noise. ``It isn't just a set of fuzzy recommendations,'' he said. The plan calls for an allowable noise budget for each airline serving Sea-Tac. The budget shrinks over successive years, as airlines would be encouraged to acquire newer, quieter planes. To reduce ground noise, the agreement calls for less revving of plane engines at night and bans the use of engines to power a plane as it backs out of a gate area. A noise-abatement committee would be established. It would include local residents who would help monitor and enforce noise restrictions. One issue the committee could not agree on was an overall flight plan for the airport. The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed a plan, but Cormick said the committee did not endorse it. Cormick said port commissioners were likely to approve the overall plan. The Port of Seattle spent more than $800,000 on committee activities and technical assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Second Major Politician Quits Amid Allegations of Stasi Links
DOC.TEXT: The charismatic head of East Germany's Social Democratic Party quit his post amid allegations he had links to the hated Stasi secret police, his party announced today. Ibrahim Boehme, who denies the allegations, said he was resigning because it will take ``lengthy investigations'' to clear up the accusations, said August Kamilli, a high-ranking Social Democrat. East Germany has been thrown into a political crisis by charges that many of its politicians had links to the Stasi secret police, which the former hard-line Communist leaders used to control East Germany. The accusations have seriously overshadowed efforts by the conservative alliance that won East Germany's March 18 elections to put together a coalition government with the Social Democrats. Boehme became the second top political leader to give up his post because of allegations of Stasi links. Just before the elections, Wolfgang Schnur admitted former ties to the Communists' secret police and resigned as head of Democratic Awakening, one of three parties in the Alliance for Germany which won the elections. Boehme announced his resignation in a letter dated Sunday, Kamilli said. He went to the former secret police headquarters in East Berlin on Friday to look at former classified documents, aiming to clear his name. But according to Kamilli, after viewing the records Boehme decided a ``speedy clarification'' was impossible and he wanted to avoid ``burdening the young (East German) democracy and the work of the party.'' Boehme's attorney, Friedrich-Wilhelm von Sell, said his client found no incriminating documents. The news came as a surprise, because Boehme had said after looking at the records that he would resume his party post today. However, von Sell said ``more documents need to be searched for and examined.'' He did not elaborate. Kamilli said a special party congress will convene to name Boehme's successor, but did not say when that would occur. Markus Merkel, the part's deputy chairman, took over in Boehme's absence. Lothar de Maiziere, leader of the alliance and the East German Christian Democrats, has also been accused of having worked with the secret police, which he denies. Manfred Stople, top administrator of East Berlin's Lutheran Church, last week examined secret police files kept on de Maiziere and later reported he saw nothing that incriminates the top Christian Democrat. De Maiziere has been trying to forge a coalition with the left-leaning Social Democrats to ensure a majority in the new Parliament in order to clear the way for adopting a plan for swift unification with West Germany. The Alliance for Germany finished with the most votes in the March 18 elections, the Social Democrats came in a distant second, and the Communists third.

DOC.HEAD: Fleet Returns From Antarctic After Catching 330 Whales
DOC.TEXT: Japan's whaling fleet returned from the Antarctic Ocean after catching 330 small whales in the third season of a controversial research program aimed at counting the whale population, officials said today. ``We believe we were able to achieve good scientific results from the research,'' said Nobuyuki Yagi, a Fishery Agency official, after the expedition ended Saturday. The Japanese government hopes the International Whaling Commission, which imposed a worldwide moratorium on commercial whaling in 1986, will decide there are sufficient numbers of some species to partially lift the ban. Japanese whaling officials say the mammals must be killed to accurately determine their age, sex, diet and health. But anti-whaling groups call the research a veiled form of commercial whaling and say skin sampling and other non-lethal research methods are available. Good weather and frequent sightings allowed Japan's four-ship whaling fleet to catch 30 more non-endangered minke whales than its original 300-whale quota during the four-month expedition, Yagi said. The research whaling plan allows a 10 percent leeway in the catch, he said. Yagi said Japan will present its findings on numbers, sex and age to the International Whaling Commission, which currently estimates there are about 730,000 minkes. The commission's moratorium on whaling was passed to allow scientists to study whale stocks without the disruptions caused by regular whaling activities. The commission's scientific commission is to meet in June to recommend whether to extend the moratorium, followed by a decision by the full commission at a meeting scheduled in July. ``Even if the scientific committee agrees after studying the scientific findings that commercial whaling should be resumed, there is a large possibility that the full commission will reject it because of opposition within it to whaling,'' Yagi said. Many of the 38 nations in the commission do not conduct whaling, and several are strong whaling opponents. Under the commission's charter, members are allowed to conduct research whaling whenever they wish, despite the commercial whaling ban. Environmental groups have charged that Japan's research program is actually commercial whaling in disguise. The same boats and facilities are used as in commercial whaling, and the meat obtained by the research program is sold for food, as permitted under the commission's regulations. Japan halted commercial whaling in the Antarctic at the end of the 1986-87 season, when it caught 1,941 whales. It then began a program of research whaling, which it says is aimed at assessing whale stocks. Japanese whalers killed 273 minke whales in the first year of the program and 241 last year. Japanese whaling officials have said at least 825 whales must be caught each year to make the research program scientifically accurate. The quota for the program's first year was initially 875, but strong opposition from environmental groups and from other commission members led Japan to reduce the quota to 300. In the early 1960s, when Japanese whaling was at its peak, whales provided about 23 percent of all meat consumed in the country. Since then, declining whale supplies have turned it into a delicacy.

DOC.HEAD: Duchess of York's Sister Wins Libel Damages
DOC.TEXT: The Duchess of York's sister, Jane Makim, today accepted substantial undisclosed damages and a public apology from the Daily Mirror newspaper over stories suggesting she had an adulterous affair. The adultery allegations appeared in three stories published in October 1988. Two were on the front page. The Daily Mirror also ran a story that alleged Mrs. Makim tried to trick her husband, Alexander Makim, into signing visa papers so she could take their two children to England. The Makims are separated and live in Australia. Announcing settlement of Mrs. Makim's libel action, her lawyer, Andrew Caldecott, told Judge Michael Davies at the High Court in London that the allegations were untrue. Mrs. Makim had not been unfaithful to her husband, nor had she ever plotted to deceive her husband into releasing the children to her, Caldecott said. The articles caused Mrs. Makim considerable distress and embarrassment, he said. Caldecott said the Daily Mirror published a page 5 apology withdrawing all the allegations and acknowledging that Mrs. Makim's behavior ``had been entirely proper.'' Bronwen Fitzpatrick, the lawyer for the Daily Mirror, said the newspaper accepted that the allegations were untrue and should never have been published. She said the newspaper was happy to repeat its ``sincere apology'' for the distress and embarrassment caused. The newspaper will also pay Mrs. Makim's legal costs, Ms. Fitzpatrick said. The Duchess of York, married to Queen Elizabeth II's son, Prince Andrew, left the hospital Friday after the birth of their second daughter, Princess Eugenie.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Rose 2.6 Percent in February
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending rose 2.6 percent in February, the government said today, as unusually warm weather continued across much of the nation. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $436.5 billion. That compared with a revised 2.5 percent gain the previous month, the warmest January on record. January spending was first reported last month to have rise 1.8 percent. Spending in December, the fourth coldest since the government began keeping records 96 years ago, had slipped 0.3 percent. All three major areas of spending advanced, with residential construction up 1.7 percent to $198.5 billion after gaining 2.9 percent in January. Single-family spending rose 3.9 percent to $123.0 billion after a 2.8 percent increase the previous month. Apartment construction advanced 3.4 percent to $21.0 billion after falling 0.5 percent in January. Non-residential spending rose 5.5 percent to $106.4 billion after a 6.1 percent jump in January. Industrial, office and other commercial building led the advance. The volatile government sector advanced 2.1 percent to $93.8 billion after falling 2.0 percent a month earlier. Schools and other public buildings as well as highways and streets were the biggest gainers. The total construction spending figure was up 4.8 percent from the level of building a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Tenants Finds Dynamite Buried in Backyard
DOC.TEXT: Two women unearthed more than 60 sticks of old dynamite in their back yard and police evacuated a two-block area for several hours until the bomb squad could remove the highly unstable explosive. The dynamite, discovered by Melinda Costello about 1:30 p.m. Sunday, was in a rusted metal chest and had no identifying marks. Police said it was not immediately apparent how long it had been buried. Costello, who has lived in the house for more than five years, said the dynamite was in a plastic bag and was wet on top. She said she unwrapped one of the sticks and found the crystallized substance inside. ``My friend and I were digging it up,'' Costello said. ``She was smoking. We were banging around. I guess we were lucky.'' Several hundred residents in a two-block radius around the house in the Bernal Heights neighborhood were evacuated while the bomb squad removed the explosive, said police Sgt. John Sterling. The aged explosive was so unstable it could be triggered by an electrical charge as small as that emitted from a camera flashbulb, he said. While police searched the backyard with metal detectors, bomb squad experts soaked the dynamite in diesel fuel to neutralize the nitroglycerine, Sterling said. Costello's roommate, Isabel Saques, said she discovered the box three or four days ago as she was turning over the soil in her yard for a garden and struck something hard about a foot down. She said she found the metal box under a cement slab but ``left it because I was tired,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Airbag Rulings
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand rulings that protect automobile manufacturers from design-defect lawsuits for not installing airbags. The justices, without comment, refused to revive three such suits against General Motors, one against Honda and one against Nissan. Three federal appeals courts and a California state court ruled in favor of the car makers. The lower courts relied on federal safety laws that until 1986 did not require any type of passive restraints and now give manufacturers the option of installing airbags or automatic seatbelts. The issue in each of the four appeals was whether the federal safety laws pre-empt product-liability suits when the alleged design defect _ the lack of an airbag _ does not violate federal standards. The justices in 1987 refused to order the government to adopt tougher standards for installing airbags or automatic seatbelts in new cars. Then-Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole adopted a so-called passive restraint rule in 1984 that phased in the use of airbags or seatbelts that automatically wrap around front-seat occupants. Car makers were required to equip 10 percent of their 1987 models with such devices. The percentage was gradually increased, and all 1990 model cars are required to have dashboard airbags, at least on the driver's side, or automatic seatbelts. In the cases acted on today, the justices were told that thousands of design-defect suits are pending against car makers, ``over a hundred of which involve claims concerning passive restraints.'' ``The pre-emption issue has been raised or is lurking in every one of them,'' the court was told. Massachusetts resident Patricia Wood sued GM after being left a quadraplegic from a May 19, 1981, accident. The 1976 GM Blazer in which she was a passenger struck a tree. She was not wearing a seatbelt. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out her suit last December. The family of Willard F. Kitts sued GM under New Mexico law after he was killed in a July 17, 1982, crash. He was wearing the seatbelt-shoulder harness system in his 1982 Pontiac. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out the Kitts family's suit last May. Florida suits were filed against GM and American Honda Motor Corp., respectively, after Charles Taylor and Paula Evans were killed in separate two-car collisions. Taylor was driving a 1980 Chevrolet, and Mrs. Evans a 1977 Honda Accord. Legal documents submitted to the justices did not specify the dates of either accident. Combining their cases, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out both suits last June. James R. Meier's family sued Nissan Motor Corp. in California four years ago after he was killed in a crash of his 1982 Nissan Stanza. A state appeals court dismissed the suit last May. Asked by the justices for its views in the Massachusetts case, the Bush administration said Ms. Wood's appeal should be rejected. Justice Department lawyers said the government's policy of letting car makers ``offer the public a choice of either automatic seatbelts or airbag passive protection systems ... is likely to be frustrated if manufacturers are held liable for not installing airbags.'' The cases are Wood vs. GM, 89-46; Kitts vs. GM, 89-279; Taylor vs. GM, 89-852; and Meier vs. Nissan, 89-940.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Born Anti-Arab Rabbi Charged With Sedition
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-born Rabbi Meir Kahane went on trial today on charges of sedition for calling Arabs a ``cancer spreading in our midst'' at a rally protesting a bloody attack on Israelis last year. Defense lawyers called the trial a test case for free expression, and Kahane has won unexpected support from civil libertarians who argue the sedition law is too broad and vague. Kahane, head of the anti-Arab Kach movement and former member of Parliament, said he didn't regret his July 7 speech. ``I admit to the words, and I would say them again at another rally,'' the 57-year-old Brooklyn-born leader said in an interview outside the courtroom in Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem. Only about 20 Kahane followers and journalists attended the trial at Jerusalem District Court. Kahane, wearing a black suit and black skull cap, sat quietly during the four-hour hearing, occasionally shaking hands with supporters and browsing through his appointment calendar. Defense attorney Zvi Hadar and prosecutor Uzi Hasson did not address the charges. They instead debated a defense motion that the trial be dropped because the prosecution forgot to sign the indictment within six months of the alleged offense, as required by law. Judge Ruth Or reserved her decision and did not set a date for the next hearing. Kahane is free on his own recognizance. At issue is a Kahane rally in Jerusalem on July 7, a day after a Palestinian from the occupied Gaza Strip grabbed the wheel of an Israeli bus, plunging it into a steep ravine on the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway. Sixteen people were killed in the attack. ``Kill those who come to kill you,'' Kahane told a crowd of about 1,000 people on July 7. His supporters chanted ``Death to the Arabs!'' and waved signs demanding that all Arabs be expelled from Israel and the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Kahane is the first Israeli to be prosecuted under the sedition law in civil court, said defense attorney Aharon Levy. In military court, the charge was brought three times in the 1950s. The law, which stems from the time of the British Mandate, defines sedition as including speech that promotes ``feelings of ill-will and enmity among different sectors of the population.'' The sedition law has been criticized by civil rights advocates, including the Association for Civil Rights in Israel. ``The use of the sedition law which really has no bounds and no safeguards is potentially dangerous to freedom of speech,'' the association's legal director, Joshua Schoffman, said today. He declined to comment directly on the Kahane case. Kahane served as a member of Israel's Parliament for four years but was barred from running for re-election in 1988 after legislators passed a law banning parties that have a racist platform. Kahane founded the militant Jewish Defense League in the United States in 1968. He renounced his American citizenship to run for Israel's Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Delta Air Lines Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ruling airlines say could make it more difficult for them to merge. The court, without comment, refused to shield Delta Air Lines from binding arbitration that could lead to a monetary-damages award for a flight attendants union. The case stems from Delta's acquisition of Western Airlines in 1986. Western agreed in 1984 that, should it merge, the Association of Flight Attendants would continue to represent Western employees in any newly formed company. Delta's flight attendants were not unionized, and Delta did not honor Western's union contract after the merger. The union then sought arbitration to retain its status as bargaining agent or to win a damage award. A federal judge threw out the union's complaint. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here reinstated it last July, and ordered the dispute submitted to arbitration. The appeals court rejected Delta's argument that arbitration is barred by the federal Railway Labor Act governing labor relations for airlines and railroads. The law gives the National Mediation Board power to certify unions as bargaining agents for airline and railroad workers. Delta said the board's authority over union representation precludes arbitration in this case. But the appeals court said, ``Due respect for privately bargained outcomes cautions against'' freeing airlines from union contracts signed by the companies they acquire. ``The most that can be said in support of Delta's position'' is that it might prompt an airline to ``forego entering into an otherwise desirable merger,'' the appeals court said. The Bush administration urged the justices to reject Delta's appeal. Review is not warranted merely because the airlines fear mergers will be inhibited, Justice Department lawyers said. ``Such concerns are speculative and, in any event, are not rooted in policies deriving from the Railway Labor Act.'' Airline industry groups said the appeals court decision ``creates uncertainty and unpredictability'' for the future of mergers. The case is Delta vs. Association of Flight Attendants, 89-459.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Kills Mother, Three Young Children
DOC.TEXT: An intense, predawn fire rolled through a first-floor apartment today, killing a woman and her three young children, authorities said. The fire in the 2{-story wood-frame tenement in a poor neighborhood on the Northwest Side was reported about 4:30 a.m., said fire department spokesman Tom Sheppard. Firefighters evacuated a family from the second floor. The fire apparently started in the living room, and may have been caused by an electrical fault, said Deputy District Fire Chief Robert Datz. The blaze spread rapidly and its intense heat melted a doorknob, he said. The mother's body was found in a doorway leading to a rear porch, where she apparently was overcome while trying to escape, and the children were found in bedrooms, Datz said. One victim, a 5-year-old girl, died of smoke inhalation at Children's Memorial Hospital, said nursing supervisor Kathy Canick. The others were pronounced dead at other hospitals, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Maryland Officials to Revoke License of Day-Care Center
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today allowed Maryland officials to revoke the license of a day-care center where young children allegedly were abused physically and sexually. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by the center's operator, who said her rights were violated because a psychologist she hired was not allowed to interview the children. The Maryland Department of Human Resources in 1988 revoked the license of the Bo Peep Day Nursery in Bel Air. State officials said there was extensive evidence that some of the 80 children attending the center had been abused. The officials relied, in part, on testimony by the children's parents and by experts who questioned the children and analyzed their behavior. The children themselves did not testify at a state agncy hearing conducted before the center's license was revoked. Deborah Cassilly, the center's operator, said her right to due process was violated because the psychologist she hired was not permitted to talk to the children. She also said the center was open at all times to parents, and that the children were supervised closely. Any abuse of the children did not occur at the nursery, she testified. The Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled last year that Mrs. Cassilly's rights were not violated. The state court noted that Mrs. Cassilly's lawyers were permitted to cross-examine all adults who testified about alleged abuse or who might have influenced any children to describe falsely what happened at the center. The state court also said revoking the center's license did not involve criminal charges, and therefore Ms. Cassilly was not entitled to the same procedural protections guaranteed by a court of law. Hearsay evidence _ what the children told psychologists who examined them _ is admissible in an administrative proceeding, the state court said. The Supreme Court said last January it will decide whether people prosecuted for alleged child abuse have the right to at least one face-to-face confrontation with their accusers. The court will use cases from Maryland and Idaho to define the rights in criminal cases of those accused of child abuse. The case acted on today is Cassilly vs. Maryland Department of Human Resources, 89-1294.

DOC.HEAD: EC Submits Detailed Plan to Protect Intellectual Property
DOC.TEXT: The European Community today submitted a detailed proposal to trade negotiators for new international rules to protect rights to intellectual property such as patents, copyright and trademarks. The proposal is the most comprehensive presented to date in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks and aims to combat increasing counterfeiting and piracy. The EC's draft, to be discussed by negotiators at GATT's headquarters in Geneva, would protect patents for 20 years to prevent third parties from making, using or selling a product without the patent owner's consent. Copyrighting, including the rights of authors, performers and broadcast organizations, is protected for 25 to 50 years and the initial registration of a trademark would be valid for 10 years under the proposal. New accords on intellectual property rights and 14 other sectors of world trade are due to be signed by GATT's 96 members in December at the end of a four-year round of negotiations. While the so-called Uruguay Round talks on areas such as agriculture and textiles are designed to liberalize global commerce, any agreement on intellectual property is likely to increase protection. The United States, the 12-nation European bloc and Japan have pressed for more stringent GATT rules. The United States is expected to submit a similarly detailed proposal on intellectual property in the next few weeks. By contrast, some developing countries led by India have argued that ready access to knowhow is essential to their development and that it should not be controlled through GATT. Peter Carl Mogens, an EC negotiator, said even though conventions already existed in these areas, basic rights were not observed. He said the plans for new rules on trademarks were meant to prevent the sale of counterfeit goods which not only harmed producers of the genuine product but but often posed a health risk, as in the case of counterfeit medicines. A few internationally agreed rules protect patents, Mogens said, but some countries, notably India, refused to respect patents for medicines. The EC draft also sets out protective measures for geographical indications, or appelations of origin, where the quality and reputation of a product is linked with a country or region. Mogens said many countries did not respect an existing international treaty, citing the example of a Third World country that imposed an import ban on French champagne while continuing to sell a home-produced version bearing the same name. He did not name the country. Other areas covered in the EC's proposal are the design of semiconductors, trade secrets and industrial designs.

DOC.HEAD: New Colt Division Owners May Resume Producing Assault-Style Rifle
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, ``We firmly... to UPDATE with NRA reaction; picks up 9th graf pvs, In 1988...
DOC.TEXT: The most popular U.S.-made assault-style weapon _ the Colt AR15 rifle _ may soon be back on the civilian market, and some gun control advocates are dismayed at the prospect. ``They're putting profits over public safety,'' said Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control Inc. ``We don't want to see one more assault weapon on the streets, and this is just going to add to it.'' The Colt AR15 was the most popular U.S.-made semiautomatic assault-style weapon _ rifle or pistol _ when Colt Industries Inc voluntarily shut down production for the civilian market in March 1989. The company took that action a day after the government temporarily suspended imports of similar foreign-made rifles, and it never resumed them, according to Mike Dunn, spokesman for Colt Industries. But Colt Firearms Division of the company was sold March 22 to a group of investors, C.F. Holding, leading to the possible change in policy. Ron Stilwell, executive vice president and chief operating officer of what is now called Colt's Manufacturing Company, Inc., said the company is evaluating whether to start producing AR15s for the civilian market again. ``We are evaluating that,'' Stilwell said in an interview. ``We will have some formal statements on it in the future. ``We firmly believe it is a legitimate sporting system and in fact the only system that can be used for certain national target matches,'' he said. National Rifle Association lobbyist David Conover said, ``Good for them,'' when told today about the possible resumption of AR15 production. ``I think that there are a lot of law-abiding gun owners out there who enjoy owning AR15s and certainly use them in competitive target shooting and recreational target shooting,'' Conover said. In 1988, the last full year of production of AR15s for civilian sale, Colt made 17,368 of the rifles, according to a Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms list. Other U.S. manufacturers made 9,411 copies of the Colt AR15 that year, according to the list. ATF spokesman Jack Killorin said he did not know if those manufacturers boosted production last year to fill the market for AR15s. In all, the list showed that domestic manufacturers produced about 80,000 assault-style weapons in 1988, about half of which were rifles with the same characteristics as foreign weapons banned from import last year. ``Why on earth would any civilized society allow the manufacture and over-the-counter sales of any rifle or pistol designed to accept silencers or bayonets?'' asked Rep. Pete Stark, D-Calif., a gun control advocate who sought the information from ATF. He released the list on Sunday. ``What's a bayonet for ... charging deer?'' asked Stark. The list included 38,108 rifles and an unknown number of Quality Parts Bushmaster rifles and Ruger Mini 14s. It also lists 40,093 pistols, although the ban on imports did not include pistols. First on the list in total production was the Colt AR15, followed by Intratec Tec 9 pistol at 13,770 and the SWD MAC-11 pistol at 12,273. The 26 types of weapons had at least one of the following assault-type characteristics: threaded barrels to accommodate a silencer, flash suppressors that could hide the shooter's position at night and prevent a loss of night vision, provisions for mounting a bayonet or folding or collapsible stocks. The ATF listed such characteristics when it defined 43 types of foreign-made guns as ``semiautomatic assault rifles'' that it banned from import last July. ATF Director Stephen E. Higgins, in announcing the ban, said a study had found that the models were ``not being used for sporting uses,'' a requirement for imports. Two weeks ago, the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime approved a bill that would outlaw domestic assault-style weapons. The bill introduced by Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., outlaws domestic and foreign-made assault-style rifles as well as domestic and imported assault-style pistols which can accept a silencer or a bayonet. The measure, passed 5-3, awaits action in the House Judiciary Committee. National Rifle Association lobbyist Dave Conover said the 80,000 figure from the ATF ``would tell me they're being fairly narrow in their interpretation of what would be a prohibited firearm.'' The NRA estimates there are a total of 3.5 million to 4 million military-style semiautomatic firearms in U.S. circulation. To Whitmore of Handgun Control, however, the total ``points up so clearly that Congress has to act quickly. These things are flooding the market.''

DOC.HEAD: Six People Killed In Highway Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Gabbert said ..., to include time element. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A car veered across a dividing line on a two-lane highway, slid and broadsided another car, killing six people, authorities said. ``I was just down the road assisting some folks with their van when I heard someone let out a scream and I looked to see what it was,'' said Sgt. Lloyd Gabbert of the California Highway Patrol. Gabbert said he saw the two cars collide on the shoulder of the highway in western Stanislaus County, east of San Francisco, and jump about 8 feet into the air. The accident occurred at about 4 p.m. Sunday. Officers said they did not know why the eastbound car crossed into the westbound lane of Highway 132 near Modesto. A Hayward family died in the eastbound car, and two men from Modesto were killed in the other car.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Slick Threatens Pittsburgh's Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with water supply for about 1 million, schools closed, state of emergency, raise reference to spill.
DOC.TEXT: A 30-mile fuel slick drifting down the Allegheny River today threatened the drinking water supply for about 1 million people, and some schools were closed to conserve water. One town of 15,000 people already had to have water trucked in. Other communities drew water from tributaries to the Allegheny, rather than the river itself, to build up reserves. The slick resulted from a landslide that broke a pipeline Friday and released 85,000 to 98,000 gallons of gasoline, kerosene and other fuels near Freeport. Pittsburgh joined with other communities in calling for voluntary conservation of water as it prepared to close its treatment plant. Other treatment centers upstream were already closed. ``We know we're next and we're just waiting for it to get to us,'' said Pittsburgh Water Department spokeswoman Donna Sagmeister. The city's system serves 500,000 people. Classes for about 18,600 students in six Pittsburgh area school districts were cancelled today to conserve water. Gov. Robert P. Casey declared a state of emergency Sunday in the area of the spill. ``We believe we have in place a process and procedure to assure a continued water supply to all affected areas,'' Casey said. Officials flew over the area to search for the leading edge of the slick today but could not immediately determine how far it was from the city, said Pittsburgh Public Safety spokeswoman Margaret Philbin. ``There's a definite sheen farther up the Allegheny River, and a slight sheen was spotted closer to us this morning, but we're not sure if it's from the spill or from another source,'' she said. Pittsburgh Mayor Sophie Masloff said her city had more than three days worth of pure water in its reservoir. Conservation could stretch that by two days, she said. The spill threatened the water supply for about 1 million residents of communities along the Allegheny and Ohio rivers. The Allegheny and the Monongahela join at Pittsburgh to form the Ohio River. Normal water service was shut off to the 15,000 residents of Harrison Township, and water was sent in Sunday by truck, said Nat Mastro, deputy county fire marshal. Preparations were also made in Beaver County, which is on the Ohio River northwest of Pittsburgh. Beaver County Emergency Services Director Russell Chiodo said he was advising eight water authorities serving about 40,000 people to begin saving water. ``We want them to be conservative as all heck right now,'' he said. ``We don't know what's going to happen.'' Buckeye Pipeline Co. estimated it lost up to 98,000 gallons of fuel from its 10-inch pipeline, which extends from Linden, N.J., to the Pittsburgh suburb of Coraopolis. The company said cleanup workers using floating booms and absorbent pads recovered about 20 percent of the fuel. Dennis Vrotny, emergency management director for Brackenridge upstream, said his community and others were drawing water from tributaries to the Allegheny to add to their reservoirs. Fire departments were pumping as much water out of creeks as possible, he said, but cooperation from residents was essential. Vrotny said the water system in Brackenridge, a community of about 4,000, serves 30,000 people. ``I don't think it's going to hold if people don't conserve now,'' Vrotny said. ``As it is, we're losing ground fast.''

DOC.HEAD: Casino Opens With ``Play Money''
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump today opened the Boardwalk's newest casino, and several hundred would-be high rollers flocked inside to slap down play money on the gaming tables and feed real coins to the slot machines. The Taj Mahal Casino Hotel Resort, named for India's sacred 16th century mausoleum, opened in a steady drizzle and a deluge of publicity. ``Turnout is great, considering the weather,'' Trump said, flanked by three bodyguards as he walked the 120,000-square foot casino floor and greeted employees. About 50 state gaming investigators would be checking that dealers know their games and that proper internal controls, surveillance and accounting procedures are in place, said Anthony Parrillo, director of the state Division of Gaming Enforcement. The slot machines accepted real coins but gamblers at the tables _ craps, roulette, baccarat _ had to forego gambling with real money until the state inspectors determine that casino workers are following proper procedures. Two state Casino Control Commissioners assigned to supervise the opening will evaluate each department's performance today and decide whether the casino needs another ``play day.'' Parrillo said the average for the 12 casinos that have opened in the city has been two days of ``play money'' followed by two days of permitting small wagers. The state already has tested the casino in items ranging from the arcane _ security's response to a hostage situation _ to the mundane _ whether the fire alarms work. Employees used Friday and Saturday nights to test their fellow workers at the tables. Parrillo said the Trump Organization has experience in opening Atlantic City casinos, but the sheer size of the Taj Mahal _ a third larger than its biggest competitor here _ leaves room for more mistakes. The Trump Castle Casino By The Bay opened June 17, 1985, and accepted limited cash bets the next day, but the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino had a rockier road when it opened May 14, 1984. Trump Plaza also went to limited cash betting the next day, but went nearly two weeks at 50 percent capacity before the gambling hall voluntarily shut to retrain gaming table employees.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Church Loses Supreme Court Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New lead; picks up 2nd graf pvs, The justices.
DOC.TEXT: A Massachusetts church lost a Supreme Court appeal today over its claim that religious freedom will be violated if state approval is required for its school's curriculum. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that the New Life Baptist Church Academy in East Longmeadow, Mass., must submit for approval the non-religious education its students receive. New Life Baptist, a fundamentalist church founded in 1977, began operating a school in 1981 to provide a religiously based education for the children of its members. State law requires all private schools to offer _ in addition to any religious training _ a secular, or non-religious, education comparable to that provided in public schools. Under state law, the church was required to seek the approval of a local school committee for the school's academic program. New Life Baptist's leaders believe it is a sin to seek such state approval for the school. The church does not object to all state regulation, such as assuring that the school meets health and safety requirements. But lawyers for the church argued that subjecting the school's educational mission to state regulation was too intrusive on religious principles. said state officials should devise some less intrusive way, such as standardized testing, to assure that New Life Baptist Academy students are receiving a proper education in non-religious subjects. But the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed Wolf's ruling last September. The appeals court said Wolf's suggested alternatives would not be any less intrusive, and that the local school committee's proposed method of gathering information for its approval decision does not threaten religious freedom. In the appeal acted on today, New Life Baptist lawyers urged the justices to strike ``a balanced protection for the church as well as the state.'' The appeal argued that in this case ``the government ... has leaped the wall of separation and it is the church crying out for protection.'' The case is New Life Baptist Church Academy vs. East Longmeadow, 89-1118.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater in New York Hospital for Further Treatment of Tumor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs with RNC statement; picks up graf 5 pvs, bgng, ``Atwater has...; edits to conform
DOC.TEXT: Republican Party chief Lee Atwater was admitted to a New York hospital today for additional treatment designed to ``minimize the potential aggressiveness'' of a non-malignant tumor on the right side of his brain. Atwater's top deputy at the Republican National Committee, Mary Matalin, said in a statement that Atwater entered New York's Montefiore Medical Center for a procedure know as a interstitial radiation implantation. The procedure involves inserting a radioactive isotope into the tumor, for which Atwater twice has been hospitalized for treatment in the past month. The statement said the procedure involves local anesthesia and that the isotope would be implanted for five days. ``Consultations with the top brain tumor specialists in the country resulted in a consensus diagnosis that Lee has a small, treatable (tumor) located in the right frontal lobe,'' Ms. Matalin said in the statement. ``After in-depth examination and evaluation, doctors determined that the tumor has the potential to behave aggressively.'' The statement said Atwater, after hearing the diagnosis, opted to have the treatment, described in the statement as the ``state-of the art method of radiation treatment.'' It said results of the procedure would not be known for eight to 12 weeks. But one of the doctors involved in the treatment was optimistic. ``Mr. Atwater's age and excellent physical condition, together with the early diagnosis of the tumor, its size and location, offer favorable circumstances for successful results,'' said Dr. Paul L. Kornblith, a neurosurgeon. Atwater, 39, has been receiving radiation treatments virtually daily since the tumor was diagnosed March 6 after he collapsed while giving a speech at a political event. He returned to work just days after the first episode but was hospitalized again 10 days ago, for two days, after complaining of queasiness. A Republican National Committee statement said doctors attributed Atwater's queasiness to a medication imbalance. After the first episode, Atwater said he was told he would have to undergo daily radiation treatments. His doctors had ruled out surgery for the tumor. Atwater's doctors have not explained that decision but other physicians have said surgery often is ruled out because of the location of tumors. The source said Atwater was ``very upbeat'' Sunday in talking about plans to undergo the treatment. Atwater was named RNC chairman after managing the successful Bush presidential campaign. He also had worked on both Reagan-Bush campaigns. In an interview after being released from the hospital the first time, Atwater said, ``I fooled myself into thinking I was indestructible. I realize now I'm down here on someone else's turf.''

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Issue of Huge Punitive Damage Awards in Alabama Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 4-13, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether huge punitive damage awards in lawsuits may violate constitutional guarantees of fundamental fairness. The court said it will consider overturning a $1 million award and three smaller awards to Alabama residents who successfully sued an insurance company for fraud. The case, of enormous importance to American business, is likely to be decided in 1991. In other action, the court: _ Let stand rulings that protect automobile manufacturers from design-defect lawsuits for not installing airbags. The justices, without comment, refused to revive three such suits against General Motors, one against Honda and one against Nissan. Three federal appeals courts and a California state court ruled in favor of the car makers. _ Left intact a ruling airlines say could make it more difficult for them to merge. The court, without comment, refused to shield Delta Air Lines from binding arbitration that could lead to a monetary-damages award for a flight attendants union. _ Turned away an appeal by a Massachusetts church that says its religious freedom will be violated if state approval is required for its school's curriculum. The justices, without commewnt, let stand a ruling that the New Life Baptist Church Academy in East Longmeadow, Mass., must submit for approval the non-religious education its students receive. _ Allowed Maryland officials to revoke the license of a day-care center where young children allegedly were abused physically and sexually. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by the center's operator, who said her rights were violated because a psychologist she hired was not allowed to interview the children. The justices ruled last year that huge awards in civil suits, often millions of dollars, do not violate the Constitution's ban on excessive fines. But the court left open the possibility that such awards, intended to punish wrongdoers, may be so disproportionate to the actual harm that they violate due-process rights. The Constitution says states may not deprive anyone of property without due process of law. Those wishing to limit damage awards say due process prohibits unlimited discretion by judges and juries. In the case acted on today, Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Co. was found by a jury to have participated in fraud by one of its agents, Lemmie Ruffin. Employees of Roosevelt City, Ala., paid health insurance premiums to Ruffin which he pocketed, according to court records. Cleopatra Haslip, a city worker who had been paying premiums, incurred $2,500 in hospital and medical bills in 1982 and then learned her insurance had been cancelled by Pacific Mutual. The hospital demanded $600 before agreeing to discharge her and her doctor eventually turned her case over to a collection agency. Her credit also suffered from her inability to pay the bills. Mrs. Haslip and other members of the insurance plan sued Pacific Mutual and Ruffin, and a jury in 1987 awarded her $1,040,000. Three others were awarded $10,288, $12,400 and $15,290. It is not clear from records filed with the Supreme Court how much of the money was intended to compensate the workers for actual losses and how much was designed to punish the insurance company. The Alabama Supreme Court upheld the awards last year. The state court said, ``Jury verdicts are presumed correct and that presumption is strengthened when the presiding judge refuses to grant a new trial.'' Pacific Mutual said its constitutional rights were violated because the jury was allowed to award damages ``as a matter of moral discretion without adequate standards as to the amount necessary to punish and deter.'' The company also said it is the victim of unfair discrimination because Alabama law limits punitive damages in some cases, including usury and some areas of consumer fraud. The case is Pacific Mutual vs. Haslip, 89-1279.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Warns Israel Against Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli comment, Iraqi denying plans to build nuclear weapon; Pickup 4th graf `British authorities...'; DELETES 18th graf pvs, `Israeli aircraft...' to CONFORM.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein today admitted that Iraq has sophisticated binary chemical weapons and warned that if Israel attacked it Iraq will retaliate and destroy half of the Jewish state. In a speech broadcast by the state-run radio, Saddam denied Iraq had nuclear weapons and that sophisticated devices bought from the United States were meant for nuclear weapons development. In a statement issued after Saddam's speech, the Iraqi foreign ministry denied that Iraq was trying to develop nuclear weapons and said such charges were intended to prevent it from obtaining ``scientific and technical know-how.'' Saddam lashed out at Western criticism of what U.S. and British authorities said were clandestine efforts by Baghdad to smuggle parts for nuclear weapons and over the March 15 execution of British-based reporter Farzad Bazoft on spying charges. Saddam said Bazoft, a reporter for the London Observer weekly, was a spy and that ``Iraq will chop the heads off spies.'' Israel condemned Saddam's comments on chemical weapons. ``It is high time for the civilized world to act in unity and see to it that Mr. Saddam Hussein will not have the possibility to pursue his irresponsible and criminal designs,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud in Jerusalem. Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Israel had ``no aggressive intention against anyone, including Iraq.'' Asked about the possibility of a preemptive strike against Iraq to neutralize the chemical threat, he said: ``We don't even want to talk about that kind of thing.'' Israeli aircraft attacked and damaged a French-built Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad in June 1981. Israel claimed Iraq was using it to develop nuclear weapons. Baghdad denied the charge. British authorities arrested several Iraqis in London last week as they allegedly tried to smuggle krytrons, or electronic devices used to trigger nuclear weapons, from the United States. In his first public comment on the arrests, Saddam denied claims that Iraq intended to use the devices for atomic weapons. He said the devices were ``only condensors which we bought for $10,500 and it's not logical that these could be used in atomic bombs.'' But he defended Iraq's right to build unconventional weapons. ``I categorically deny that we have any atomic bombs, but let them (Iraq's critics) hear here and now that we do possess binary chemical weapons, which only the United States and the Soviet Union also have,'' he declared. These weapons contain two relatively safe compounds which are mixed shortly before release to create lethal toxic gases. It was believed to be the first time the Iraqi leader has admitted that his country possesses binary weapons, although Western intelligence agencies have long said the Iraqis were developing such weapons at top-secret installations. In a clear reference to Israel, believed to be the Middle East's only nuclear power, Saddam said: ``Those who are threatening us with nuclear bombs, we warn them that we will hit them with these binary chemical weapons.'' ``I also say that if Israel dares to hit even one piece of steel on any industrial site, we will make the fire eat half of Israel,'' he said. Saddam claimed that criticism of his country was intended to intimidate Iraq and ``to pave the way for Israel to attack us.'' Iraqi officials admitted they used some types of chemical weapons during the 1980-88 war with Iran, but claimed they used them in self-defense. They deny widespread allegations by governments and human rights groups that they used chemical weapons, outlawed under a 1925 Geneva protocol, against their Kurdish minoity in areas held by Kurdish separatist guerrillas. Almost 100,000 Iraqi Kurds fled to Turkey in August 1988 claiming that Iraqi warplanes were dropping chemical weapons on their villages. Iraq has warned Israel several times in the past two years against launching pre-emptive strikes against its burgeoning arms industry that Baghdad now says is capable of producing long-range missiles and rockets capable of putting satellites into orbit. In December, Iraq announced it had tested two long-range missiles with ranges of up to 1,200 miles, enough to reach either Tehran or Tel Aviv. Israeli officials said a pre-emptive strike is unlikely despite Iraq's development of missile technology. Saddam's fierce rhetoric comes amid growing Arab frustrations with Israel's refusal to enter peace talks with the Palestinians and an expected flood of tens of thousands of Soviet Jewish emigrants to Israel following Moscow's easing of travel restrictions. Saddam claimed that during the war, ``Iraq was offered enriched uranium and even a complete atomic bomb by people who were either American, British or Zionist agents. But Iraq turned down these offers.'' He gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Defense Tries to Put U.S. Invasion on Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with this morning's defense presentation; pick up 6th graf, `Key to ...
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's defense attorneys showed television footage of the U.S. invasion of Panama today, and called a former U.S. attorney general to the stand as they argued that his drug case should be dropped. The video footage showed scenes of buildings in flames, shootouts and wounded and dead bodies. Defense attorney Frank Rubino said the scenes depicted ``outrageous conduct on the part of the U.S. government.'' Rubino said the video was put together by his staff from reports on the invasion by the U.S. television networks and a Panama City station. Government attorneys objected to much of Rubino's presentation, calling it out of place. But Rubino said it shows Noriega was brought to this country in a ``shocking'' way, a legal standard he says mandates that the 1988 drug case against Noriega be dismissed by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. Earlier, when both sides were complaining about delays in exchanging discovery information, Hoeveler told the attorneys he wouldn't allow such issues to postpone Noriega's trial. It is set to begin Jan. 28, 1991. Ramsey Clark, former U.S. attorney general, testified about reports of mass graves and seeing body bags, some with more than one body in them, during an independent inquiry he made in Panama. In pre-hearing papers filed with the court, the defense cites ``conduct by the United States government shocking to the conscience and in violation of the laws and norms of humanity.'' Clark claims civilian deaths following the Dec. 20 military action numbered in the thousands, rather than in the hundreds, as the Defense Department has stated. It also includes reports that civilians, and in some cases the press, were deliberately targeted by U.S. soldiers. Key to the defense arguments is a 1974 case called United States vs. Toscanino, in which a federal appeals court ruled that shocking behavior in the arrest of a defendant, even outside the United States, could be grounds for freeing him. Noriega attorney John May said that U.S. abuses during the invasion were sufficiently shocking to require a dismissal. ``Nothing General Noriega is accused of could ever justify such a deliberate taking of human life,'' the dismissal motion said. ``If ever there were a case where our courts must act to deter such conduct from occurring again, such a case is this.'' The U.S. Attorney's office here defends the invasion. It calls the civilian deaths ``an unfortunate, unavoidable byproduct'' of any military action in an urban area. The prosecutors also question the findings and integrity of the investigatory commission. ``We believe that the report of that organization is extraordinarily biased and inaccurate in many respects,'' says the response filed by prosecutors Michael Sullivan and Myles Malman. But there is no need to debate the invasion, the prosecutors say, because the U.S. Supreme Court has never accepted the Toscanino rule. In fact, they say, the high court recently ruled in United States vs. Verdugo-Urquidez that the Fourth Amendment protection against illegal search and seizure does not apply to non-citizens outside the country, the prosecutors say. The defense had subpoenaed Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to testify today, but U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler quashed the subpoena. The subpoena had asked Powell to produce civilian and military casualty predictions made prior to the invasion, reports on civilian deaths, lists of weapons used and any information on ``management of the press.'' Noriega faces 145 years in prison if convicted of a variety of drug counts in a 1988 indictment that accused him of accepting bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: List Prosecution Says Family Executed; Defense Blames Mental Disease
DOC.TEXT: John E. List stopped the mail and the papers, wrapped up his affairs, then ``systematically executed'' his family of five 18 years ago and disappeared, a prosecutor said in opening List's murder trial today. List, a former Sunday school teacher, devised a plan that ``turned into a day of horror'' at the family's 18-room mansion in Westfield, said Brian Gillet, an assistant Union County prosecutor. ``This defendant systematically executed his wife Helen, his wife of almost 20 years; his 84-year-old mother Alma, his daughter Patricia; his son Frederick; his son John. All his own flesh and blood,'' Gillet said. In reviewing evidence the jury would hear, Gillet said List left notes at the children's school and employer, saying the family had to go to North Carolina. He also stopped mail delivery and canceled newspaper subscriptions. Like the accountant he was, List ``closed the books, balanced out the accounts before he fled and took on a new life,'' assuming another identity almost immediately, Gillet said. ``John E. List was buried long before Alma, Helen, Patricia, Frederick and John were laid to rest,'' the prosecutor said. Until today, defense attorney Elijah L. Miller Jr. said little publicly about how he plans defend List on five counts of first degree murder. His opening statements said the killings had to be viewed as the product of a ``fragmented'' man unable to deal with changing times. List, a war veteran, began to see ``failure at every turn'' in an age of rebellion and changing morals. He saw his family disintegrating and falling from their religion, but he had to do something under church teachings that he was charged with their salvation, Miller said. ``He committed these acts with love in his heart,'' said Miller. ``For the salvation of his family, he had to act as he did.'' Miller said that he would trace List's past to show ``these killings are something other than murders.'' Miller said List still suffers from a mental disease. He argued that List's ``diminished capacity'' could let the jury return a conviction on a lesser charge. On Dec. 7, 1971, police found the bodies of List's 45-year-old wife; his mother; and the children, Patricia, 16, John Jr., 15, and Frederick, 13. Police said the family was killed Nov. 9, 1971. For 18 years investigators pursued the case, but it was a segment about the killings on the TV show ``America's Most Wanted'' that got List back to New Jersey. Investigators said shortly after List fled New Jersey he assumed the identity of Robert P. Clark and lived in the Denver area, gradually assuming his old life, working as an accountant and joining local Lutheran churches. He moved to the Richmond, Va., suburb of Midlothian in 1987 with the woman he married in 1985. A former Virginia neighbor saw the TV segment and had her son-in-law call the program. List was arrested June 1 in Richmond.

DOC.HEAD: United States Contributing $100 Million to Bridge Loan for Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: The United States is contributing $100 million to a $400 million bridge loan for Venezuela, the Treasury Department announced today. ``United States participation in this arrangement reflects continuing support for Venezuela's strong comprehensive economic reform package which is being implemented with the support of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank,'' the Treasury said in a statement. ``This support comes at a time when Venezuela and the commercial banks have recently reached agreement in principle on a medium-term finance and debt-reduction package,'' it continued. ``We welcome this agreement, which should provide new money as well as the potential for significant debt and debt service reduction in support of Venezuela's strong economic program.'' The Treasury said the loan would be repaid with future disbursements from the IMF and the World Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Makes Pitch for Atlanta as Olympic Host City
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today made a pitch for Atlanta to host the 1996 Summer Olympics and promised not to let politics intrude ``no matter what's happening.'' Bush, after addressing a broadcasters convention, visited a scale-model exhibit of new and existing sport facilities that the Atlanta Organizing Committee has promised in its bid to win the Games. Bush greeted several members of the International Olympic Committee who were here checking out what Atlanta had to offer. ``I don't want to put the hard sell on anybody, but I feel very strongly about it, and I also believe it is very good for the Olympics to ... come to the United States right often,'' Bush said. The United States boycotted the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow to protest the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and the Soviet Union in turn stayed away from the 1984 Games in Los Angeles. ``We've got to keep politics out of the Olympic Games and we will try very hard to do it. ...,'' Bush said. ``No matter what's happening out there, I'd like to see us keep it out of the Olympic Games,'' said the president, an avid sportsman himself. Billy Payne, head of the Atlantic Olympic committee, said a decision is due Sept. 18 and he views Athens, Greece; Melbourne, Australia and Toronto, as Atlanta's main competition.

DOC.HEAD: Six Dead, 27 Injured in Car Bombing Near Police Academy
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded outside the National Police Academy while cadets were doing their morning exercise today, killing six people and wounding 27, the armed forces said. One police officer, four cadets and a civilian died in the 6:30 a.m. blast, the armed forces press office said in a statement. Twenty-four cadets and three civilians were wounded. The armed forces blamed the attack on urban commandos of the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, which has been at war with a series of U.S.-backed governments for a decade. The attack occurred outside the National Police Academy, eight miles from the capital in the town of Santa Tecla.

DOC.HEAD: Taxpayers Paid $2.3 Million to Defend Operators Of Rocky Flats
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has paid about $2.3 million since 1979 for legal fees of Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant operators, who were sued on behalf of workers allegedly killed or injured by radiation, a newspaper reported today. Yet total damages sought by seven widows and one living worker whose cases have come to trial is only about $1 million, The Denver Post said. The Post quoted federal records which show the government's share of that potential liability is less than $400,000. The rest of the claims would have been paid out of a state fund created by Colorado employers. To date, two widows have won workers' compensation lawsuits, collecting a total of about $60,000. A third case has been settled out of court for an estimated $10,000. In each case, the government has argued that the workers' deaths and cancers were caused by something other than exposure to on-the-job radiation. The inspector general of the Department of Energy, which owns the Rocky Flats plant outside Denver, will conduct an informal review to determine if the legal fees are justified, said Rob Jacques, an assistant to the inspector general. The legal fee records, obtained by The Denver Post through the Freedom of Information Act, show that the money was paid by the plant's two previous operators _ Dow Chemical and Rockwell International Corp. _ to the Denver law firm of Martinez & Allman. The Department of Energy then reimbursed the plant operators. Attorneys Robert Allman and Larry Martinez said the key legal decisions in each case were made by their clients _ the plant operators and the Energy Department. Federal records show the two lawyers billed an average of nearly $30,000 a month from June 1984 through January 1990, even though most of the official legal appearances, hearings and appeals were concluded before June 1984. During 1986 and 1987, state records show almost no formal legal proceedings took place on any of the cases. Yet the lawyers charged the government $341,000 and $273,000 for each year, respectively. Between 1979 and June 1984, the government spent roughly $425,000 defending its operators, the records show. Since then, the government has paid almost $1.9 million on legal fees.
