Jack Kemp, secretary of the department of Housing and Urban Development, said he signed the waiver because it ``will help residents of rent subsidized housing earn extra income and will also help the Census Bureau secure a more accurate account of the number of low-income, rent-subsidized Americans.'' The Census Bureau hires the temporary workers to canvass homes in which residents did not return the 1990 census form received in the mail. The temporary jobs pay up to $8 an hour. HUD and Census Bureau officials said hiring residents of subsidized housing complexes to canvass their neighbors should help provide a more accurate count. The formulas for several HUD grant programs are based on census information. Low-income residents who receive rent subsidies generally pay a percentage of their income for rent. The waiver signed by Kemp would exempt any income from the Census Bureau temporary jobs from the rent calculation.

DOC.HEAD: Opening Arguments Tuesday in Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor in the trial of Imelda Marcos presents opening arguments Tuesday in an effort to prove that she helped plunder more than $160 million from the Philippines' treasury to buy four Manhattan properties. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella and defense lawyers will give a preview of their court strategies in the fraud and racketeering trial of the former Philippines first lady and her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. The trial, which has been in recess since the jury was sworn in last Tuesday, is expected to last three or four months. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan has ruled that bank records from the Philippines, Hong Kong and Singapore could be used as evidence. They include 2,000 pages of records from two trust accounts at the Standard Chartered Ban of as much as we are,'' agent Vern Gauby told a reporter.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Communist Party Reported About to Change Name
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party will change its name on Tuesday and that of its newspaper, informed sources said. The change will coincide with the beginning of a more realistic dollar exchange rate. The state news agency BTA said Bulgarians traveling abroad will have to pay up to four times as much for U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies, but no other details were given. Vladimir Vladimirov, director general of the National Bank, announced that the new rate for one dollar will be 9.60 leva for those seeking to buy dollars. Those wishing to sell dollars to the government can do so at a rate of 9.69. But BTA later said the new rate would be a floating exchange rate governed by supply and demand. The agency also reported that while final results of a membership referendum were not available, most favor the Communist Party being renamed the Bulgarian Socialist Party. Sources, speaking to The AP on condition of anonymity, said a decision to that effect is to be announced after a session Tuesday of the party's Supreme Council, successor to the longtime policy-setting Central Committee. The sources also said the party newspaper would be renamed but did not elaborate. Last week, however, a small, independent party challenged the forthcoming decision, saying it already had the same name _ the Socialist Party. A crane meanwhile lifted the huge Rabotnichekso Delo (Workers' Affairs) sign off the roof of the Communist Party newspaper building in Sofia on Monday. The newspaper, with a daily circulation of 800,000, from now on will be published under the name Duma (Word), BTA said. BTA said the National Bank on Monday cut by more than half the amount of freely convertible currency that can be purchased by Bulgarians traveling abroad. They are now entitled to buy $30 worth instead of $65. The previous dollar exchange rate was about 2.50, long considered unrealistic. Informants said the new rate was designed to curb a growing black market. The measure will make it even harder for Bulgarians to visit Western countries, however.

DOC.HEAD: 100 British Policemen Mobilized to Hunt Suspects After Tax Riot
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Monday mobilized 100 policemen to track down suspects in a weekend anti-tax rally that erupted into a riot and one of the worst outbreaks of violence in modern-day London. The courts took a hard line with some of the 339 people already arrested. At least 12 taken into custody during Saturday's six-hour melee at Trafalgar Square were refused bail at five London courts. Most of the 68 people in court Monday were in their teens or 20s and gave addresses in London ``squats'' _ illegal residences in abandoned houses or apartments. The charges ranged from arson to criminal damage and theft to threatening behavior. Scotland Yard police headquarters said the riot over the imposition of a new tax by the Thatcher government on every adult caused hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage and injured 374 of the 2,198 police officers involved. Police said 86 civilians were injured. Charges of blame for the violence meanwhile flew back and forth. Authorities accused anarchists, who in turn blamed police. The government partly blamed the opposition Labor Party, and a Labor member accused the government of playing politics. Home Secretary David Waddington said 100 policemen were taking part in a large-scale search for suspects headed by chief Det. Roy Ramm. The detective appealed to the news media and public to provide film and photographs of the riot to help police identify troublemakers. Magistrates set bail for some suspects charged with public order offenses. However, as a condition of bail, some were forbidden to attend any more anti-tax demonstrations, while others were barred from coming within one mile of Trafalgar Square. The violence broke out after a peaceful demonstration by about 40,000 people. Police were attacked, automobiles burned and overturned, shop windows smashed and shops looted. The demonstrators were protesting a new tax called the community charge, which is levied on every adult to finance local government services across the country. The old tax was levied on property owners. Many households will be paying up to one-third more, while millions of people will be paying the tax for the first time. Demonstrations against the tax have broken out across Britain, and the levy has been blamed for contributing to drop in popularity for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives. The Yard said anarchists in a group called Class War were prominent in starting trouble. However, Andy Murphy, a leader of the group, said: ``The police were attacked and quite rightly so.'' In comments to BBC radio, she called the rioters who battled police ``working-class heroes.'' The demonstration organizers, the All Britain Anti-Poll Tax Federation, blamed a small group of troublemakers but also accused police of losing control. In a noisy House of Commons debate, Waddington denied the demonstration had not been sufficiently policed. ``What happened on this occasion was that it was not just a few, but 3,000 or so members of our society behaved in a most disgraceful, criminal and uncivilized fashion,'' said Waddington, the Cabinet minister for law and order. The police showed courage and restraint in dealing with ``some of the most ferocious violence we have ever seen on the streets of London,'' he said. Both opposition and Conservative government politicians condemned the violence. However, Waddington said part of the blame had to be shouldered by the opposition Labor Party, because 30 of its members had urged citizens not to pay the poll tax. ``Do they really expect the people they seek to influence to stop just trying to break the tax _ and not in fact encourage them to break policemen's heads?'' Waddington said. Labor Party lawmaker Peter Mandelson called Waddington's attack ``mindless mudslinging.'' He said the minister was trying to score political points.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Police Chief Running for Mayor's Job
DOC.TEXT: Former Police Chief Maurice T. Turner, vowing to return honesty and integrity to the local government, announced Monday that he will run for mayor of the nation's captital. ``We need leaders who serve for the public good, not personal gratification,'' Turner said. ``We need leaders who surround themselves with people of integrity, not people who merely want a city contract.'' Turner, a policeman for 32 years and chief for the last eight, said that improving the school system and fighting drugs and crime would be the top priorities of his administration. He offered few specific proposals but promised to listen to the complaints and suggestions of citizens. Turner, 54, switched to the Republican Party last July, fueling speculation that he intended to run for mayor. He is the only Republican in the race and is making his first run for public office. Democrats outnumber Republicans about nine to one in the nation's capital. The former chief and Mayor Marion Barry clashed publicly over police staffing levels during Turner's final months in office.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels, Ethiopians Meet in Yemen for Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian officials met with four of the five major Eritrean rebel groups on Monday for peace talks aimed at ending Africa's longest civil war. While the main guerrilla faction did not attend the meeting in this North Yemenese capital, officials hope the talks will develop into an overall peace conference involving all factions. At the opening meeting Sunday night at the North Yemen Foreign Ministry in San'a, both sides stressed their desire to end the guerrilla war with a lasting political settlement. They then went into closed session. Shewandani Yalta, a member of the Politburo of Ethiopia's ruling Labor Party, led a 14-member delegation to the talks sponsored by North Yemen, a country facing Ethiopian on the other side of the Red Sea. In attendance were rebel leaders from the Eritrean Liberation Front, the ELF-Revolutionary Council, the ELF-National Council and the ELF-Unified Organization. The Moslem-dominated groups claim to represent half the disparate rebel forces fighting for autonomy for Ethiopia's northern province since 1962. Former President Jimmy Carter arranged talks between the leading Eritrean Popular Liberation Front and Ethiopian authorities in Atlanta last year and then this year in Nairobi, Kenya. The Front, which was not attending the talks in North Yemen, launched a new offensive in February and recently captured the port of Mussawa. No one at the new talks has pointed to any basis for an agreement, although there is a U.N. resolution calling for Eritrean self-rule. An Eritrean source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``The main thing is to decide whether to continue negotiations or not, and then possible solutions will be laid out.'' The San'a meeting is the second between the four smaller Eritrean groups and the Ethiopians. The first, mediated by the East African neighbor Sudan, was held in Khartoum in March and April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Treated at New York Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with information on nature of the tumor; quotes from physicians and President Bush. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater entered a New York hospital Monday for intense radiation treatment of a type of brain tumor that experts say is persistent and dangerous. Mary Matalin, chief of staff for the Republican National Committee, said in a statement that doctors had determined Atwater has an astrocytoma, a type of tumor that has ``the potential to behave aggressively.'' The tumor was diagnosed last month after Atwater collapsed during a speech. Dr. Stuart Grossman, director of neurological onocology at the Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore, said astrocytomas ``are tough tumors to cure. They do have a tendency to come back.'' Astrocytomas are graded I through IV, although grade IV is usually called by another name. The announcement did not identify the grade of Atwater's tumor. ``All of these types of tumors are potentially curable and potentially fatal,'' said Dr. R. William Harter, an associate professor of radiation onocology at Georgetown Unversity Hospital. He said for a grade I astrocytoma the five-year survival rate is about 50 percent when treated aggressively. For grade II, he said, the five-year survival rate is 25 percent, and for grade III it is 10 percent to 20 percent. Grade IV, more commonly called glioblastoma multiforme or anaplastic astrocytoma, are always fatal, Harter said. Grossman cautioned that ``a five year survival does not equal cure.'' ``These types of tumors usually come back,'' he said. Another physician, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said patients with astrocytomas ``run a substantial risk of dying from this disease at some point.'' One source familiar with the case said doctors found cells within the tumor that had the potential for sudden growth. The source, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said there had been no growth in the tumor diagnosed March 6. Atwater, 39, checked into New York City's Montefiore Medical Center, where doctors planned to insert radioactive isotopes into the tumor on the right side of his brain. After the procedure, done under local anesthesia, the isotopes remain implanted for five days. The treatment is under the direction of Dr. Paul L. Kornblith, chairman of neurological surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. ``Mr. Atwater's age and excellent physical condition, together with the early diagnosis of the tumor, its size and location, offer favorable circumstances for successful results,'' Kornblith said. ``The treatment provides a higher dose of radiation targeted on the tumor over a shorter time period,'' Matalin said. The RNC announcement said Atwater's tumor is in the frontal lobe. Both Harter and Grossman said the frontal lobe is more easily treated without the risk of loss of function than are most other areas of the brain. Harter said patients receiving radioactive isotope treatment directly on brain tumors seldom suffer acute side effects and most are able to work while the treatment is under way. Every two to three months after receiving such therapy, patients are re-examined, with X-ray or magnetic images taken to determine if the tumor is growing. ``You can have a problem on down the line in that the area exposed to the radiation may shrivel up,'' Grossman said. ``The brain doesn't handle such dead tissue very well, so you have to go in and clear it (of dead cells.)'' In Cincinnati, President Bush said he wished Atwater his best. ``Right now, there's nothing more important for Lee to do than get well, and I know that's exactly what he intends to do given that fighting spirit,'' Bush said while campaigning for George Voinovich, the GOP gubernatorial candidate in Ohio. After Atwater was first hospitalized, doctors said the tumor was non-malignant and would be treated with daily radiation therapy over a five-week period. ``The doctors are sticking by the original thing, that it's small and it's very treatable,'' said Charles Black, a political consultant who is a close friend and former business partner of Atwater. ``What he did was seek out the most aggressive kind of radiation treatment you can get,'' Black said. ``What these guys are going to do is in a week give him more radiation than he would get over the whole five weeks with the program he was on.''

DOC.HEAD: Soggy Commuters Walk, Bicycle And Carpool As Buffalo Transit Shuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The shutdown ...,' to CORRECT spokeswoman's name to `Shriver,' sted `Shrver.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BF2
DOC.TEXT: Soggy commuters walked, bicycled and joined in carpools to get to work Monday and half of Buffalo's high school students were absent from classes because of the city's bus and subway system shutdown. ``I just don't understand this at all,'' said Sheila Addison, who walked three miles through drizzle and fog to her job at a downtown bank. A chance at reviving some transit service in time for Monday evening's rush hour fell through when commissioners of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority balked at a financial rescue plan that would have eliminated all weekend service and 125 of the system's 600 bus drivers. The commissioners agreed to delay taking a formal vote on the plan after Erie County Executive Dennis Gorski told them aides to Gov. Mario Cuomo were willing to consider contributing additional state money. A Cuomo spokeswoman later said she knew nothing about that possibility, and the commissioners went home after deciding no immediate help would be forthcoming from the state. Bus and subway service for 120,000 daily riders ended early Sunday when the transit agency ran out of cash. The shutdown of a six-mile subway line and 1,015 miles of bus routes came three days after the County Legislature rejected a proposed tax on utilities to raise $9 million for transit. The system costs $55 million a year to run and depends on a combination of farebox revenues and grants from the county, state and federal governments. It barely avoided a deficit in the fiscal year that ended Friday and faced a $15.6 million gap in the new fiscal year budget. The shutdown left 11,000 public high school students without a ride to school. Attendance was as low as 40 percent at some high schools, said school spokeswoman Kathy Shriver. She said no decision had been made about whether to penalize students for their absences. Buffalo Teachers Federation president Philip Rumore said the union would wait for the transit agency to vote on the bailout plan before asking a federal judge to order service to be restored. The union says the shutdown has illegally disrupted the city's desegregation plan. Public and private schools in New York's second-largest city remained open and Buffalo's 25,000 elementary students rode privately contracted buses as usual. Commuters fared better than the students, but nearly everyone had a story to tell. ``My sister-in-law has this old junky piece of car and said we could use it if we could find out what's wrong with it,'' said Tequita Craig, a nurse's aide. ``We dished out $70 for a new battery.'' Police Capt. John O'Keefe said traffic density was near normal, but a lot of motorists appeared to have joined carpools. ``Where you'd usually have one guy in a car or two guys, today there were six guys,'' O'Keefe said. Others braved the chilly, damp weather to get to their jobs. ``Everybody was walking together with sneakers on. Can you believe it?'' said a woman named Tennizee High, who walked 1{ hours to her downtown job. County and transit officials met all night to devise a new fiscal plan for the transit system. County officials agreed to raise real estate transfer taxes and, starting next year, to allocate a portion of sales tax revenue to transit. The transit agency agreed to raise fares from $1 to $1.10, raise transfers from 5 cents to 20 cents and make $2.5 million in budget cuts. The deal collapsed when transit officials, rechecking their figures, discovered they had been using the wrong fiscal year in their calculations and that $3.7 million in budget cuts would be necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Blocks Execution In California
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to let California carry out its first execution in 23 years, letting stand an order that blocks a murderer's Tuesday trip to the state gas chamber. By a 6-3 vote, the court rejected an emergency request from state authorities who wanted to execute Robert Alton Harris on schedule. A federal appeals court judge Friday had ordered the execution postponed, ruling that more study of Harris' mental condition may be needed. Judge John Noonan of the San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Harris should be kept alive until a three-judge appeals court panel studies whether his lawyers or the psychatrists they hired were incompetent in failing to have him tested for brain damage and other serious mental disorders. Harris was convicted of killing two San Diego boys in 1978. The nation's highest court had ruled against him four times previously. California Attorney General John Van De Kamp sought to have Noonan's order set aside, and his emergency request was submitted to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. She referred it to the full Supreme Court. The court voted to deny the state's request. Its brief order read: ``The application of the attorney general of California to vacate the (appeals court) order, dated March 30, 1990, staying the execution of sentence of death, presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the court is denied.'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy voted to set aside the stay of execution and let Harris die.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Appeals for Peace Between Rival Blacks in South Africa
With AM-South Africa
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela stood on a muddy hilltop Monday in Natal province's ``Valley of Death'' and pleaded for peace, while members of warring Zulu factions glared at each other from opposite ridges. ``This violence must end,'' said Mandela, vice president of the anti-apartheid African National Congress. He was speaking to about 200 ANC supporters in Imbali, a township where rival blacks have battled since 1983. The main combatants are ANC supporters and backers of the Inkatha party, which is headed by Zulu homeland leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Since heavy fighting began in 1986, more than 4,000 blacks have died in southeastern Natal Province. The battles have intensified the past week, with at least 53 injured, hundreds injured and thousands made homeless. When the sun sets after soaking autumn rains on the grassy hills of Edendale Valley, the night brings the sound of gunshots, screams and the explosion of gasoline bombs. The sun rises through the morning mists to reveal bodies lying in the streets and fields, houses aflame, and women and children hurrying along the roads carrying their hastily wrapped belongings. Mandela went to the heart of what has been dubbed the ``Valley of Death'' with two messages: that he and other ANC leaders cared what was happening, and that the enemy is not fellow Zulus. ``We are not fighting Inkatha. We are fighting apartheid and the forces of oppression,'' he told a crowd of 2,000 earlier in the day in Edendale. They shoved into a church hall to hear him, then stampeded out to chase and cheer his car along the wet dirt road. Later, he repeated the message in nearby Imbali, where local residents said four men died the night before in fighting. Hundreds of ANC supporters lined the ridges of the hills around the township to glimpse Mandela's motorcade on the opposite hill. They said they were afraid to pass through the section of town controlled by the rival Inkatha group to hear Mandela's speech. As he talked to the few hundred who tramped across muddy fields to see him, the crowd stirred, mumbled and pointed to Inkatha men on an opposite hill. Mandela repeated his desire to meet with Buthelezi, an old friend despite their political differences. He had suggested holding a joint peace rally Monday with the Inkatha leader, but Natal ANC leaders and other anti-apartheid figures persuaded him to cancel Friday. Their view seemed to predominate in the non-Inkatha sections of Imbali, where young men in the streets said a Mandela-Buthelezi meeting would change nothing, and a joint peace rally would be dangerous. ``I think he thought it would stop the war,'' 20-year-old Sibusiso Peters said of Mandela's desire for a peace meeting. ``But I think we know better.''

DOC.HEAD: Showers and Storms Sweep South And East; Snow Freezes North
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms rumbled through much of the South and the East Coast on Monday, and snow kept parts of the northern Midwest frozen. Snow fell in northern Lower Michigan, Upper Michigan, eastern and northern Wisconsin, and northeast Minnesota. As much as 2 inches of snow fell near La Crosse, Wis. Scattered showers and thunderstorms fell from the Texas coast to the Florida Panhandle and southern Alabama, and from western Virginia to eastern West Virginia, the Maryland Panhandle, western Pennsylvania and western New York. Showers spread from central New Mexico to southwest Texas. Rain extended from western Ohio to Indiana and southern lower Michigan. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Monday was 15 degrees at both Bemidji and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 22 degrees at Marquette, Minn., to 87 degrees at Homestead, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Viet Boat Person Murdered by Fellow Vietnamese
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese refugee hacked to death a countryman in a camp for boat people Monday night, police said. It was the latest report of violence in the overcrowded, squalid camps of this British colony. Many fights have broken out in past months, but with few casualties. Details on the death Monday were sketchy, and police said only that the victim was 33 years old. They said no arrests were made. The deaths occurred in an open camp, where refugees are allowed to come and go. About 55,000 Vietnamese boat people are languishing in camps throughout the territory. Those in detention camps, without freedom of movement, are being screened to determine if they qualify for resettlement. Otherwise, Hong Kong has vowed to send them back to Vietnam.

Leaders of the National Right to Life Committee on Monday announced plans for an April 28 rally they are billing as a ``celebration of life.'' ``We won't be marching or shouting,'' said John Willke, president of the group, which wants to outlaw abortion. ``What we will be doing is celebrating, singing, speaking out and sharing ... the truth about abortion.'' The afternoon rally is to be held on the grounds of the Washington monument and will feature entertainment by musicians, Christian singers and celebrities. Willke declined to estimate the size of the crowd he expects, but he said people from across the country are planning to attend.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Immigrant Jailed in Israel as PLO Spy
DOC.TEXT: A court sentenced a Yugoslav immigrant to three years in jail Monday for supplying classified information to the PLO, Israel radio said. It said Victoria David, 34, pleaded guilty in exchange for dropping more serious charges of spying. She was also given a three-year suspended sentence. Ms. David came to Israel about two years ago after converting to Judaism in Yugoslavia. She was given new immigrant status under the Law of Return, which automatically grants citizenship to any Jew who wants to live here. Israel radio said she tried to kill herself in prison and told Haifa District court in northern Israel before being sentenced that she regretted the entire incident. Ms. David was arrested on Jan. 7 with another Yugoslav woman, Patricia Kansevitz, 26, on suspicion of photographing military installations and sending the pictures to an activist of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Yugoslavia. Ms. Kansevitz, a Christian who came on a tourist visa, was deported in March. Also Monday, Jerusalem police and the General Security Service said they broke a Palestinian guerrilla cell that operated in the Jerusalem area the past two years. Eight Palestinians were held on suspicion of attacking Israelis and Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. He said the group was suspected of killing Palestinian Ibrahim Sawan as a collaborator in March and of bomb attacks in Jerusalem and Jewish settlements. At least one Israeli was seriously injured in one bombing, Sandori said. Israel television said police found a cache of weapons and explosives.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Party Leader Accuses Papandreou of Backing Violence
DOC.TEXT: A conservative leader Monday accused former Premier Andreas Papandreou of backing organized violence in the campaign for April 8 elections. Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the New Democracy party, made the accusation the day after shots from a passing car killed a Socialist supporter and injured four people in Iraklion on the island of Crete. Mitsotakis' party says one of the injured was a New Democracy backer. ``Andreas Papandreou and his supporters are trying with all legitimate and illegitimate means _ even violence _ to block the rise of New Democracy to power,'' Mitsotakis told a news conference. ``Yesterday's violence on Crete was part of a carefully worked out plan,'' said Mitsotakis. Papandreou, leader of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, described Mitsotakis' statements as `inflammatory'' and ``morally unacceptable'' in televized remarks from his home. Sunday's violence broke out after Socialist supporters set up barricades to stop conservatives from approaching Iraklion's center, where Mitsotakis was scheduled to address a campaign rally. Papandreou said the dead man and one of the four wounded were party members. New Democracy said Crete journalist Costas Papageorgiou, 40, shot in the chest and listed in serious condition, is a party cadre. Papageorgiou works for the newspaper Kastrina Nea of Iraklion. Mitsotakis said that, at his request, Premier Xenophon Zolotas had earlier asked Papandreou to order his supporters to dismantle the roadblocks, but the Socialist leader refused. ``Papandreou did nothing because he wanted acrimony, and he wanted to provoke the incidents,'' Mitsotakis said. ``This is not the first time New Democracy is the victim of terrorist acts. They are trying to intimidate us, terrorize us and even murder us,'' he said. Mitsotakis' son-in-law, conservative member of parliament Pavlos Bakoyannis, was shot to death by the November 17 urban terrorist group in September. Mitsotakis himself was the target of an attack before national elections in November. A Greek Air Force warrant officer was killed as he attempted to plant a time bomb in a theater on the island of Lesbos, where Mitsotakis was due to speak later the same day. Greeks have already voted in two inconclusive elections since June.

DOC.HEAD: US To Drop Export Licenses For Computer Disk-Drives
DOC.TEXT: The Commerce Department moved on Monday to free exports of hard-disk drives for personal computers. Last year U.S. sales to other countries were worth about $500 million, the department said, despite licensing requirements imposed to keep them out of the Soviet Union and its allies. Dropping the curbs is expected to lead to a large increase in sales. On Wednesday the licensing restrictions will be removed for sales of disks with a capacity of 45 megabytes to almost all countries outside the Soviet Union and its allies. One megabyte holds roughly a million characters. ``The net result of this decontrol will be to focus and maintain export restrictions on those items that are truly strategic and can be controlled effectively,'' said Dennis E. Kloske, undersecretary of commerce for export control, in a statement. The department has decided the hard-disk drives can be bought freely from other countries, so there is no reason to prevent American companies from competing for the business. For sales to the Soviets and its East European allies, the Commerce Department is submitting a proposal to the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls (COCOM) in Paris. This group includes the member countries of NATO, except for Iceland, plus Japan and Australia. Until COCOM rules, the Commerce Department will continue to require export licenses for shipments to eastern Europe countries, it said. If COCOM agrees, as it is expected to do within a few months, U.S. disk drives will be available for sale anywhere in the world, except to Libya, Cuba, Vietnam, North Korea, Cambodia and the police and armed forces of South Africa. Last Friday the Defense Department announced that it had decided to drop out of export licensing for what it called ``minimal security risk'' items and leave decisions on those to the Commerce Department. These items included some computers, medical equipment and industrial items including machine tools and telecommunications equipment. Pentagon officials will continue to look at requests to export super-computers. Business people have complained for years that review by the two departments cause export delays and complications.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Spill Threatens Pittsburgh Water Supply
LaserPhotos PG3,5, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Pittsburgh braced for a long-term water crisis Monday as a slow-moving fuel spill snaked down the Allegheny River, threatening supplies to as many as 1 million people. ``I think it's very possible the worst of this is yet to come,'' said the city's public safety director, Glenn Cannon. ``There's no end to it.'' A hospital served meals on paper plates, supermarkets sold out of bottled water, schools closed and a steel plant trucked in water to flush its toilets. A landslide late Friday severed an underground 10-inch-wide pipeline near Freeport, 35 miles north of Pittsburgh. The pipe spilled between 75,000 and 300,000 gallons of gasoline, diesel fuel and kerosene into the river. Like tumbling dominoes, water companies along the Allegheny were forced to close the intakes of their water treatment plants one by one as the 20-mile-long spill oozed toward Pittsburgh, reaching the city early Monday evening. Some were able to reopen Monday as the spill became more diluted and the water could be treated with filters. The Pittsburgh Water Department, which serves 450,000 people, still was drawing water from the river and boosting its reservoirs Monday afternoon but was preparing to close its intakes at any moment. If the spill ``should move suddenly, we'll have to shut the plant,'' said Mayor Sophie Masloff. Pittsburgh gets only part of its water from the Allegheny, and had enough reserves to last three to five days, said Cannon. ``The long-term impact could be devastating,'' he said. Up to 20,000 residents served by the Harrison Township Water Authority have been without water since Saturday and depended on National Guard portable water tanks set up to provide drinking and cooking water. Orders to conserve water were issued to at least 400,000 other people served by various other water authorities northeast of Pittsburgh. At least nine school districts closed Monday, idling more than 21,000 students, and many businesses were affected by the spill. State emergency officials trucked in water to replenish a 45,000-gallon reservoir at Allegheny Valley Hospital, which draws its water from the river. The hospital used paper plates and cups to serve meals to its 225 patients, closed its laundry and was sending dirty linens to another hospital. Drinking water was trucked in for the 2,600 employees of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corp. specialty steel plant in nearby Brackenridge, and some was used to flush toilets, said company spokesman Bert Delano. At Marshall's Amoco station in Natrona Heights about 30 miles northeast of Pittsburgh, the taps and the car wash went dry Sunday afternoon, said attendant Laurie Maycock. ``Nothing happens when you turn the tap on,'' she said. ``But it's not so bad. It's raining, so no one wants to wash their car anyway.'' Like many supermarkets in the area, the Shop'N Save in Natrona Heights quickly sold out of 150 cases of bottled water Monday morning. ``That's the thing about water,'' said manager Bill Rossey. ``You don't miss it until it's gone.'' The thick, gel-like spill, estimated to be 5 to 21 feet deep, moved almost imperceptibly at times. At its fastest, it moved half a mile an hour. ``It's almost as if it stops and takes a rest somewhere,'' said John Kaus of the Allegheny County Emergency Management Agency. Booms stretched across the river were having little effect, and recovered less than 10,000 gallons because most of the fuel was well below the surface, Kaus said. About 100 workers from Buckeye Pipeline Co. and two contractors worked Monday to clean up the leak, said Roy Haase Jr. of Buckeye Pipeline. Below the source of the leak, crews built a dam on Knapp Run Creek to collect fuel flowing from the oil-soaked soil. The landslide prevented workers from reaching the broken pipeline, but the danger of an explosion has been minimized by rain and wind, Haase said. Officials said some fish and other aquatic life were killed, but said it was too early to determine the extent of environmental damage.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Rock Two Ministries, Two Other Athens Buildings
DOC.TEXT: Bombs rocked two ministries and the buildings housing the nation's industrialist and labor unions early Tuesday in downtown Athens, police said. There were no immediate reports of injuries. A police spokesman said the 2:20 a.m. explosions ripped through the National Economy and Transport ministries, the Federation of Greek Industrialists and the General Confederation of Greek Trade Unions. The officer said an anonymous caller to a newspaper claimed the Popular Armed Struggle urban guerrilla group had planted the bombs. The group has called for voters to boycott Sunday's national elections. The group has been involved in bombing targets of a mainly economic nature since 1974 but none of its attacks have ever caused fatalities.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief to Hold Geneva Talks With Salvador Gov't, Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will start a new El Salvador peace initiative this week by holding talks in Geneva with the government and leftist rebels, U.N. officials said Monday. He will interrupt a European tour to fly from Paris to Geneva to preside over the Wednesday meeting, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said the government side will include Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria, the official spokesman of the commission for dialogue with the rebels, and ambassadors Guillermo Paz Larin of Italy, Ana Cristina Sol of France and Carlos Ernesto Mendoza of Switzerland. Negotiating for the rebel Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, will be Cmdr. Shafik Handal, general commander; Salvador Samayoa and commanders Ana Guadalupe Martinez and Roberto Canas of the political diplomatic commission. U.N. officials said the secretary-general will hold separate meetings and a joint meeting Wednesday. How long the meetings would go on was not uncertain, and the agenda was not disclosed. Alvara de Sota, the secretary-general's personal representative for the Central American peace process, will take part and could continue the talks after Perez de Cuellar leaves Thursday for Athens, officials said. The conservative government of President Alfredo Cristiani and leftist rebels already have met to discuss ending the insurgency. Both sides accepted U.N. mediation, but this will be the first time the secretary-general has met with both sides. The rebels have been fighting since 1979 to overthrow U.S.-backed conservative governments. This marks the secretary-general's latest effort to bring together two sides in a regional conflict. His other efforts included Afghanistan, bringing Afghanistan and Pakistan together; the Iran-Iraq war and Cyprus. U.N. officials said the Central American peace agreement, the recent free elections in Nicaragua, and plans to disband Nicaraguan rebels have created a positive atmosphere for resolving the El Salvador conflict. Negotiations between government and rebels broke off last November after a union headquarters was bombed and the guerrillas launched an offensive in San Salvador, the capital. More than 1,000 people died in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Sought Purported Killer for Mafia Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A reputed Mafia assassin wanted for nine years has been arrested in what authorities described Monday as one of the biggest blows to the Sicilian underworld in years. Giuseppe Lucchese, 29, who was considered one of Italy's most dangerous fugitives, was arrested Sunday as he left an apartment building outside Palermo, authorities reported. Inside, police said they found a .38-caliber revolver, $16,000 in cash, a ski mask, fake identity papers and other documents. ``It's the most important police operation of the last few years,'' said Giovanni Falcone, Italy's top anti-Mafia prosecutor. Police said Lucchese has been implicated in dozens of gang murders, including the 1982 assassination of Gen. Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, who led the state's fight against the Mafia. One Mafioso-turned-state's witness, Marino Mannoia, has accused Lucchese of involvement in 37 slayings. Lucchese has already been convicted in absentia and sentenced to life imprisonment in a mass trial of Mafia figures. Investigators tracked him down by following his girlfriend, Claudia Chines. She was also arrested and charged with aiding a fugitive.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Calls For Global Strategy To Aid New Democracies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to include material on Mitchell letter to Baker.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush needs a strategy to help new democracies around the world before expecting Congress to approve the $800 million he seeks for Panama and Nicaragua, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Monday. ``The administration is asking Congress to put together a jigsaw puzzle without any overall picture and without all the pieces,'' Mitchell, D-Maine, said in a statement that called the White House approach ``piecemeal.'' The majority leader's comments appeared to place a further complication in the way of quick passage of the aid money, which Bush contends is necessary to bolster the new democratic governments in the two Central American countries. House passage of the aid measure, which has ballooned to $2.4 billion with the addition by lawmakers of an array of domestic spending, was expected to come on Tuesday with a minimum of controversy. But no action had been scheduled in the Senate on the money bill, which Bush had said he wanted to be enacted before Congress leaves town Thursday for a 12-day Easter recess. Mitchell said he hoped to begin work in the Senate Wednesday on a companion bill setting up aid programs for the two countries. But that bill contains no money to fund the programs. ``By approaching foreign aid on a country-by-country basis and in one-shot increments, the administration has provided no overall or long-term view of how all the pieces can and should fit together,'' Mitchell said. ``They have provided no rationale as to how this request relates to other parts of the budget _ to other foreign aid spending, to defense or domestic spending, to the deficit,'' he said. Mitchell contended that the administration has provided no plan for future aid to the two Central American countries, or how their priority for aid compares to that of emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and elsewhere. Administration officials testifying before Congress have said the money is needed as a speedy response to conditions that could not have been foreseen when the White House wrote its budget for this year. It has proposed to pay for the aid through commensurate cuts in the Pentagon budget. Mitchell said he would not delay in meeting ``the genuine emergency needs for Panama and Nicaragua.'' But he added: ``I do not believe we should appropriate the full amount requested until the administration submits a meaningful long-term foreign aid plan.'' In the first spurt of U.S. aid to emerging democracies, it was Mitchell and Senate Democrats who led the way last year in providing millions for Poland and Hungary. Mitchell called Bush ``timid'' for not doing more for emerging democracies. Mitchell's statement on Monday said ``it makes little sense for the Congress to lurch from country to country on piecemeal emergency foreign aid requests for different parts of the world without some kind of an overall long-term plan'' that relates aid to the rest of the budget. In a brief interview, Mitchell said the statement was not inconsistent with last year's action, but was a response to ``the sheer number of these one-shot requests. When they accumulate in number, the need for an overall plan becomes apparent.'' Mitchell further spelled out his request in a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, saying the spending plan should cover plans for the next three to five years for foreign aid, defense spending, domestic spending and the deficit. The administration has not explained ``the relationship between this request and our overall national security objectives,'' Mitchell told Baker. ``I believe it is essential that the Senate have such a plan before it appropriates the emergency aid requested by the administration for Panama and Nicaragua.''

DOC.HEAD: Unapproved Fungicide Traces Found In Imported Wines
DOC.TEXT: Traces of a fungicide not approved in the United States have been found in 11 samples of imported wines, the Food and Drug Administration said Monday. There is no ban on the wines, and none is being recalled, said FDA spokesman Bill Grigg. But the FDA is requiring the makers of these wines to certify that they do not contain the fungicide procymidone before they are shipped to this country. Grigg said the vineyards involved must retain independent testing labs to certify that the wines are fungicide-free before shipping them to the United States. He said the FDA will conduct spot tests on the wines to confirm the certifications. The maker of procymidone, Sumitomo Chemical Co. of Osaka, Japan, has begun providing the Environmental Protection Agency with data on the fungicide, which is approved in Europe, the FDA said. This could lead to the setting of a residue tolerance by EPA. Currently, the EPA has no tolerance levels for procymidone, which means that no amount of it can appear in any products sold here, Grigg said. He also said there is no indication the fungicide, which is applied to grapes while they are growing, constitutes a health risk. The FDA initiated a 200-sample survey after traces of procymidone were found in an Italian sparkling wine, Tosti Asti Spumante. Of the 116 wine samples tested so far, seven French and three Italian wines were found to contain traces of the fungicide. No traces were found in samples of wines from Australia, Brazil, Chile, Germany, Hungary, Israel, Spain and Portugal, the FDA said. The agency, so far, is requiring testing of Tosti Asti Spumante, as well as two other wines in which traces of the fungicide were found _ Gionelli Asti Spumante and B&G Saint-Louis Beaujolais. Residues of the fungicide also were found in the following wines: _Asti Spumante, Collinetta _Asti Spumante, Martini & Rossi _Beaujolais, Le Chamville _Red, Louis Jadot _Vouvray, B&G _Chablis, B&G _Red Burgundy, C. Montra _White Bordeaux, Barton & Guestier

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Has Nerve Gas, Threatens Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that Geneva protocol bans initial use of chemical weapons. Picks up 3rd, `Iraq is..'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said for the first time Monday that his country has deadly binary nerve gas weapons, and he threatened to use them on Israel if the Jewish state attacks Iraq. Binary weapons, usually artillery shells or missile warheads, contain two relatively safe compounds that combine to produce toxic nerve gases. The first use of chemical weapons was outlawed under the 1925 Geneva Protocol. Iraq is already seen as a front-runner in a Middle East drive to develop arsenals of long-range and surface-to-surface missiles. Its development of chemical weapons, and possibly nuclear arms, has raised fears of an arms race in the volatile region. In Israel, government officials warned Monday that Israel would retaliate if Hussein used chemical weapons against it. The U.S. State Department denounced Hussein's chemical weapons threat as ``inflammatory, irresponsible and outrageous.'' Hussein, in a speech broadcast by Baghdad Radio, denied Iraq has nuclear weapons. Concerns about this were raised last week by the interception in London of 40 Iraqi-bound trigger devices that officials said were designed for nuclear bombs. ``I categorically deny that we have any atomic bombs,'' the president said at a ceremony in Baghdad, where he awarded medals to senior military officers. Hussein claimed during the 1980-88 war with Iran, ``Iraq was offered enriched uranium and even a complete atomic bomb by people who were either American, British or Zionist agents. But Iraq turned down these offers.'' He did not elaborate. Such an offer would not be in accord with Western efforts to block nuclear military technology to developing nations. Hussein warned the Israelis if they try to repeat their June 1981 air strike on a French-built nuclear reactor near Baghdad, he will retaliate with chemical weapons. ``I say that if Israel dares to hit even one piece of steel on any industrial site, we will make the fire eat half of Israel,'' he declared. ``Let them hear, here and now, that we do possess binary chemical weapons which only the United States and Soviet Union have.'' In a clear reference to Israel, believed to be the only Mideast power with nuclear weapons, Hussein said: ``Those who are threatening us with nuclear bombs: we warn them that we will hit them with this binary chemical weapon.'' A statement issued in Jerusalem by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said Hussein's remarks ``reveal once again the basic threat at the root of the situation in the Middle East, which is . .. the continued aspiration to destroy Israel. ... Let there be no doubt, Israel will also know how to defend itself in the future and defeat the evil designs of its enemies.'' Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said, ``We have no aggressive intention against anyone, including Iraq.'' Asked about a possible preemptive strike, Pazner said: ``We don't even want to talk about that kind of thing.'' Western intelligence officials have long said Iraq is developing chemical weapons at top-secret research installations. Only the United States and Soviet Union have officially admitted having binary weapons, although other countries were believed to possess them. In an interview with The Associated Press, Foreign Ministry Undersecretary Nizar Hamdoon said Iraq developed the weapons during the Iraq-Iran war but did not use them. Hussein said Britain and the United States should recognize ``the rights of nations and peoples to defend themselves.'' The Iraqis have told Israel several times the last two years not to launch preemptive strikes against its burgeoning arms industry. Baghdad says it now is capable of producing long-range missiles and rockets capable of putting satellites into space orbit. In December, Iraq announced it had tested two missiles with a range of up to 1,200 miles, enough to reach Iran's capital and Israeli cities. Hussein also made his first public comment on U.S. and British allegations that Iraq tried to smuggle in 40 U.S.-made krytrons, or electronic detonators for nuclear bomb detonators. ``These are only condensors which we bought ... and it's not logical that these could be used in atomic bombs,'' he said. The Foreign Ministry released photocopies of documents it said proved Iraq's innocence and showed that a person it identified as an FBI agent attempted to lure Iraq into ordering the triggers. It said ``attempts by British and American authorities to portray Iraq as a nuclear power are aimed at blackmailing and pressuring Iraq to prevent Iraq from acquiring scientific and technical know-how.'' The ministry said the devices seized at London's Heathrow Airport could be used for nuclear bombs but that Iraq wanted them for use in a university laser system. Hussein, who has ruled Iraq as undisputed strongman since 1979, said recent criticism against Baghdad over its human rights record and its military ambitions was designed ``to threaten and intimidate Iraq'' as well as ``pave the way for Israel to attack us.'' Israel's air force bombed Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981 while Iraq was at war with Iran. Israel claimed the plant was developing a nuclear bomb. Iraq denied it.

DOC.HEAD: Employees Strike At Nation's Largest HMO
DOC.TEXT: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, was hit by a strike Monday by 11,000 nurses, technicians and maintenance workers, cutting services at hospitals and closing some clinics. Workers defied the recommendation of a union negotiating team and rejected a $44 million contract offer Friday by a 3,067-to-1,474 vote. A six-hour negotiating session with a federal mediator ended Saturday without an agreement between Pasadena-based Kaiser Permanente and Service Employees International Union Local 399. The company's offer includes a 5 percent to 6 percent pay raise in the first year and a 3 percent to 5 percent increase in the second and third years. It also guarantees that employees' wages are 3 percent higher than the average wage at 12 Los Angeles-area hospitals used as a yardstick. The union said 314 job classifications were affected. It declined to outline its contract demands. ``Management knows what it will take to settle the strike,'' said union Vice President Dave Stilwell, who said the top-wage guarantee was simply no match for the work demands placed on Kaiser employees. Kaiser employees accepted a wage freeze three years ago and have stood by the company during nine years of financial difficulty, said union spokesman Tom Ramsay. ``Now that Kaiser is back on their feet and prospering, employees expected some recognition and didn't get that, and they were very angry,'' Ramsay said. ``Workload has gone up two- and threefold, and employees are still being asked to sacrifice.'' The union includes licensed vocational nurses, clerks, housekeepers and radiology technicians at seven of the Kaiser Permanente Medical Centers and more than 40 satellite medical offices in Los Angeles and Orange counties. The hospitals affected are in Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City, Bellflower and Anaheim. Kaiser, a nonprofit medical institute, has more than 2.2 million subscribers in Southern California who pay a fee for comprehensive health care rather than the traditional pay-per-visit system. At Kaiser's Anaheim hospital, more than 100 workers walked the picket lines. ``Most of us here have ourselves and families to support. It's hard on both sides,'' said Joyce Johnston, a licensed vocational nurse. Kaiser said medical care will continue to be provided to employees not affected by the strike. By Monday afternoon, about 150 Kaiser patients had been transferred to community hospitals, said company spokeswoman Janice Seib. She said Kaiser was trying to reduce occupied beds at affected hospitals to about 40 percent, down from a usual 75 percent. She said some Kaiser clinics used for annual physicals, check-ups and outpatient treatment were closed, but could not say how many. Kaiser borrowed workers from facilities unaffected by the strike and postponed non-emergency surgery at affected hospitals, Seib said. Management said union leaders did a poor job of presenting the rejected package to members. The union agreed that members were left confused, but said the complex contract offer was handed to them at the last moment and was too difficult to decipher in time for the vote. ``We did the best we could, and the members still didn't understand and voted not to give management a blank check,'' Stilwell said. ``The feeling generally is that they misrepresented it or presented it in an extremely negative way,'' said Seib. Several pickets said they might have been better informed, but said they would still have voted to strike.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer: List a Fragmented Man Saving His Family's Souls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 15th graf, `After opening ...' to UPDATE with testimony about List's obsession with unsolved mysteries; picks up 16th graf, `Barbara A. ...'
DOC.TEXT: John E. List killed his wife, three children and mother in 1971 ``with love in his heart'' to save their souls, his attorney argued Monday at the start of the former Sunday school teacher's murder trial. List, a strictly raised Lutheran, was a ``fragmented'' product of 19th century ethics who despaired while his family loosened church ties and felt himself failing as a provider, said defense lawyer Elijah L. Miller Jr. ``He was simply not equipped to cope, to deal with the pressure of our times,'' said Miller. Arrested in Virginia in June, List is charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of his wife, mother, daughter and two sons at his Westfield mansion Nov. 9, 1971. ``On that fateful day, he slipped from despair into oblivion. ... He entered hell with his eyes open,'' said Miller. ``He committed these acts with love in his heart for his mother, wife and children. For the salvation of his family he had to act as he did.'' The defense contends List was mentally diseased at the time, a ``diminished capacity'' argument that would let jurors return a guilty verdict to a lesser charge. ``He is still fragmented with a mental disease,'' Miller said. Assistant Union County prosecutor Brian Gillet offered a different picture, saying List ``systematically executed ... his own flesh and blood.'' List's 84-year-old mother, Alma; wife, Helen, 45; daughter Patricia, 16; and sons John, 15, and Frederick, 13, were ``unsuspecting and undeserving victims of this defendant's cruel, evil and calculating mind,'' said Gillet. The prosecutor opened his brief statement by reading a five-page letter that List had written his pastor to describe the events and explain that he acted out of economic distress and fear for his family's souls. List slumped in his chair without apparent emotion. Gillet told the jury how List stopped the mail and milk deliveries, wrote notes to his children's employers and schools saying the family was going out of town, and settled his financial affairs. Like the accountant he was, List ``closed the books, balanced out the accounts before he fled and took on a new life,'' said the prosecutor. His careful plan ``turned into a day of horror'' at the 18-room mansion and become his family's ``worst possible nightmare.'' After opening statements, witnesses reconstructed the family's final day. Their testimony spoke of an idyllic suburban life, where a car pool took the kids to school, the milkman put the milk in the refrigerator and bank tellers knew their customers by name. Gene Syfert, who is married to the sister of Helen List, testified that he talked with List about a collection of crime books at the house during his last visit there in 1968. ``He indicated that he was rather obsessed with the unsolved mystery,'' Syfert said. Barbara A. Baeder, who with List ran a carpool for their children to and from school, told how she brought John Jr. home. Police say he arrived early, and was the only victim shot more than once. List, in his letter released last week, said John struggled. ``In order to snuff the life out of that young man, the defendant needed more than 10 shots to kill him, his namesake,'' Gillet said in his opening statement. Mrs. Baeder's son, Richard, 13 at the time, remembered taking a telephone message from List the evening of Nov. 9. List said Mrs. Baeder didn't need to pick up the children because they were going to visit their sick grandmother in North Carolina. Herbert L. Argast, the milkman, told how he saw a note on the refrigerator saying, ``no more milk until further notice.'' It was written by List on a ``nice piece of lined paper'' rather than the usual scrap left by Mrs. List, he said. Bank employees told how List cashed checks totaling $285, and $2,000 in savings bonds. The town truant officer said she went by the home several times when the children did not come to school for several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim Unconscious, Said to Be Dying from Internal Bleeding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to ADD White on a ventilator and CORRECT family is not deciding when he will die, ADD that Mrs. White divorced from White's father; picks up 8th graf, `White's hemophilia ...' ^LaserPhoto NY25
DOC.TEXT: Ryan White, whose battle with AIDS brought him scorn in his hometown but support from across the world, was hospitalized with internal bleeding Monday and was not expected to live, authorities said. Doctors said Monday afternoon that White, 18, probably would not survive the day, said Carrie Van Dyke, director of health promotion for the State Board of Health. It was later disclosed, however, that White was on a life-support system, a ventilator, that could prolong his life. White's chief physician, Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, declined to speculate on White's prognosis. White put a youthful face on the AIDS plight. He increased public awareness of the deadly disease and helped reinforce the message that AIDS cannot be spread through casual contact. His struggle was the subject of numerous accounts, including a People magazine cover story and a televison movie. ``He is presently in the intensive care unit and he is in critical condition,'' Kleiman told an afternoon news conference. ``He is heavily sedated and we feel that he is experiencing no discomfort.'' Van Dyke said his mother, Jeanne, and his sister, Andrea, were among the relatives at his bedside at Riley Hospital for Children. Jeanne and Ryan White's father, Wayne, are divorced. White's hemophilia, the disorder that initially exposed him to the deadly AIDS virus, prevented doctors from operating, said Van Dyke. She said she was told about White's condition by his mother at lunchtime. ``This is it. He's not expected to come out of it,'' Van Dyke said. ``He's not responding.'' Van Dyke voiced a small hope White would recover, saying, ``He's surprised us before.'' Kleiman, White's physician since he was diagnosed as having AIDS in 1984, said White was admitted to the hospital Thursday suffering from a respiratory infection, which occurred as a complication of AIDS. Kleiman said White's family had asked that no additional details of his condition be released. White's battle with acquired immune deficiency syndrome sent him to Washington to testify before Congress and to California for star-studded fund-raisers. He had gained the support and close friendship of entertainers such as Michael Jackson and Elton John. Last week, he appeared with former President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, at a pre-Oscar party in Los Angeles for sick and disadvantaged youths sponsored by Athletes and Entertainers for Kids. The organization has established the Ryan White National Education Program for Youth, an AIDS education forum. News of White's condition Monday prompted a statement of concern from the Reagans. ``We are praying for him and his family as we are praying for all people with AIDS and their families,'' the statement said. Elton John also called White's family to express concern, Van Dyke said. White's mingling with celebrities and entertainers was a cruel contrast to the days when AIDS hysteria made it impossible for him to mix even with his classmates. When White's case first made headlines, misinformation combined with a lack of knowledge of the incurable disease made White a pariah. But he went on to become a national spokesman for children with AIDS after winning a court battle to attend school near his hometown of Kokomo. However, he and his family felt ostracized there, and moved to a new home about 20 miles away in Cicero, where they were welcomed by the local community and school system. ``Personally, I would rather have given it up a long time ago,'' Mrs. White said during the court battle. ``It would have been a lot easier on me and a lot easier on the rest of the family. ``But, believe it or not, Ryan has always really loved school. Andrea (his sister) says, `Boy, I wish it would be me that could stay home.' But this is what Ryan wants to do, and I want what he wants.'' His life story was told in a television movie last year and an education program called ``I have AIDS _ A Teen-ager's Story: A 3-2-1 Contact Extra,'' which White helped develop. It was nominated for an Emmy and won a George Peabody Award and an Ollie Award. White enjoyed collecting comic books, swimming and customizing his red Mustang. He also owned two dogs, Wally and Gizmo, although his doctors advised the family against having pets. Mrs. White said she allowed her son to have the dogs because she was unable to tell him another thing he wanted was out of reach because he had AIDS. ``Ryan said, `It's my life and I want a pup.' He said, `I want a pup that likes no one but me,''' she said. White was diagnosed as having AIDS in 1984, when he was 13. He contracted the disease through blood products he received to treat his hemophilia, a disorder that impairs the blood's ability to clot and stop bleeding. ``I don't think it's the AIDS as much as he's a hemophiliac and he's bleeding internally, and that's the problem,'' Van Dyke said. She said White was in poor health before Thanksgiving, when they prepared several public service announcements for World AIDS Day on Dec. 7. White dropped out of classes at Hamilton Heights High School before Christmas, she said. Officials there could not be reached for comment Monday because the school was on spring break. White turned 18 on Dec. 16 in continued ill health, with a low blood platelet count and staph infections in his eyes and legs. The national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta says it has recorded 2,055 cases of AIDS among children since June 1981 as of January, accounting for 2 percent of the total number of AIDS patients. There are 1,207 hemophilia patients with AIDS, or 1 percent, the CDC said in its latest statistics released in March. Transfusion or blood related cases account for 3 percent of the total number of AIDS cases, or 72,153 cases, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Bradley Wants to Be Senator Six More Years
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley announced Monday that he will seek a third term on Capitol Hill, quashing speculation about a 1992 presidential bid by saying he planned to represent New Jersey for the full term. ``I'll say the same thing in 1990 that I said in 1984 ... that I will serve my six-year term,'' the Democrat told about 150 people gathered at Montclair State College. ``I can't conceive of anything that would change it.'' A poll of Democratic state chairmen from throughout the nation recently put Bradley, 46, at the top of their list for the presidential nomination in 1992. Bradley, however, said he wants to make his contribution representing New Jersey. Bradley, a Rhodes scholar from Denville who played basketball for Princeton University and the New York Knicks, is seen as one Northeasterner who would be acceptable in more conservative regions. His wife, Ernestine Schlant Bradley, a professor of German and comparative literature at Montclair State, introduced her husband. Speaking beneath an arch of red, white and blue balloons inside the college's student center, he talked of children, the environment and education. ``I want to make sure the kids of New Jersey get their share,'' he said. Bradley planned a second campaign stop at a water treatment plant outside Camden, N.J., later in the day. The senator is running what is expected to be a $10 million campaign to keep his seat. Aides say most of the money will pay for television advertising in the expensive New York and Philadelphia media markets and fend off possible negative campaigning by the GOP. Republican Christine Todd Whitman, 44, of Far Hills, N.J., said she will run a positive race strictly on the issues, including tax and spending. Bradley declined her challenge to cap his campaign spending at $3 million. He reaffirmed, however, his support Monday for public financing of campaigns, spending limits, limits on contributions by political action committees and reduced television costs for candidates. Mrs. Whitman, former president of the state Board of Public Utilities and a former Somerset County official, anticipates running a $1.5 million race. A possible GOP primary candidate is John Scott, chairman of the Conservative Caucus of New Jersey. Candidates have until April 12 to file for a place on the June 5 primary ballot. As of Friday, no other Democrat had filed. Bradley built a national record through 1986 tax reform and his positions on Third World debt and trade relationships with Canada, Mexico and Japan. In his 1978 race against Republican Jeffrey Bell, Bradley captured 56 percent of the vote. In 1984, he defeated Mary Mochary with 64 percent of the ballots cast.

DOC.HEAD: Breakout Bid at 2nd British Prison, Riot Continues at 1st
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with attempted breakout at second prison. Picks up 5th pvs, `The Home' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Inmates at Long Lartin Prison attempted a mass breakout Monday night and about 30 convicts barricaded themselves on a prison landing after guards foiled the escape bid, the Home Office reported. At a second prison in central England, Strangeways Prison at Manchester, nearly 100 inmates ran loose Monday but guards regained control of much of the riot-damaged facility and officials were in contact with the remaining inmates still inside, authorities said. The Home Office, which is responsible for prisons, said in a statement that guards at low-security Long Lartin grabbed a group of prisoners as they tried to scale the 15-foot wire mesh perimeter fence. The guards led them back into the building without violence, it said. The statement did not say how many inmates tried to break out, but said other inmates immediately began demonstrating, forcing guards to retreat. The Home Office said about 30 prisoners barricaded themselves on one of the landings of a prison wing and kept guards at bay early Tuesday. At Strangeways, prisoners hung up a flag saying ``No Dead,'' but the government said deaths could not be ruled out in one of Britain's worst prison riots. Authorities said 37 inmates and 12 prison guards had been injured since riots began Sunday at Strangeways, one of the most crowded jails in Britain. News media reported unconfirmed accounts of up to 12 deaths. Prison staff regained control of four cell blocks and the kitchen Monday after scores of inmates surrendered. Rioters still held five blocks, said the Home Office. The Home Office said 99 prisoners were still loose, but Ivor Serle, chairman of the Strangeways Prison Officers' Association, put the number at 80 to 90 after more men surrendered in the evening. Serle said he was in three wings of the prison and saw no bodies. About a dozen masked inmates remained on the steep roofs in the night cold, waving and shouting. ``I think it will go on until tomorrow. ... They've got plenty of food, plenty of drugs and plenty of fresh air,'' Serle said, referring to looting of hospital storerooms. Home Secretary David Waddington said some surrendering prisoners claimed a number of inmates were dead, but no bodies were found. ``But the possibility that fatalities have occurred cannot be ruled out,'' he added. He said nine surrendering prisoners claimed to have been forcibly injected with drugs by other inmates. The riot highlighted Britain's much-criticized prison system. With a prison population of 47,000, Britain has the highest number of inmates per capita in Western Europe. Red-brick Strangeways prison, built in 1868 to hold 970 men, contained 1,648 prisoners Sunday. It is a local jail and contains inmates of all categories, from extremely dangerous to low risk, the Home Office said. Roy Hattersley, the opposition Labor Party's deputy leader, said 82 one-man cells were crammed with three prisoners, and 96 single cells housed two inmates each. The inmates were confined to these cells for all but 11 hours a week and were allowed one shower and one change of clothing each week. ``If you treat men like animals, we ought not to be surprised if they behave like animals,'' Hattersley said. Dr. Philip Randall of North Manchester General Hospital said most of the more serious injuries were caused by prisoners assaulting other prisoners. By late afternoon, 1,458 inmates had been transferred to prisons and 74 were awaiting transport, the Home Office said. ``The (prison) governor has been in touch with the prisoners all day long,'' said Home Office spokesman Roy Payne. ``There has been no confrontation, no demands and no threat.'' Police with riot gear were on stand-by along with squads of armed officers. No clear indication emerged as to what caused the rioting. It began during Sunday morning service in the prison chapel, when inmates grabbed keys from guards and used them to gain access to large areas of the facility. The inmates started fires. At one point it was feared the 19th-century Victorian prison would burn down. ``If you imagine a bomb dropped in World War II in a built-up area, that's what it looks like,'' John Bartell, national chairman of the Prison Officers' Association, said Monday. ``They've ripped off landing rails, wire netting and doors. Anything has can be damaged has been damaged. ... They have burned down a number of buildings.'' He said the prison management was warned that ``there would be a serious disturbance this weekend,'' and he accused the Home Office of ``criminal negligence'' for leaving only five guards to supervise 300 men in the chapel. Home Office minister David Mellor, who first called the allegation ``ridiculous,'' later said in a Sky News interview: ``I gather there was some information given to the governor that he regarded as very much the same kind of information he'd received on several previous occasions when nothing had happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Volcano Lava Threatens Rural Hawaii Community
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano on Monday flowed toward a subdivision of 83 homes in this coastal town, and authorities ordered most of the residents to evacuate by nightfall. The slow-moving flow was half a mile from Kalapana Gardens Subdivision in the morning. A lava flow in 1986 destroyed dozens of homes in the same area. Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim ordered residents in 50 of the houses to evacuate and placed the town on alert, meaning residents in about 150 homes could be ordered to evacuate within 72 hours. Earlier, authorities evacuated four outlying homes as the flow crossed Kalapana Bypass Highway, which lies between the town and a lava vent six miles upslope. Lava came within 300 yards of the houses, then turned eastward toward the subdivision, said Civil Defense spokesman Lanny Nakano. The flow posed a serious threat because the only route to the ocean is through a populated area, said Hawaiian Volcano Observatory spokesman Reggie Okamura. ``It's just a matter of time if it keeps going,'' Okamura said. Authorities also were monitoring a finger of lava to the east, which was following the course of the 1986 flow. That flow was three-quarters of a mile upslope from the highway. Since its latest and longest eruption began in January 1983, the volcano has destroyed 76 homes and a national park visitor center, causing $20 million in damage.

DOC.HEAD: 19 Filipinos Slain in Two Clashes With Communist Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen people, including eight civilians, were killed in two clashes with Communist rebels in widely separated areas of the Philippines, the military reported Tuesday. A military report said six New People's Army guerrillas and four soldiers died Saturday during an eight-hour firefight near Pasuquin in Ilocos Norte province, 260 miles north of Manila. In another report, the military said eight civilians and one government militiamen were slain when rebels attacked a village in the central province of Antique during memorial services Monday for a militiaman killed in a previous incident. Two civilians and one militiaman were also wounded in the raid, staged by about 40 rebels in Valderama, about 260 miles southeast of the capital. The New People's Army, the military wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines, has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: First Bensonhurst Racial Trial Begin
DOC.TEXT: The young man accused of leading a white mob charged in the slaying of a black teen-ager went on trial Monday along with the man accused of pulling the trigger. Defense lawyers failed to block testimony by witnesses who identified the pair from photographs and lineups. Six other young white men from Bensonhurst have been charged in the Aug. 23 slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old who was shot after he went with three friends into the largely Italian section of Brooklyn to look at a used car. Joseph Fama, 19, who is accused of being the triggerman, and 20-year-old Keith Mondello, who authorities say was the ringleader, are the first to stand trial. Both are charged with two counts of second-degree murder, riot, assault, menacing and other crimes. Each faces 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Five of the others have been charged with second-degree murder and other crimes, and the sixth with assault. In a heated session Monday, attorneys for Fama, Mondello and another defendant, Joseph Serrano, argued that the reliability of witnesses who picked their clients out of lineups or from photo spreads was questionable because of the publicity surrounding the slaying. Fama's attorney, David DePetris, said photographs of his client were released by the police and publicized widely, makinge it impossible for witnesses to view a lineup objectively. Fama fled after the attack. Judge Thaddeus Owens rejected the arguments and ordered the trial to proceed. The judge plans to speed the proceedings by impaneling two juries. The panels will sit side by side in the courtroom, with one deciding the fate of Fama and the other considering Mondello's case. The judge also set a June 11 trial date for Serrano and Pasquale Raucci, both 20-year-olds charged with second-degree murder. There may be as many as six trials, defense lawyers and prosecutors say. Assistant District Attorney Edward Boyar, a lead prosecutor in the case, came to the seventh-floor courtroom carrying a summons ordering him to jury service Monday. ``I went to the clerk's office and had it delayed,'' he said, laughing.

DOC.HEAD: Top Contra Reportedly Agrees to Disband Fighters
DOC.TEXT: President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras said Monday the top military commander of the Contra rebels has agreed to disband his forces. In Tegucigalpa, Honduras, a Contra spokesman said all rebel forces remaining in that country will surrender their weapons to U.N. monitors on April 18. In an accord March 23, a lower-ranking Contra commander agreed to demobilize. But deep divisions remain in the rebel ranks, with many rank-and-file fighters saying they won't lay down their arms by the time the new Nicaraguan government takes office on April 25. Callejas made his announcement when he arrived in Nicaragua for a two-day summit with four other Central American presidents in Montelimar, a new beach resort 40 miles from the capital, Managua. The top item on the agenda was demobilizing the U.S.-backed Contras, who have waged a 10-year war against Nicaragua's leftist government. Callejas said top rebel commander Israel Galeano, also known as Commander Franklyn, had assured him the Contras would disband by the time President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is sworn in. The Honduran president spoke with reporters after meetings with Mrs. Chamorro and Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo in Managua. The cardinal witnessed the March accord in Honduras between Contras representatives and those of Mrs. Chamorro. There have been doubts about the viability of the accord because Galeano did not sign it and thousands of Contras have since returned to Nicaragua with their guns.
