The accord said the rebels in Honduran base camps would demobilize by April 20, but it did not set a deadline for those on Nicaraguan territory. In addition, many of the rebels who were in Honduras have reportedly slipped back into Nicaragua. But Callejas said Monday that Galeano has assured him his forces will disband by April 25. In Tegucigalpa, Contra spokesman Alejandro Acevedo announced that all Contras in Honduras will surrender their arms to a U.N. peacekeeping force a week earlier _ April 18. Other rebels inside Nicaragua will gather inside security zones to surrender their arms, as specified in the March accord, Acevedo said in an interview. He said the decision was made by Galeano and the rebel high command. He said the formal surrender of weapons by forces in Honduras will take place at Yamales, a small town near the Nicaraguan border. Acevedo said their weapons consist mainly of Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, cannons, rocket-propelled grenades, surface-to-air missiles, machine guns and mortars. He refused to specify quantities. President Oscar Arias of Costra Rica spoke enthusiastically of peace prospects when he arrived in Managua on Monday. He said Callejas ``has brought me the good news that the Contras and Commander Franklyn are in total agreement on complete demobilization.'' Arias said that ``never before in the last 3{ years have we felt as optimistic as now.'' Arias won the Nobel Peace prize in 1987 for working out the first of a series of Central American peace accords aimed at ending civil wars in the region. He said he was certain the region's presidents would reach an agreement that would encourage the Contras to hand over their guns to a U.N. demobilization force. As for the civil war in El Salvador, Arias said he expected ``substantive'' agreements on a dialogue between the U.S.-backed rightist government and the leftist guerrillas. Also attending the summit are Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani, Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo and outgoing Sandinista President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Blocks Harris Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with reax from victims' families, governor, prosecutor, death penalty opponents, ADDS what happens next. Edits to trim. Picks up 10th graf, `Harris would ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday refused to allow California to carry out its first execution in 23 years, letting stand an order blocking Robert Alton Harris' trip to the state gas chamber. Harris, 37, who in 1978 kidnapped and murdered two San Diego teen-agers to use their car in a $3,000 bank robbery, had been scheduled to die in the gas chamber at 3 a.m. Tuesday. However, a federal appeals court judge imposed the stay Friday, and the nation's highest court voted 6-3 Monday to reject an emergency request from prosecutors who wanted to execute Harris on schedule. Because of the Supreme Court's action, one of California's most notorious criminal cases could drag on for months. The case, which focuses on Harris' mental condition, will return to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, prosecutors said. ``There is no legal or moral reason why the execution ... should not proceed as scheduled,'' state Attorney General John Van de Kamp said in papers filed with the Supreme Court. ``There has never been a question Robert Alton Harris killed the two helpless victims in cold blood.'' The request went to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who referred it to the full court. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy voted to set aside the stay of execution and let Harris die. Voting in the majority were Justices O'Connor, Thurgood Marshall, William Brennan, John Paul Stevens, Byron White and Harry Blackmun. ``My own reaction, in a sense is one of disappointment,'' said Van de Kamp, who personally opposes capital punishment. Relatives of Harris' two 16-year-old victims were angered and saddened by the justices' decision. ``This is unbelievable. It's unfair. They've heard all these arguments before,'' said William Stalder, of Carlsbad, uncle of victim John Mayeski. ``There's nothing new. I'm finished with it,'' Linda Herring of Escondido, sister of victim Michael Baker, said she expected the decision. ``What are they going to do _ let him sit in jail and rot?'' she said. ``Everybody protects the criminals, but what about us? I just hope this doesn't happen to too many people, but it will, and they'll just get the same that we did _ no justice.'' In Sacramento, Gov. George Deukmejian said he was disappointed and frustrated by the Supreme Court's decision. Deukmejian's voice rose steadily as he listed three appeals of the Harris case to the California Supreme Court, five appeals to the federal court and five appeals to the U.S. Supreme Court since the original death sentence 11 years ago. ``And still no resolution, still no justice. Just delay, delay and more delay,'' Deukmejian said at a news conference. But death penalty opponents lauded the high court's decision to let the stay remain, and planned to turn their vigil at the San Quentin gates into a celebration. ``We are tremendously relieved that California will not become a killer tonight,'' said Martha Kegel, spokeswoman for Death Penalty Focus of California. Harris would be the nation's 122nd convicted killer put to death since the Supreme Court's 1976 decision that allowed executions to resume. Since January 1977, 13 states _ mostly in the South _ have executed prisoners. Trend-setting California would be the most populous state to carry out a death sentence. California voters overwhelmingly favored executing Harris, reflecting the public's longstanding support for capital punishment, a statewide poll found. According to the Los Angeles Times Poll released Monday, 60 percent said they favored Harris' execution, 16 percent were opposed, 5 percent were undecided and 19 percent hadn't heard enough to respond. During the six-day telephone survey, 1,667 registered voters were asked if they favored the execution of Harris, noting he would be the first to die in the California gas chamber since 1967. The margin of error is 3 percent. Death penalty opponents held a prayer vigil a few miles from San Quentin. ``This execution will of course make many feel that justice has been done. Many will feel avenged. But many of us will feel sad because we know the cycle of violence and death will continue,'' said Roman Catholic Archbishop John Quinn of San Francisco. ``We know that Robert Harris' death will not stop the hatred, the crime and the violence which rages in our cities and towns,'' Quinn told about 75 people who attended the service in the chapel of the 172-year-old Mission San Rafael before a march to the prison. Prosecutors asked the Supreme Court to intervene after a conservative federal appeals judge in San Francisco issued the stay, saying further studies of Harris' mental condition may be necessary. The decision by Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals came after identical defense arguments that Harris had inadequate psychiatric help at the time of his trial and may have mental disorders were rejected by the state Supreme Court and a federal judge in San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Conoco Offers to Buy 400 Properties to Settle Contamination Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The proposal ...,' with 2 grafs to ADD background on Times Beach, Love Canal buyouts; picks up 5th graf, `Anthony Roisman ...'
DOC.TEXT: Conoco Inc. said Monday it has proposed a $23 million settlement that would involve buying nearly 400 houses where residents say the groundwater was tainted with hydrocarbons. Conoco lawyer Mark Zehler said he believed the agreement is one of the largest relocation settlements ever in the country. ``Conoco agreed to the settlement because it is the right thing to do _ for these residents, for Ponca City and for Conoco,'' said the oil refinery's manager, Dennis Parker. Two comparable cases involved government money: the evacuation of homes built atop tons of chemical waste at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and the virtual abandonment of Times Beach, Mo., which was tainted by dioxin. The Love Canal buyout involved about $19 million to purchase 232 homes. In Times Beach, about $33 million was spent to buy 393 properties. The Conoco proposal, which must be approved by a federal judge in Oklahoma City, calls for the company to buy almost 400 houses and residential lots and to establish a $5 million settlement fund. Conoco said the property acquisition could cost $18 million. Anthony Roisman, a lawyer for the residents, says anyone involved in the lawsuit will be entitled to share in the fund. Conoco does not have the number of plaintiffs involved in the class-action suit, said Lynn Hohensee, a company spokesman. Conoco said the settlement would resolve the lawsuit without either party admitting liability or responsibility for any claims, injuries or damages. Homeowners in the Circle Drive residential area in southwest Ponca City had complained since 1987 that groundwater laced with hydrocarbons seeped into their basements and threatened their health. Some residents camped out at the state Capitol in Oklahoma City for weeks in 1988 to get the state to buy their houses. ``To Conoco and du Pont we say `thank you' in coming forth with this settlement,'' said resident Anna Sue Rafferty. ``I'd just like to say none of us is happy to be leaving our home. No one intended to get rich.'' Conoco is a subsidiary of du Pont Inc. Conoco had noted that other oil refinery operations have been based in the area over the years. ``There has been steady progress on the technical aspects of a groundwater remediation effort,'' Parker said. ``There has not been corresponding resolution of the many difficulties experienced by the people, and those considerations also deserve our attention.'' If approved, the settlement would allow owners and renters of property within a certain area of the northern Oklahoma city to receive financial payments and relocate. Residents of a larger area of the neighborhood could receive payments because of their proximity to the groundwater problems and the activities needed to fix it. A hearing on the proposal is scheduled June 5 in Oklahoma City. Conoco would pay residents who participate the appraised value of their homes, an above market-value premium, a moving and household disruption bonus and various other bonuses and incentives. Zehler said residents would have six months from when the settlement is approved to seek an appraisal.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of March 26-April 2:
DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Should Explore Videotex Before Phone Companies: Exec
DOC.TEXT: The newspaper industry's reluctance to embrace videotex threatens to create a vacuum that telephone companies and others eventually will fill, a top newspaper executive said March 26. ``We ought to be asking ourselves if we are not in the local information business'' instead of the newspaper business, said Phillip J. Meek, president of the publishing division of Capital Cities-ABC Inc., and former publisher of the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. Speaking at the annual meeting of the Texas Daily Newspaper Association, Meek chided the industry for failing to pursue videotex _ computer-delivered information. He said the failure could leave the market open for telephone companies and other competitors. The newspaper industry has fought efforts by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and some regional phone companies to provide information over existing lines, but Meek said he is ``frustrated and alarmed that nothing is happening'' within the industry to fill the void. Although currently restricted, ``sooner or later, if newspapers don't do something, the phone companies ought to come in,'' Meek said. Some large newspaper chains have offered videotex services with little success, and some experts doubt videotex will develop a following among the general public. Meek said those past failures have scared off other newspaper ventures. ``It's a narrow audience, but it's a decent business,'' said Meek, who oversaw the creation of StarText, a videotex service of the Fort Worth newspaper. Meek said StarText, begun in 1982, now has about 4,200 subscribers in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, more than Prodigy, a similar venture of IBM and Sears Roebuck and Co. Newspapers must also be aware of attempts to slice up their traditional markets, he said, pointing to the proliferation of free publications that advertise homes, jobs, cars and other items that normally make up a newspaper's classified ad section. Suggesting the industry provide some of those publications, he said, ``If it makes sense, it's going to happen.'' Meek also called on the executives to fight proposed changes in U.S. Postal Service regulations that would reduce the mailing costs of ``saturation'' publications while raising fees for newspapers by $20 per thousand. ``It's an unfair break to one segment of direct mail that just puts pressures on newspapers,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: New Suburban Kansas City Afternoon Paper
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Kansas City publisher said March 29 he plans to launch an afternoon tabloid newspaper designed to appeal to ``news addicts'' in the wake of the shutdown of the afternoon Kansas City Star. Stephen F. Rose, president and co-publisher of Sun Publications Inc., said The Evening News will be published Monday through Friday beginning May 14. The paper will cost 50 cents and focus on national and international news provided by The Associated Press, business news and national and local sports. It will be sold at newsstands, convenience stores and newspaper racks throughout the metropolitan area but won't be distributed to homes, which Rose said would boost expenses and require earlier news deadlines. ``We expect it to appeal to busy people who want more information, people who don't want to wait 24 hours to find out what happened today,'' Rose said. On March 1, The Kansas City Star Co. stopped publishing the afternoon Star, merged it with the morning Times and began publishing a seven-day, morning newspaper called The Kansas City Star. ``We certainly felt it left a vacuum,'' Rose said. Joe McGuff, editor of the Star, said he didn't know enough details to comment. ``We'll just have to wait and see if a paper of that type will work in the afternoon,'' McGuff said. Rose said he would begin publishing 25,000 copies a day. ``We don't think that's an unreasonable hope, but we don't have to sell 25,000 papers for this to be viable, depending on the advertising,'' he said. Rose, 42, the sole investor, declined to provide financial details but said he's saving some money by using Sun Publications' printing press, other equipment and some employees. Sun Publications, owned by Rose's family, currently publishes 18 twice-weekly papers in suburban Kansas City, plus two weeklies.
DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Agrees To Buy Lane Publishing for $225 Million
DOC.TEXT: Media and entertainment giant Time Warner Inc. said March 27 it has agreed to buy Lane Publishing Co. and certain related assets for $225 million in cash and stock. The family-owned Lane of Menlo Park, Calif., publishes Sunset, The Magazine of Western Living and owns Sunset Books and Sunset Films. The purchase would be the first major acquisition for Time Warner since Time Inc. completed its $14 billion acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. in January. Under an agreement in principle, Time Warner said it would pay $80 million in cash and $145 million in preferred stock for Lane. The purchase would give Time Warner a second major regional publishing operation to complement its Southern Progress Corp., which publishes Southern Living and several other magazines.
DOC.HEAD: Publisher, Restaurant Group Launch Magazine With a Menu
DOC.TEXT: Diners at more than 60 New York restaurants are getting more than a menu when they stop in for a meal. A new venture owned by a specialty publishing concern and a company that owns restaurants is stapling the menus inside a new general interest magazine called Knife & Fork. The magazine, given to all customers, is being billed as a means of reaching young affluent consumers who spend little time watching television. If it is successful in New York, its owners say they may expand it nationally. Knife & Fork is a creation of a 50-50 joint venture by the publishing company Performance Network Inc. of Lindenhurst, N.Y., and The Riese Organization, a privately held company that owns more than 300 restaurants in the New York area and has investment stakes in more than 100 others nationwide.
DOC.HEAD: Anti-Roman Catholic Editorial Prompts Closing of College Paper
DOC.TEXT: Geneva College closed its student newspaper March 26 for the rest of the semester after it published an editorial critical of Roman Catholics. Geneva is affiliated with the Reformed Presbyterian Church, though Catholics comprise the largest religious group on campus. The decision came as the result of ``a firestorm of complaints'' about Editor Eric Dugan's editorial, said college spokesman William Gibbs. The editorial in The Cabinet, titled ``Theology of the Pointy Hats,'' says senior clerics in the Catholic Church _ who were referred to as ``pointy hats'' _ have become authoritarian and their councils and traditions ``supersede Scripture.'' The editorial says Protestants use the Bible to assess the validity of their leaders' statements. ``The Catholic, however, finds most of his faith and practice moored in the sayings of popes and councils, which frequently contradict each other,'' the editorial says. ``And just what if one pope isn't exactly holy? His words are still law.'' The editorial closes, ``He who holds to teachings which contradict the Bible finds a final resting place with the serpent.'' Gibbs said the decision to close the paper wasn't censorship but was an apology to Geneva's students, particularly Catholics, who account for about one-fifth of the 1,200 students. Dugan said the board acted out of fear the college would lose students and tuition. ``The college has responded in the way it has, in my opinion, not because of its theological persuasion, but because of the wealth of their pocketbooks,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper-Solid Waste Connection
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers must fight the public perception they are causing the avalanche of solid waste that threatens to overwhelm the nation's landfills, industry executives said March 26. ``There is a national misperception that newspapers are creating the problem,'' Sandra Hardy, vice president of Calkins Newspapers, told members of the Texas Daily Newspapers Association. Newspapers account for only about 6 to 8 percent of solid waste, said Ms. Hardy. Some city and state governments have begun requiring citizens to separate waste paper, and two states already have laws requiring newspapers to use recycled paper, said Tonda Rush, director of industry affairs for the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Eighteen more states are considering similar measures, she said. But the supply of recycled paper is limited, she said. Printing of an ANPA publication entitled ``Read Then Recycle'' had to be limited because of the scarcity of the recycled paper used to publish it.
DOC.HEAD: New Paper Targets Capital Insiders
DOC.TEXT: Not hearing enough about the federal government? Roger Kranz hopes so and he's prepared to fill the gap with gossip, news and opinion pieces about the capital's major industry. Kranz is launching the Washington Reporter, a new daily newspaper to be distributed free to 30,000 lawyers, lobbyists, journalists, members of Congress and other ``insiders.'' ``They must read many, many publications to really find out what's going on in Washington,'' said Kranz, who quit his job as group vice president of the National Journal to publish the new paper. The 16-page Washington Report is scheduled for launch Oct. 1. Jim Glassman, editor of Roll Call, a twice-weekly newspaper about Congress, is not optimistic. ``People are overwhelmed with paper. And this, if it ever gets published, is going to overwhelm them even more,'' Glassman said. ``We brought up the idea (of going daily) with our readers, and were told, `God, no, I've got enough stuff on my desk.''' Kranz said he is still trying to raise the $12.45 million needed for the newspaper's first year. The front page of a prototype edition features articles about the Federal Election Commission, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a sensitive high-tech telephone deal with the Soviet Union, the House since Jim Wright's departure and President Bush's capital gains tax cut proposal.
DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Denies Ad Cut Linked to Labor Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. says its decision to cut advertising in Seattle's two daily newspapers was not linked to coverage of the apparel retailer's labor problems. Cindy Demme, Nordstrom vice president for sales promotion, said on March 27 the upscale clothing retailer had been trying different mixes of advertising media in other markets and wanted to do the same in Seattle. The company cut its ads in The Seattle Times and the Seattle Post-Intelligencer from three full-page and three smaller ads on March 22 to one full page a week later. The newspapers share joint business and advertising functions but have separate editorial operations under a joint operating agreement. Times ad director Marji Ruiz said Nordstrom is one of the afternoon paper's top 10 advertisers. Nordstrom's stormy labor relations and declining profits and stock prices have received extensive media coverage, including a front-page article in The Wall Street Journal detailing complaints of past and present employees. Reporter Susan C. Faludi said she interviewed more than 30 people for the story. Company co-chairman Jim Nordstrom called the Times coverage ``horrible ... worse than The Wall Street Journal because that girl didn't know us. She just regurgitated what the union said.'' Michael Fancher, Times executive editor, said he felt no pressure to alter coverage. ``I think it's important for readers to understand that when advertisers purchase an ad, they are buying exposure to our readers. Nothing more and nothing less. ... We're a neutral reporting voice, and that's our role.''
DOC.HEAD: Two Post Reporters Kept From Trump News Conference
DOC.TEXT: The battle of the Trumps and the city's tabloid war joined March 26 when two New York Post reporters were barred from a news conference held by Ivana Trump's attorney. Jerry Nachman, editor of the Post, said his newspaper was not told by any of the parties involved about the news conference held by Michael Kennedy to announce the filing of court papers. ``Other people told us,'' he said. When the reporters and a photographer arrived, they were blocked by two men from entering the conference room where the news conference was under way. ``From what I understand, this was because Mr. Kennedy doesn't like our coverage,'' Nachman said. ``He can't exclude an element of the press and then claim he doesn't like the coverage he gets from that element of the press.'' Gossip columnist Liz Smith of the Daily News broke the story of the breakup and has been accused of favoring Mrs. Trump in the ensuing media frenzy, a charge she has denied. Trump gave his side of the story to Post columnist Cindy Adams.
DOC.HEAD: Sportswriter Arrested in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: A Tampa Tribune sportswriter was arrested March 30 in what police said was a five-month investigation into a crack cocaine ring. Cary Lewis Waldman, 31, was charged with racketeering, possession of crack cocaine and conspiracy to traffic in cocaine, which carries a minimum mandatory three-year prison sentence. Waldman, who has worked in the Tribune sports department for seven years, was suspended indefinitely without pay, said Managing Editor Lawrence McConnell. Prosecutors gave Waldman a reduced bail of $10,000 because they don't consider him likely to flee, said police Detective Mike Fendle. Waldman, recently assigned to the soccer beat, refused to comment, The Tribune reported. Tribune Sports Editor Tom McEwen said Waldman was a good reporter. ``He has been willing and ambitious. He seemed on top of the world, devoted to his work and his family. And he is innocent until proven guilty,'' McEwen said. Detectives said the ring operated for several years, making wholesale and retail dope deals. Waldman was not a leader in the organization but had been making regular crack deals with others in the ring, said Detective Jerry Weiss.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Tribune Plans Fax Edition
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Tribune set an April 2 launch for a fax-delivered daily news sheet designed to bring closing Wall Street prices and word of top-level corporate personnel changes to busy executives. The one-page Tribfax is to be compiled by Tribune editors and transmitted by 4:30 p.m. CDT each business day via US Sprint facilities in Overland Park, Kan. A yearly subscription costs $400. ``It will be primarily business and financial news, but we'll do other news _ and sports if there's something breaking,'' Tribune spokesman Jeffrey D. Bierig said. He said the paper had lined up three charter advertisers. One banner ad will run across the bottom of the page each day.
DOC.HEAD: Unions: Not Much Optimism in Daily News Talks
DOC.TEXT: Further talks between the Daily News and its unions were scheduled after the newspaper's contract expired March 30. The News ran advertisements in its April 1 editions seeking, in case of a strike, replacements for reporters, drivers and pressmen, as well as workers in advertising, finance, promotion and circulation. At the same time, the ``bug,'' or logo, normally on Page 2 indicating union work, failed to appear. A management source who spoke on condition of anonymity had earlier said the bug would be removed. The approximately 800 reporters and office workers belonging to Local 3 of the Newspaper Guild were to receive a letter from Publisher James Hoge and a copy of the paper's latest proposal. The bargaining unit has until April 9 to accept the entire package or at least be negotiating a counterproposal before the offer disappears. ``The way things are going, it is almost impossible to reach a solution with management,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council. Both sides say the negotiations are the most critical ever to the News' survival. The paper says it needs to invest $500 million in new plants to stay competitive. The News says it needs concessions to cut $50 million to $70 million annually in costs to make the paper profitable.
DOC.HEAD: Journalists Are Lazy, Say Bernstein and Deaver
DOC.TEXT: Carl Bernstein and former top Reagan aide Michael Deaver agreed on one point at a college forum March 29: Many journalists are lazy, and it shows. Bernstein, who helped break the story of the Watergate scandal, and Deaver, who managed public relations for President Reagan, were the featured speakers at the Tom McCall Forum at Pacific University. Deaver said it was too easy to manipulate reporters, and Bernstein said too many of his colleagues skim the surface of an issue. ``It's hard work and we're lazy in journalism today,'' said Bernstein, a former Washington Post reporter and ABC bureau chief who is now an author and correspondent for Time Magazine. ``The media I've had a lot to do with is lazy,'' agreed Deaver. ``Yes, we fed them and they ate it every day.'' Deaver was Reagan's deputy chief of staff and conceived the practice of having the president appear in front of visually appealing backdrops to make his point.
DOC.HEAD: Police To Check Report Missing Carrier Sighted in Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Police say it's a long shot, but they're sending two officers to a Mexican resort to check a possible sighting of a Des Moines newspaper carrier missing for six years. A relative reported seeing a young man who resembled Eugene Martin while she was at the airport in Cancun on March 17, but did not approach him. ``They were coming through Cancun, they were transferring planes there, and she ran across this young man that looked like Gene and looked so much like me when I was 18 years old that it was really frightening to her,'' Donald Martin, the youngster's father, said March 27. ``She wanted to say something to the boy but ... she was afraid she would get in trouble with the law if she approached the boy or anything.'' Eugene, 13 at the time, disappeared early in the morning of Aug. 12, 1984, while delivering The Des Moines Sunday Register in a residential area. Another Des Moines news carrier, Johnny Gosch, has been missing since Sept. 5, 1982, when he was 12.

DOC.HEAD: Debut of Renamed, Redesigned Saint Paul Pioneer Press
DOC.TEXT: The renamed and redesigned Saint Paul Pioneer Press debuted March 26 with changes intended to make the newspaper more attractive and accessible to readers. The newspaper, which had been known as the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch since 1986, dropped ``Dispatch'' to shorten the name, Publisher John Henry said in a column published March 25. The word ``Saint'' is spelled out in the new name ``to reinforce and leave no doubt about thng guidelines to be applied uniformly in federal courts. But judges must use discretion in deciding which convicts will pay for their prison stay. Only those who can afford the monthly payment of $1,210.05, plus $91.66 a month during probation, can be ordered to pay. Those fees, calculated by the U.S. Bureau of Prisons, cannot be imposed if they would leave the defendant's family destitute or on welfare, said Paul Martin, a commission spokesman. ``It was kind of a very simple thought _ select those folks who have the ability to pay for their cost of incarceration or supervision,'' Martin said. ``It's mainly earmarked, of course, for the `white collar' defendant, someone who has some financial resource.'' Of the 45,000 cases that reach federal court every year, few criminals appear to fit the bill. ``Most people who are put away in the federal court system are indigent. They don't have a dime. I've had clients who didn't have enough money to buy a six-pack of beer,'' said Ron Wheeler, an attorney in Des Moines. Last year, Wheeler represented a University of Iowa student charged with possessing LSD with the intent to sell. The student, Matthew Follett of Kenilworth, Ill., pleaded guilty. In August, U.S. District Judge Charles Wolle sentenced Follett to seven years in prison plus four years of probation. Noting that Follett had a substantial trust fund, Wolle also fined Follett $20,000 and ordered him to pay for his prison stay, plus the monthly fee during probation. ``I don't have any problem with that at all,'' Wheeler said. ``If they're convicted and can pay the cost of being kept in prison, I think they should.'' ``It looks nice on paper, but in actuality, there aren't a lot of these kinds of defendants.'' In February, in another drug-related case, U.S. District Judge Francis J. Boyle of Providence, R.I., ordered three men accused of supplying 75 percent of the city's heroin to pay the costs of their confinement. ``It's the just thing to do,'' Boyle said at the time. ``To the extent that a defendant is able to pay for it, the defendant should be required to.'' Wilkins and others who support the program say requiring inmates to pay for imprisonment isn't meant as a deterrent. ``The deterrent effect comes through the imposition of a prison term,'' the judge said. One critic of the program is Alvin J. Bronstein, director of the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, who noted that the federal prison system is running at 170 percent of capacity ``and getting worse every month.'' ``It is clear to me that federal prisons today are basically unconstitutional because of the conditions of overcrowding, inadequate medical care and all the problems created by that mass of overcrowding,'' he said. ``It seems unseemly and highly inappropriate _ if not illegal _ to be requiring defendants to pay for room and board, or the cost of being incarcerated, in an unconstitutional facility,'' Bronstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Journalists Forced From Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Western journalists covering Lithuania's standoff with Moscow from the Baltic republic's capital were ordered to leave the country and most, if not all, were out by April 1. More than 100 journalists based in Moscow and other European capitals followed events from Vilnius before they were ordered to leave. Despite the greater freedom of movement permitted under glasnost, Soviet authorities have routinely closed areas stricken by ethnic violence to foreign journalists. Some regions regarded as strategically or politically sensitive are closed at all times, others only temporarily. The order restricting journalists' access to Lithuania came as the Kremlin increased pressure on the rebellious republic and as Lithuanian leaders sought to use the Western media to protect them from a use of force to crush their effort to establish an independent state. Moscow-based foreign journalists must give the Soviet Foreign Ministry advance notice of any plans to travel outside the Soviet capital, including the dates and means of their travel and where they will stay outside Moscow. The Soviet government may refuse to permit the trip, temporarily closing areas to foreigners. The Foreign Ministry on March 23 stopped permitting most Moscow-based reporters from traveling to Lithuania and ordered a number of diplomats out of the republic.
DOC.HEAD: Czech Parliament Abolishes Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on March 28 enacted a press law abolishing censorship, which was instituted after the Soviet-led invasion of 1968. The move was among the latest by the non-Communist government, which took office in December following a popular uprising, to rid itself of four decades of Communist control. The law allows citizens to publish their own periodicals. However, deputies left intact a constitutional provision that radio, television and the film industry _ controlled for decades by the Communists _ are national property.
DOC.HEAD: Former Spanish TV Head Accused
DOC.TEXT: The former director of state-run Spanish Television was indicted March 27 on charges of misappropriating public funds and using them to buy designer clothes. A Madrid district court issued the indictment against Pilar Miro, 41. She resigned from her post in November 1988 after newspapers reported an internal audit indicated she had spent about $36,000 of public funds on her personal wardrobe and gifts. Miro said she made an honest mistake and had believed accounting procedures permitted her to buy clothes for use at the numerous official functions she said the job required her to attend. She reimbursed the television station after the audit.
DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Independent TV On the Air and Off in One Hour
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's first independent television station was banned March 28 after being on the air barely one hour. Federal inspectors interrupted the broadcasting, saying the station, Studio B Television, failed to get permission from the official state-run Belgrade television. ``The real reason is ... political struggle,'' said a source at Studio B, who refused to be identified. He alleged that the state was trying to preserve its monopoly on information. The state Tanjug news agency said viewers flooded the independent station with calls after it went off the air, demanding that the program be continued.
DOC.HEAD: Cubans Block TV Marti
DOC.TEXT: The Bush Administration began beaming MTV videos, a 1971 World Series tape and other samples of American television to Cuba on March 27, but that country jammed the signal and accused the United States of aggression. The TV Marti test began early in the morning and lasted five hours, although the Cuban jamming began after less than a half-hour. Cuba has denounced TV Marti as a violation of national sovereignty and said other retaliatory measures might be taken. That country could activate transmitters capable of blocking U.S. radio broadcasts over a huge area east of the Mississippi. The station is designed to be a TV version of Radio Marti, which has provided news and entertainment to Cuban listeners since 1985. Radio Marti was not jammed during the March 27 debut.
DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Press Agency Reopens
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Press Service, an Arab-run news agency that played a key role in reporting the start of the Palestinian uprising, was allowed to reopen March 30 after a two-year closure. ``I hope this means that (Israeli authorities) will realize that we can make peace only by letting the other side talk and not stifling us,'' said co-owner Ibrahim Karaeen. The agency was founded in 1977 by Karaeen and Raymonda Tawil, now a Washington-based journalist, and was long the main source of news about Palestinian causes for both the Israeli media and the foreign press. Palestinian journalists said they hoped the move would signal more openness toward Palestinian-owned media, which have been blamed by authorities for inciting unrest in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
DOC.HEAD: Proposal To Ban Tobacco, Alcohol Ads
DOC.TEXT: The government on March 28 approved a draft law banning all cigarette advertising and all broadcast ads for alcoholic beverages. The measure will be submitted to Parliament during its spring session, said government spokesman Louis Le Pensec. If approved, the bans will be implemented progressively over a three-year period.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Sells Star Magazine to Rival National Enquirer Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. said March 29 it had agreed to sell Star magazine for $400 million in cash and stock to the publisher of its saucy rival, The National Enquirer. G.P. Group Inc. said it plans to ``maintain the Star's editorial independence'' and would continue to publish it from the magazine's current location in the New York suburb of Tarrytown. The agreement comes almost a year after G.P. Group itself was acquired by a partnership led by the romance magazine publisher Macfadden Holdings Inc. for $412.5 million. G.P. Group also publishes a third sensationalist tabloid, Weekly World News. The Star has an average weekly circulation of 3.6 million, according to News Corp. executives. The National Enquirer's average weekly circulation is 4.1 million and Weekly World News is at 950,000, according to G.P. Group. Under terms of the agreement involving the Star, News Corp. would be paid about $200 million in cash and would get the balance in preferred stock of the company that would publish the Enquirer, the Star and Weekly World News.
DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Against Glamour Magazine Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A judge on March 27 dismissed the lawsuit of a Minneapolis woman who alleged that Glamour magazine went too far in identifying her in a story about sexual exploitation by therapists. The woman agreed to provide the magazine details of the sexual abuse she suffered during psychiatric therapy in 1979 and 1980. But she had asked not to be identified or ``identifiable'' in the story and sued The Conde Nast Publishing Inc. and writer Claudia Dreifus for breach of contract. Even though the September 1988 article gave the woman a fictitious last name, it went on to describe her as a Minneapolis attorney and gave specifics about her activism on issues involving sexual abuse of patients by therapists. U.S. District Judge Harry H. MacLaughlin said the agreement between Dreifus and the woman was ``too ambiguous to be enforced.'' Dreifus had testified that the woman ``wanted some kind of masking,'' but ``was very casual about it,'' according to court records. The judge said Dreifus honored the woman's only specific ``masking'' request by not describing problems she had at one of her previous jobs. The woman knows only two people who identified her from the article and they had been therapists for her, the judge said. The article portrayed the woman as ``someone who successfully recovered from an exploitative situation,'' MacLaughlin wrote. To enforce reporter-source agreements in litigation, plaintiffs ``at a minimum'' must prove ``specific, unambiguous terms and to provide clear and convincing proof that the agreement was breached,'' the judge wrote. ``The court has no doubt that in balancing the rights of the free press with common contractual rights, the free press rights under the First Amendment must be given preference,'' the decision said. Elliot Rothenberg of Minneapolis, the woman's attorney, said he is discussing with his client the possibility of an appeal. If an appeal is filed, Rothenberg said he would almost certainly again invoke the case of Dan Cohen, a Twin Cities public relations agent who received a $700,000 jury award in a breach of contract lawsuit against the Star Tribune and St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch.
DOC.HEAD: Indiana Court Protects Reporters Who Question Grand Jurors
DOC.TEXT: A divided Indiana Supreme Court, in a case watched closely by media groups across the nation, ruled March 27 that two newspaper reporters can't be held in contempt of court for questioning former members of a grand jury. In a 3-2 decision, the court threw out earlier state Court of Appeals decisions that said reporter Mark Kiesling of The Times of Hammond and William Heltzel, formerly a reporter at the paper, could be held in contempt because they violated the secrecy of the grand jury system. The contempt citations were sought by former Lake County Prosecutor Jack F. Crawford after The Times published stories in 1987 detailing why a grand jury impaneled in 1984 didn't return indictments in an investigation of a township trustee's office in that county. A Lake County court had thrown out the contempt request before the Court of Appeals, in two 1989 decisions, ruled that the secrecy of the grand jury was ``of paramount importance'' and the reporters could be punished for inducing jurors to violate hat secrecy. The three-justice majority of the Supreme Court held that while the reporters' actions weren't protected by the freedom of the press guarantee in the First Amendment, they didn't rise to the level of contempt because the questioning of the jurors occurred long after the jury had been dismissed. The court said the need to protect the secrecy of the grand jury is at its ``peak while the grand jury is in the process of hearing testimony, deliberating and voting. Once the proceedings are over and the grand jurors have been discharged, however, the need to protect these policies falls off dramatically.'' The court took note of a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision striking down a Florida law permanently barring grand jury witnesses from talking about their testimony. However, the Indiana justices said that because their decision was focused narrowly on the issue of contempt, they didn't have to address the larger issue of permanent bans on disclosure of grand jury information. ``We're absolutely delighted,'' said Jan M. Carroll, who filed a friend-of-the court brief on behalf of a group of media organizations including the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the Society of Professional Journalists. ``This case had far-reaching effects, not only for reporters but for any citizen who had the temerity to ask questions about a grand jury,'' said Carroll.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Chronicle Wins Libel Case
DOC.TEXT: A county jury ruled March 26 that the Houston Chronicle did not libel a court reporter in a 1982 news story. The jury said that seven out of eight contested sentences in the article were true or substantially true. One time frame in the story was found to be incorrect but not libelous. Court reporter Norma Stewart sued eight years ago for more than $2 million, alleging that the article libeled her and damaged her reputation. The article detailed the delay in setting an execution date for Roger Leroy DeGarmo, convicted of the kidnap-slaying of a Houston medical technician. DeGarmo has not been executed. The article also discussed the delay in completing the trial transcript for automatic review by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. Wayne Strickler, the victim's father, had called Ms. Stewart's handling of the DeGarmo transcript an ``obstruction of justice.''
DOC.HEAD: JAMA Moves Up Release Date
DOC.TEXT: The Journal of the American Medical Association is moving its release date from Friday to Wednesday, giving it a one-day jump on the New England Journal of Medicine. JAMA said March 29 the main reasons for its publishing earlier in the week are improved production capabilities, a desire to release important findings quickly and a wish to give reporters more time at week's end to develop spinoff stories. The change begins the week of April 2. But ``if you read the (AMA) press release carefully, they want to come out first,'' said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the Boston-based New England Journal, which publishes on Thursday. ``I can't understand any other reason, beyond the obvious competitive one.''
DOC.HEAD: Washington Journalists Take Aim at Bush, Broccoli at Annual Gridiron Fete
DOC.TEXT: The Washington press corps poked fun at the Democrats' misfortunes, saluted East European democracy and kidded President Bush about broccoli at the annual Gridiron Club dinner March 31. Following the 105-year-old club's tradition, the journalists hurled satirical barbs at the prominent government officials and political figures they cover every day. Many of their targets, including Bush, were among more than 600 guests at the white-tie event. Club members also lampooned Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega and Vice President Dan Quayle, who was ribbed about his purchase of an obscene gag doll during a visit to Chile earlier this month. Initiated into the club were Thomas J. Brazaitis of The Plain Dealer of Cleveland, Anne L. Groer of The Orlando Sentinel, Cragg Hines of the Houston Chronicle, Frank Jackman of the Daily News of New York, Charles J. Lewis of Hearst Newspapers, Kathy Lewis of The Houston Post and Ronald J. Ostrow of the Los Angeles Times.
DOC.HEAD: CBS Sports Drops Brent Musburger After 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: Brent Musburger, the smooth-talking announcer who was the voice and face of CBS Sports in the '80s, was let go by the network April 1 after he and CBS failed to agree on a new contract. ``I was surprised, but it was a great run and I have a million memories, and I leave behind a lot of good friends,'' Musburger said in a statement. ``At this time, I'm going to take an extended vacation, and I'll be working again someday, somewhere.'' The move stunned Musburger's colleagues, some of whom thought it was an April Fool's joke. ``I'm shocked,'' sportscaster Greg Gumbel said. ``I think most everyone assumed that Brent was going to continue to be the primary voice of CBS Sports.'' Neal Pilson, president of CBS Sports, said it was a difficult decision to let Musburger go after 15 years. ``We simply felt we wanted to give more opportunities to some of the younger people who currently work for us,'' Pilson said. ``We were asked by Brent's representative to make a decision, and that's what we did.'' Musburger's 5{-year contract with CBS, which reportedly paid him about $2 million per year, expires in July. Pilson said money wasn't a major factor in the negotiations, but he wouldn't name the key issues in the dispute.
DOC.HEAD: Preferential Awards of Licenses Backed
DOC.TEXT: Minorities say they've gotten a small toehold in broadcasting thanks to 18-year-old rules that give them preference in seeking radio and television station licenses. The Federal Communications Commission's minority and female preference rules have allowed ``missing voices'' to be heard, backers of the rules told the Supreme Court on March 28. Opponents, however, said the rules discriminate against white males. They contended the rules should be dropped and the marketplace should determine the bidding. Minority ownership of the country's stations has increased from 1 percent a few years ago to 3 percent. Two cases in Florida and Connecticut involve challenges to broadcast minority preferences. ``It's clear that the court is very troubled by what the FCC is doing,'' Andrew Schwartzman of the Media Access Project, a supporter of the rules, said following the oral arguments. ``It's always dangerous to guess (what the court will decide) but I'm not too optimistic.'' The Supreme Court upheld a federal public works set-aside program in 1980, saying Congress had special authority under the Constitution to enact such programs. But last year the court, with a newly conservative majority, struck down a similar set-aside program for minority contractors run by the city of Richmond, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Tighter Regulation in Store for Cable Sector, Broadcasters Told
DOC.TEXT: Consumer complaints and runaway rates will bring the ``pay TV'' industry under increased government regulation, the nation's broadcasters were told March 31. ``We began the 1980s with cable an infant industry, crying for special privilege just to survive,'' Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said in his ``state of the industry'' address at the NAB's convention. ``Cable is multiplying faster than radio formats,'' Fritts said, calling for Congress and the Federal Communications Commission to ``restore enough balance to the competitive forces to let consumers decide how much programming they want for free.'' Legislative efforts are under way to allow price controls in areas where cable companies have monopolies, and to enable communities to better ride herd on the service the companies provide. Congress should not regulate cable TV programming, but cracking down on service and prices is another matter, said Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., chairman of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee. Congress is likely to restore the ``must-carry'' provision, requiring cable companies to carry local TV broadcasting, Hollings predicted.
DOC.HEAD: NAB Honors Osgood, Jackson
DOC.TEXT: CBS correspondent Charles Osgood and New York disc jockey Hal Jackson were named to the National Association of Broadcasters' Hall of Fame on April 1. Osgood is the writer and anchor of four daily CBS News radio broadcasts. He is also a co-anchor on the ``CBS Morning News'' and contributes to ``CBS This Morning,'' on which a TV version of ``The Osgood File'' is featured each Monday. He joined CBS News as a New York-based correspondent in 1971. Jackson, of New York's WBLS, is vice chairman of Inner City Broadcasting, the largest black-owned communications company in the country. He has been a broadcaster for 51 years and is credited by many with creating opportunities for many black broadcasters and performers. They received their awards during a luncheon at the association's convention.
DOC.HEAD: Alcohol Ad Ban on Alaska State-Owned Network Proposed
DOC.TEXT: The Alaska Senate voted March 29 to ban beer and wine advertising on the state-owned television network. Broadcasters say the ban, while well-intentioned, would backfire. National networks would not allow the advertising to be blacked out and would simply withhold their programming, state broadcasters say. The Rural Alaska Television Network gets free programming from ABC, CBS and NBC affiliates in Anchorage. As part of the arrangement, the network is required to run all the commercials that come with the programs. The Alaska measure must still be approved by the state House and the governor.
DOC.HEAD: TV Station Picks News Over Smurfs
DOC.TEXT: A television station plans to replace cartoons in its Saturday morning lineup with four hours of news programming. NBC affiliate WPXI will offer consumer news, expanded local features and weather, as well as national and international news starting June 2, said News Director Dick Tuninga. Ratings for animated programs have declined in recent years, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported. ``We have to be aggressive ... We think it is a pretty bold move to dump four hours of cartoons and put in four hours of local news,'' Tuninga said.
DOC.HEAD: `Falcon Rest' _ A Cable Channel Entirely for the Birds
DOC.TEXT: Continental Cablevision is returning a hit show for a second season on its public access channel: live coverage of a falcon nest from the 21st story of a downtown building. A camera mounted near the nest was switched back on March 26 with the spring return of two peregrine falcons that spend their summer on a ledge on the 23-story Monarch Place office building. ``It amazes me that someone can sit and watch the birds hour after hour,'' said Continental general manager Brian Lambert. ``I am one of them. It stays on in the office all day long. We just kind of wait to see the bird move or the eggs or whatever. It's mesmerizing.'' Running cable to the building and mounting the camera behind reflective glass cost about $10,000, Lambert said. ``We often joke around the office that we spend tens and hundreds of thousands of dollars on new customer service features or new programming services and almost as a second thought we covered the peregrine falcons story and overnight it became an instant success,'' Lambert said.
DOC.HEAD: William Keating Moves to Cincinnati
DOC.TEXT: William J. Keating, president and chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency, is returning to Cincinnati as chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. Keating, also chairman of the board of The Associated Press, will be succeeded in Detroit by Joseph M. Ungaro, Gannett Co. Inc. said March 28. Ungaro is a Gannett vice president, and president and publisher of its Westchester Rockland Newspapers in suburban New York City. Keating was publisher and president of the Enquirer in Cincinnati and a regional president of Gannett from 1979 to 1984. In Cincinnati he replaces John Zanotti, who resigned to become publisher of the Arizona Republic and Phoenix Gazette. Gary F. Sherlock was named to succeed Ungaro. Sherlock has been executive vice president of advertising for the Newspaper Division of Gannett since 1988 and president of Gannett National Newspaper Sales since 1986. From 1981 to 1986 he was publisher of The Idaho Statesman in Boise.
DOC.HEAD: Robert Hall Named Publisher in Philadelphia
DOC.TEXT: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced March 28 that Robert J. Hall, publisher and chairman of the Detroit Free Press, would assume the same duties at Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., the company that publishes The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Philadelphia Daily News. Hall replaces Sam S. McKeel, who retired in June and then became president and chief executive officer of Chicago Sun-Times Inc. Named to replace Hall was Neal Shine, former senior managing editor of the Free Press who retired last June. Shine has continued to write a column in the newspaper and was teaching at Oakland University in Rochester, Mich.
DOC.HEAD: Maurer, Bahrenburg Get New Posts at Hearst
DOC.TEXT: Hearst Corp. announced on March 29 that Gilbert Maurer, executive vice president of the corporation and president of its magazine division, had been named chief operating officer of the parent company. D. Claeys Bahrenburg, 42, was named to replace Maurer as president of the magazine division. He had been executive vice president and group publishing director at Hearst Magazines.
DOC.HEAD: Stauffer Names New Editors
DOC.TEXT: Daniel S. Collinson, editor and publisher of the Arkansas City Traveler the past seven years, will succeed R. Joe Sullivan as editor and publisher of The Blue Springs (Mo.) Examiner. Kimberly M. Benedict, advertising manager of The Hillsdale (Mich.) Daily News, will replace Collinson in Arkansas City, it was announced March 20 by Kenneth C. Bronson, vice president-newspapers of Stauffer Communications Inc.
DOC.HEAD: Edwin Freakley Named Publisher of The Daily Progress
DOC.TEXT: Edwin M. Freakley, an executive vice president of the Worrell Enterprises Inc. newspaper group, was named publisher of The Daily Progress on March 28. He replaces William A. Kirkland Jr., who is retiring after 10 years as publisher, said Thomas E. Worrell Jr., chairman and president of Worrell Enterprises. Freakley moved to the company's corporate office in Charlottesville a year ago. He joined Worrell in 1980 as executive editor of The News & Daily Advance in Lynchburg. Prior to that he was assistant managing editor of the Roanoke Times & World News.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Salter Named Publisher in Clovis
DOC.TEXT: Bill Salter, editor of The News Herald in Panama City, Fla., was named publisher of the Clovis News-Journal on March 28. Salter, 46, replaces James Griffin, said Joseph F. Barletta, executive vice president-chief operating officer for Freedom Newspapers. Salter became managing editor of the Kerrville Daily Times in 1972 and joined Freedom Newspapers in 1976 at Brownsville.
DOC.HEAD: Mastricolo Named Director of Photography
DOC.TEXT: Carlo A. Mastricolo was named director of photography for The Boston Globe on March 27, replacing Vincent J. Alabiso, who left to become executive photo editor for The Associated Press. Mastricolo, 43, had been assistant director of photography since 1987. He worked for The New York Times as an assistant picture editor for six years before coming to the Globe, and was a picture editor in the Washington bureau of the AP for the two previous years. Mastricolo has also worked for The Bulletin in Philadelphia, the Courier-Post in Camden, N.J., and the Bucks County Courier Times in Levittown, Pa.
DOC.HEAD: Jensen Named Great Falls Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Chris E. Jensen was named president and publisher of the Great Falls Tribune on March 28 after the Gannett Co. completed its purchase of the newspaper. Jensen, 44, has been publisher and president of the Muskogee (Okla.) Daily Phoenix & Times-Democrat since August 1986. He succeeds Steven Studt, who will remain regional vice president of Cowles Media Co. Jensen began his career in 1965 as a dispatch clerk at Gannett's Pensacola News Journal. He later served as credit manager, personnel director and advertising director at the newspaper. Cowles announced March 2 that it was selling the Tribune to Gannett for $41 million.
DOC.HEAD: Katherine O'Hearn Named ABC News L.A. Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: Katherine O'Hearn, a former senior producer of ``World News This Morning,'' was appointed Los Angeles bureau chief for ABC News on March 26. She succeeds Mark Nelson, now a senior producer at ABC's ``Nightline.'' O'Hearn, who began her career in 1976 with CBS News, will be the second woman in charge of a network news bureau in Los Angeles. The other is Jennifer Siebens of CBS.
DOC.HEAD: Gloria Fletcher Named Publisher at Woodward News
DOC.TEXT: American Publishing has named Gloria Fletcher publisher of the Woodward News. Ms. Fletcher had been general manager for the past two years. She joined the newspaper in 1985 as art director and was subsequently named advertising manager.
DOC.HEAD: Diane McFarlin Named Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Diane McFarlin, executive editor of The Gainesville Sun, will take over as executive editor of the Sarasota Herald-Tribune next year. The Herald-Tribune announced March 29 that McFarlin will return to Sarasota in June as managing editor, a position she held from 1985 to 1987 before going to the Sun. That move is to fill the vacancy left by the resignation last month of Kerry Slagle. On Jan. 1 she will replace William McIlwain, who will become a senior editor of the New York Times Regional Newspaper Group, which owns the Herald-Tribune and the Sun. McFarlin joined the Sarasota newspaper in 1976 as a reporter and copy editor.
DOC.HEAD: Landers Named Fort Myers Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Everett S. Landers, editor and associate publisher of The Olympian in Olympia, Wash., was named executive editor of the Fort Myers News-Press on March 28. He replaces J. Keith Moyer, who became editor of Little Rock's Arkansas Gazette in early March. Landers was previously executive editor of the Reno (Nev.) Gazette Journal. All four are Gannett Co. Inc. newspapers.
DOC.HEAD: Buchleitner Moves to Newsweek
DOC.TEXT: Walter Buchleitner, an executive at U.S. News & World Report, will join Newsweek magazine as associate publisher and advertising sales director for the domestic edition. Buchleitner, 47, replaces Arthur Karlan, who retired in 1989. He will also be a vice president at Newsweek Inc., the company announced March 30. Buchleitner joined U.S. News in 1985 and was vice president and director of advertising sales. He had previously been associate sales director and national sales account manager at Business Week. He began his publishing career in 1964 as a sales representative for the Chicago Tribune and also worked in sales capacities at Readers Digest and Time.
DOC.HEAD: Seabury Merritt Blair
DOC.TEXT: Seabury Merritt Blair, former city editor and copy editor for the Spokesman-Review, died March 28 of cancer. He was 80. Blair joined the Spokesman-Review as a part-time general assignment reporter in 1941. He became a staff writer five years later and was named city editor in 1950, a post he held for nearly nine years. He was a features editor and assistant to the Sunday Inland Empire Magazine editor for five years before serving on the copy desk, chiefly as wire editor. Survivors include his wife, Hildegarde, and two sons, one sister, one brother and one granddaughter.
DOC.HEAD: Alan B. Gillon
DOC.TEXT: Alan B. Gillon, a former managing editor and Sunday editor of the Plattsburgh Press-Republican, died of cancer March 28 at the age of 56. Gillon was the newspaper's special projects editor and had been ill for a year. He was managing editor from 1972-76 and launched Press-Republican's new Sunday edition in 1987. Gillon was also known for a column, called ``Fast Forward,'' he wrote for the Sunday Press-Republican. He worked for the Atlanta Constitution before joining the Savannah News-Press in 1963, and the Tampa (Fla.) Times in 1967. Gillon is survived by his wife, Susan, and a son.

Ledgerwood C. Sloan, a longtime Associated Press and Texas newspaper reporter, died March 28 at the age of 87. After starting at the San Angelo Standard-Times, Sloan worked for the AP in Dallas and New York from 1937 until 1962. Sloan transferred to New York in 1945 as a photo editor. Four years later, he moved to the AP's General Desk. In 1951 Sloan returned to Dallas and was an AP broadcast reporter until he retired from the wire service in 1962. He went to work for The Dallas Morning News as an editor and reporter before retiring again in 1968. Sloan is survived by his wife, Frances, and a niece.

DOC.HEAD: San Jose Mercury News Wins Headliner Award for Quake Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Coverage of the California earthquake won The San Jose Mercury News top honors March 28 in the 1990 National Headliner Club's 56th annual competition. The newspaper won first place in the category of news reporting in daily newspapers with a circulation greater than 150,000. The Arizona Republic won the best investigative reporting award for its coverage of the collapse of Charles Keating's savings and loan empire. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer won the outstanding public service award for a series written by James A. Wallace that exposed the health dangers posed by transporting poisonous materials in large tank trucks. The Fort Worth Star-Telegram received a special citation for creating extraordinary local involvement and pride with its coverage of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. The Press Club of Atlantic City, sponsors of the award competition, will present the honors at a dinner May 12. This year's competition drew a record 1,600 entries in categories for newspapers, magazines, syndicates and broadcast outlets. The winners in print categories are as follows: _ Outstanding news reporting for circulation of up to 50,000: 1. Eileen Welsome, Mark Taylor, Shonda Novak, The Albuquerque Tribune, ``A Price on Their Heads,'' wildlife profiteering; 2. DOC.HEAD: Society of Professional Journalists Announces 1989 Awards
DOC.TEXT: The Society of Professional Journalists has awarded its 1989 Sigma Delta Chi Award for deadline reporting to the San Francisco Examiner staff for coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake that rocked the San Francisco Bay area. The award was one of 26 for print and broadcast journalism announced April 1 by the Chicago-based society, which has issued awards annually since 1940. This year's winners will receive plaques and bronze medallions at a banquet May 5 in Tulsa, Okla. The society's judges said the Examiner's coverage was the best of several entries from newspapers that reported on the earthquake. ``The lead was exceptional, telling and thorough, as were the pages and pages of articles in the special 16-page all-news issue the day after the earthquake,'' the judges said in a statement. They noted that the special edition was put together without electricity and with only five telephone lines operating. Two San Francisco radio stations and a television station also received awards for their earthquake coverage. KCBS won the award for radio spot news for its 84 hours of continuous commercial-free news and information after the Oct. 17 earthquake, while the television spot news reporting award went to the staff of KGO-TV. The award for public service in radio journalism went to KGO for a retrospective on the Oct. 17 earthquake. The other awards announced by the society were: _Non-deadline reporting: Tom Hallman Jr., Dave Hogan, Holley Gilbert, Julie Tripp, Fred Leeson, James Long and Lauren Cowen of The Oregonian in Portland for a 12-part series on the impact of drugs in their city. _Investigative reporting: Bob Paynter, Keith McKnight and Andrew Zajac of the Beacon Journal of Akron, Ohio, for a series of exposes on Ohio House Speaker Vernal G. Riffe Jr. _Feature writing: Tom Archdeacon of the Dayton (Ohio) Daily News for an account of a 13-year-old boy's accidental slaying by a friend while the two were playing with a handgun. _Editorial writing: Lawrence Levy of Newsday for ``Killer Taxes,'' a series of editorials on Long Island's economic problems. _Washington correspondence: Bill Lambrecht of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch for ``Trashing the Earth,'' a series on the toxic waste trade and its effects on the residents of developing nations. _Foreign correspondence: Nora Boustany of The Washington Post for her continuing coverage of the war in Lebanon. _Public service in newspaper journalism (circulation greater than 100,000): the Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader for an examination of the politics of education in Kentucky, a series that prompted more than 1,400 letters from readers. _Public service in newspaper journalism (circulation less than 100,000): a tie between the Washington (N.C.) Daily News and The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass. The Daily News was cited for a deadline story and follow-up on carcinogens in the area's water supply. The Patriot Ledger was honored for a series on the influx of Asian immigrants into the area of Quincy, south of Boston. _Magazine reporting: Daniel Golden for two articles in The Boston Globe Magazine on the Oglala Sioux of the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. _Public service in magazine journalism: a tie between Common Cause Magazine and The New Yorker. Common Cause was honored for a series of articles on the corrupting influence of money on the political process in Washington, D.C. The New Yorker was cited for a series on the possible health hazards of low-level electromagnetic radiation. _Photography: Patrick Davison of The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune for photographs accompanying a series on the exploitation of elk. _Editorial cartooning: Don Wright of The Palm Beach Post of West Palm Beach, Fla., for a cartoon on the role of the U.S. Supreme Court in the controversy over abortion. _Editorializing on radio: WBBM-AM in Chicago for editorials by Catherine Cahan on the issue of acces for the disabled in the workplace. _Radio investigative reporting: Phil Rogers of WBBM-AM in Chicago for reports on security gaps at O'Hare International Airport. _Public service in television journalism (networks and top-40 markets): WITI-TV in Milwaukee for a report on the problems of teen-age sexual activity and pregnancy. _Public service in television journalism (all other markets): KSAT-TV in San Antonio, Texas, for a story on the impact of uranium mning on Karnes County, Texas. _Television editorials: Ed Quinn, Paul Sands, Don Lundy, Judy Vance and John Beatty of KGTV in San Diego, Calif., for three editorials on local topics. It was the second year in a row that the KGTV editorial crew won the honor. _Television investigative reporting: Mark Feldstein, reporter, and Diane Sperrazza, producer, of WUSA-TV in Washington, D.C., for their investigation of allegations of drug use by Washington Mayor Marion Barry. _Research about journalism: Gregory Gordon and Ronald E. Cohen for ``Down to the Wire: UPI's Fight for Survival,'' their book on the recent history of the news service.

Richard Nixon's new book ``In the Arena'' offers some hints on dealing with reporters, including translations of such phrases as ``Oh, and just one more question.'' Nixon: ``Forget the other 10 he asked; this is what he really came for.'' ... The late Margaret Bourke-White, the Life and Fortune magazine photojournalist, has been named to the National Women's Hall of Fame in Washington ... President Bush's speaking style has become a favorite for comics to imitate. Bush mocked his staccato delivery himself at the Radio and Television Correspondents Association dinner March 29 when he said of one comic: ``I'll be honest. He's good _ too good. That's as far as I'll go. Not going to comment. Not going to criticize Jim Morris at this juncture. Wouldn't be prudent.''

DOC.TEXT: Brent Musburger, the smooth-talking announcer who was the voice and face of CBS Sports in the '80s, becomes a free agent tonight. Musburger was let go by the network Sunday after they failed to agree on a new contract. His farewell broadcast will be tonight's NCAA basketball championship game between Duke and the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. ``I was surprised, but it was a great run and I have a million memories, and I leave behind a lot of good friends,'' Musburger said in a statement. ``At this time, I'm going to take an extended vacation, and I'll be working again someday, somewhere.'' The move stunned Musburger's colleagues, some of whom thought it was an April Fool's joke.

A man who donated one of his kidneys seven years ago to save his mother's life died hours before she could pay him back today with a bone marrow transplant. Hilliary Mitchell, 37, who had been unable to work as a truck driver since contracting leukemia, was scheduled to receive the bone marrow from his mother, Ernestine, 56. But Mitchell was unable to hang on for the potentially life-saving procedure. He died at 11:25 p.m. Sunday, said nursing coordinator Ann Jagliella of the University of Chicago Hospitals. Mitchell had already won one battle in getting the money for the $150,000 transplant from the state Medicaid program after Gov. James R. Thompson stepped in and reversed a decision denying funds for the operation.

A worldwide celebration of the environment will envelop this battered and polluted planet this month, and by all accounts Earth Day '90 will dwarf its namesake of two decades ago. Even corporate America wants to get involved. Planning for the environmental extravaganza has been in the works for more than a year. President Bush has proclaimed April 22 Earth Day, and governors and mayors across the country are issuing similar proclamations. That spring Sunday comes exactly 20 year after Earth Day '70 ushered in the modern environmental movement.

Soviet defector Alexander Ushakov outwitted two carloads of KGB gumshoes to make a daring escape to the West six years ago. Now he's plotting another humiliation for the Soviet secret police. Ushakov says he's suing the KGB. The former Soviet navy commander plans to haul his former tormenters into court _ possibly before an international tribunal in London _ to recover books, manuscripts and other documents seized by KGB agents during a raid on his wife's apartment in Odessa in 1984. Ushakov is seeking not only the return of his anti-communist writings, but monetary damages for the emotional suffering he and his wife, Irina, endured.

A highly paid army of lobbyists and lawyers is fighting one of the last battles of the Cold War, an intense struggle to influence U.S. policy in the obscure African country of Angola. It is one of the last skirmishes left for the United States and Soviet Union. Neither is willing to abandon its allies in Angola, but neither is either side willing to let the civil war there hold up overall improvements in their relationship. While the Bush administration's approach is low key, conservatives in Washington have adopted a highly visible stance. ``A key test of whether the Soviets have in fact changed their imperial ambitions is Soviet behavior'' in Angola, according to a half-page ad in The New York Times that was paid for by the International Security Council, a conservative think tank.

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Monday April 9 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Have Freedom, but Not From the Household Bills
DOC.TEXT: Ilona Nagy is all for democracy, but it doesn't solve the problem of how to pay a $74 electricity bill and still keep a family of six going on the rest of $300 a month. The monthly budget would be much smaller if she did not have a second job. Her husband, Daniel, has left a secure government position to form a private partnership, so his income is uncertain. ``You have to work out a strategy to survive,'' said Mrs. Nagy, a 45-year-old folklore specialist at the Academy of Sciences who is fluent in English and German. ``I work about 70 to 80 hours a week.'' Her monthly net salary of about $135, after 20 years at the academy, illustrates how the former communist regime treated most intellectuals who were not party members. A few intellectuals got into the bureaucracy, but most faced a combination of punishment for dissent and pay lower than that of blue-collar workers. Mrs. Nagy works as a part-time editor of folklore literature to supplement the family income, and three of her four children take odd jobs for pocket money. Two boys study at Budapest universities. More liberty has been a mixed blessing to the Nagys. With democracy has come greater inflation, now approaching a yearly rate of 20 percent. Also, Mrs. Nagy often has visiting mouths to feed because her husband is a Hungarian from Transylvania, in neighboring Romania, and the revolution there has given his relatives freedom to travel. ``In this situation, I can't care too much about politics, but one has to think that things will be getting better after all,'' Mrs. Nagy told an interviewer in her Budapest apartment. ``I see the political changes as terribly interesting, but in our everyday life the situation has not changed. You realize that, with every month, the economic situation worsens.'' Relatives arrive from Transylvania, in western Romania, in groups of three or four, and stay for varying periods. ``Umpteen times it's been like this: The door bell rings and outside are our Romanian relatives,'' Mrs. Nagy said. ``My first thought always is: The fridge is empty, so is the purse, but I've got to look after them.'' Vacations have been only a dream to the Nagys for years, but now even normal life is squeezed by price increases. The two-month electricity bill just went up from to 4,600 florints, about $74, from less than 3,000. Daniel Nagy earned the equivalent of $177 a month as a chemical engineer for a state enterprise, but his wife said ``it's not clear what his income will be'' from the new partnership. ``For a long time, I haven't bought a new dress,'' she said. ``Most everything we wear has been bought at a secondhand shop. ``To find something suitable there is fun, of a kind. It is also interesting, because ... people who do their purchasing there are very poor, those who have to eke out a living with very little money.'' Worsening economic conditions have impoverished one-fifth of Hungary's 10.7 million people. Hungarians generally seem to feel economic problems will be with them for a long time, whatever a new democratic government does. Average monthly pay is the equivalent of $129, rent averages $16 a month and a pair of women's shoes costs $48. Milk is 32 cents a liter (just over a quart), a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of butter is $2.60 and a kilo of pork costs $4. Most price increases stemmed from the reduction or elimination of subsidies and other cuts in public spending needed to qualify for International Monetary Fund credits. Price hikes in January and early February led to public protests and Budapest's first public transport strike.
