According to Gary P. DelVecchio, Doubleday Book Shops' president, the travel shops are decorated to evoke the elegance of luxury cruise ships, with marble, mahogany and etched glass. ``The cash register areas look like a ship's bar, down to the brass footrails,'' he says. A prototype Traveldays opened last year in Columbus, Ohio, and the company says more branches are planned. _ If you want to include that other member of the family in the vacation fun, there are two guides: ``Pets on the Go,'' written by pet specialist Mordecai Siegal and offered free from Alpo Petfoods, and ``Touring with Towser,'' for $1.50 from the Quaker Pet Care Center. ``Traveling with animals is not as difficult as it may seem,'' Siegal writes in this booklet, which includes practical trips about pet health and accomodations on the road. The 68-page book from Quaker, which makes Gaines and Ken-L Ration products, lists names, addresses and phone numbers of 2,000 independently owned hotels and motels and ten chains with more than 4,000 locations that welcome pets. There's also a listing of pet accommodations in areas where hotels and motels don't allow pets. For ``Pets on the Go,'' write to the Alpo Pet Center at P.O. Box 4000, Allentown, Pa. 18001. ``Touring with Towser'' is available with a check or money order for $1.50 payable to Quaker Professional Services, 585 Hawthorne Court, Galesburg, Ill. 61401. _

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Factors to Consider When Buying Medigap Insurance
With BC-PRI--Medigap Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Here are some important factors to consider when shopping for medigap insurance, as suggested by the Senate Special Committee on Aging. _ Review Medicare's gaps in coverage to determine what is important to you in a supplement. Consider policy features, premiums, waiting periods, pre-existing condition exclusions, and maximum benefit clauses. _ Work with hometown agents and companies you know. A company must meet certain qualifications to do business in your state. _ Talk with friends who have had good claims experiences. _ Investigate group insurance sold by legitimate organizations. But remember, some senior citizen or retired person organizations are legitimate and some are set up as fronts to get your business. While some of these plans are good deals, others are not as good as individual plans. _ Take into consideration any other coverage you have that continues beyond age 65. _ Consider how much you can afford to pay for hospital or medical bills and how much you can afford for supplemental health insurance premiums. _ As a general rule, buy one good comprehensive Medicare supplemental policy. There are some exceptions if you have an employer group policy that is affordable, but limited in benefits. _ Check for special circumstances for which the insurance company may eliminate coverage for a health condition you had before you bought the policy. A policy may refer to this as a pre-existing condition. _ Beware of replacing existing coverage. Be suspicious of a suggestion that you give up any policy and buy a replacement. Often new policies will impose a waiting period or will have exclusions and waiting periods for pre-existing conditions. This means you may have to wait for up to six months before you will be eligible to collect anything on a new policy. _ Beware of maximum benefits. Most policies have a limit on benefits that may be expressed in dollars available or the number of days for which payments will be made. _ Check your right to renew. Beware of policies that let the company refuse to renew your policy on an individual basis. A policy that is guaranteed renewable is preferable. _ Remember, policies to supplement Medicare are neither sold nor serviced by state or federal governments. Do not believe statements that insurance to supplement Medicare is government-sponsored. _ Don't pay cash. Write a check or money order payable to the company, not the agent. _ Keep the agents' and-or companies' names, addresses and telephone numbers so that you can contact them easily in case of problems. _ The medigap insurance market is highly competitve. Take your time. Do not let a short-term enrollment period pressure you, and remember that some states prohibit special enrollment periods.

Editors: Copies of ``A Guide to Purchasing Medigap and Long-Term Care Insurance'' may be obtained by writing to the Senate Special Committee on Aging, G-31 Dirksen Building, United States Senate, Washington, D.C., 20510, Attention: Publications.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Getting Nostalgia Kicks on Route 66
DOC.TEXT: The people at Lucille's Service Station have pumped gas on Route 66 long enough to see history buffs start getting mileage out of it. Eula Mae Brown, 67, remembers when it was something to have the traveler perched on the Nehi icebox at her father's Hydro station turn out to be from the East Coast. ``I always found it just exciting,'' Mrs. Brown said. ``Some of the people who talked a different dialect would amuse me so.'' Now the people who pull up to the pumps under the station's old-fashioned clapboard overhang talk with British accents, Australian accents. They ask Lucille Hamons to autograph her photograph in a glossy book on Route 66 that confirms her status as living history. Mrs. Hamons has run the station since her husband took it over in 1941, 14 years after Mrs. Brown's father built it. Mrs. Hamons sells sandwiches and soft drinks from her gas station, and since 1966 also has sold what she calls the coldest beer in Oklahoma. ``You know who will be coming here next, don't you? It'll be the Japanese,'' Mrs. Hamons says, anticipating the next wave of tourists on the highway that ran from Chicago to the West Coast. Tulsa writer Michael Wallis said he already has seen Japanese among the tourists and filmmakers at barbecue joints and cafes along Route 66 this year. Four independent filmmakers are working on documentaries about the highway, he said. St. Martin's Press is due to publish Wallis' own book about the road this spring. Wallis plans to tool down 66 in a 1964 Corvette to promote it. Route 66 crosses eight states and three time zones, starting out at the shores of Lake Michigan in Illinois. It makes its winding, wooded way south from the lake, and from Oklahoma City on makes a pretty straight shot through the western Plains and desert, over the Rocky Mountains, and through arid country again to the beach at Santa Monica. It opens to four lanes in spots, but is mainly a two-lane highway, with curbs and curves that used to send Packards and Plymouths spinning off the road and into tree trunks. Legislation is under way to make all 2,400 miles a national monument. This winter, Kansas became the eighth and final state to establish a Route 66 association, devoted to the 12 miles that hook through its territory, Wallis said. Oklahoma tourism is catching on. Promoters plan a Route 66 car rally and a Mr. and Mrs. Route 66 contest this summer. Businesses are capitalizing on the ``Route 66'' moniker to sell everything from art to antiques. Oklahoma could capitalize on Route 66 retaining more of its old feel than it does in some other states, Wallis said. Oklahoma also happens to be the only state that earned a qualitative statement in a song listing the quantity of cities lining Route 66 (``... Saint Louey Joplin Missouri, And Oklahoma City is mighty pretty. ...''). Bobby Troup thought up the song as he drove out to California when he got out of the service. Pop singer Michael Martin Murphy is putting it through its 25th recording, Wallis said. It's a song about getting your nostalgia kicks on Route 66. ``But this is a case where nostalgia has really symbolized the best of something,'' Wallis said. ``It's still a corridor of America that's not generic.'' ``It's an America that's before fax machines and fern bars, before the malling of America,'' he said. ``I remember when it was an adventure, starting when Dad used to back the Plymouth down the highway.'' For Lucille's in Hydro, there were 40 years when ``I can't even think how you could have left New York City and go to the coastline without coming by our little store,'' Mrs. Brown said. She saw the first pioneers to try out the notion of a road that let one drive from Lake Michigan to the Pacific Ocean without once having to stop to ask directions. Mrs. Hamons saw the exodus of Okies, distinguishable from the Arkies, she said, by the single rather than the double layer of mattresses on top of their cars. She saw the post-World War II migration in which singer Troup took part, and supplied Nehis and rented cabins to the tourists who followed. Mrs. Hamons started selling beer to survive after road crews plowed up a temporary ramp leading off newly built Interstate 40, parallel to 66, she said. She has a case for claiming the title of longest continually operating merchant on Route 66 in Oklahoma. Fern bar and shopping mall development hasn't spoiled her stretch of Route 66 because there was little development money after the interstate came. Today, Mrs. Hamons sells Route 66 T-shirts, coffee mugs and refrigerator magnets along with beer. She is thinking of opening one of the tourist cabins out back to accommodate an expected increase in trade this summer. ``It's what you've seen, and who you've come to know,'' she said. ``To me, that's 66. It's not so much a money-making deal. It's just memories.'' ``It's memories to Lucille,'' Wallis said. ``It's making a buck to everyone else.'' ``Route 66 ... is and was a commercial proposition,'' Wallis said. ``People trying to make a living selling postcards, tanks of gas, a room for the night, greasy cheeseburgers, a look at the snake pit.'' Now, merchants from ``Saint Louey'' to San Bernadino are hawking memories. Americans, Wallis said, are buying ``a chance to rediscover themselves on the ribbon of time.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Board Chairman Says Company Will Review Loans
DOC.TEXT: The head of a giant lending company says he's taking steps to guard against cases like the one in which his company tried to seize the home of an elderly, impoverished widow. Other loan files from Transamerica Financial Services' Scottsdale office will be reviewed, but any problems are likely to be local, said Arthur Van Leuven, chief executive officer of Transamerica Financial Group and executive vice president of its parent, Transamerica Corp. Transcripts of court testimony by a former loan officer persuaded Transamerica to drop its fight with 77-year-old Lennie Williams, Van Leuven said in a recent telephone interview. ``It was really not a hard decision,'' he said. ``It was a slam-dunk.'' The battle began after Mrs. Williams allowed her small, 42-year-old home to be used as security for a loan her son-in-law took out from Transamerica Financial Services Inc., the corporation's Arizona operation. The son-in-law disappeared with the money, according to court records, and Transamerica began foreclosure on the home after Mrs. Williams, who supports herself on pensions of $438 a month, was unable to keep up with monthly loan payments of $499 a month. Volunteer lawyers fought back. The loan officer who handled Mrs. Williams' loan testified that he doubted whether she understood what she was doing, and a doctor who was treating her at the time testified that she wasn't capable of remembering which pill to take, much less of understanding loan agreements. Even after a Maricopa County Superior Court judge in January ordered a temporary halt to the foreclosure and said it was likely Transamerica ``knew or should have known'' something was wrong when it made the loan, the company's lawyers pursued the case and demanded that Mrs. Williams post bond of $450 a month pending trial. Last month, an Associated Press story detailed Mrs. Williams' plight. At about the same time, senior officials at Transamerica Financial Group received a transcript of the loan officer's testimony, according to Van Leuven. ``It became apparent from that transcript that two parties had been victimized,'' he said. ``Lennie Williams is one of them, and Transamerica is the other.'' The company decided to drop all proceedings against Mrs. Williams and proceed only against the son-in-law because it is ``far easier for us to stand the victimization than for Lennie Williams,'' Van Leuven said. The company will return payments Mrs. Williams made to the court and will review other loans by its Scottsdale office to ensure there aren't any similar cases, he said. The review will be difficult, because there was nothing in Mrs. Williams' file to indicate an unusual transaction until her lawyers began complaining, he said. Mrs. Williams' attorney, Michael Curran, said a tentative agreement had been reached in her case. ``She was just completely relieved when we finally were able to get it through to her that she was never going to have to worry about someone taking her house again,'' said another of her lawyers, Douglas Erickson.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Research Shows Some People Are Born with Confidence
DOC.TEXT: Some people are born with the belief that they are masters of their own lives. Others feel they are at the mercy of fate. New research shows that some of those feelings are in the genes. Psychologists long have known that people confident in their ability to control their destinies are more likely to adjust well to growing old than others. Two researchers who questioned hundreds of Swedish twins report that such confidence, or lack of it, is partly genetic and partly drawn from experience. They also found that the belief in blind luck _ that coincidence plays a big role in life _ is something learned and has nothing to do with heredity. The research was conducted at the Karolinska Institute, which annually awards the Nobel Prize for medicine, by Karolinska's Nancy Pedersen and Margaret Gatz, a psychology professor at the University of Southern California. Their results recently were published in the United States in the Journal of Gerontology. The study of twins, who have identical or similar genes, eliminates genetics as the explanation of differences, said Richard J. Rose, professor of psychology and medical genetics at Indiana University. Variances in twins must then be attributed to their distinct environment and experiences. The result of the Gatz-Pedersen study ``is consistent with other world literature on the subject,'' but has the added importance of being based on a far larger and more representative sample than previous research, Rose said. ``The belief in your ability to control your life direction, or the belief in your own competence, is 30 percent something you are born with,'' said Gatz, interviewed during a consultation visit to Sweden. People who are confident of their ability to control their lives have an ``internal locus of control,'' and a better chance of being well adjusted in old age, said Pedersen. An ``external locus of control,'' believing that outside forces determine the course of life, has been linked to depression in later years, she said. ``This is one of the windows on the aging process,'' said Pedersen, who has published a series of studies on the genetics of personality traits based on interviews with twins. The study on life-control involved 554 pairs of twins. ``We are trying to understand what makes people different. What makes some people age gracefully and others have a more difficult time?'' she said. ``Whether people feel independent is an important standard for service institutions and how they treat the elderly.'' The study showed that while people have an inborn predilection toward independence and self-confidence, about 70 percent of this personality trait is affected by a person's environment and experiences. Pedersen's studies, with various collaborators, probe the aging process by comparing sets of twins, identical and fraternal, many of whom were separated at an early age. The subjects were drawn from a roster first compiled about 30 years ago registering all twins born in Sweden since 1886. The complete list, which was extended in 1971, has 95,000 sets of twins. Rose said the registry, based on the whole population, is ``an unusually powerful tool.'' U.S. researchers have nothing comparable, and normally rely on twins who respond to advertisements. Karolinska Professor Anders Ahlbom, who runs the registry, said 80 percent to 85 percent of twins typically respond to questionnaires sent by researchers. Pedersen said that studies of twins who were reared separately but have identical or nearly identical genes, compared with twins reared together, can yield a unique measure of nature-vs.-nurture in human development. Earlier research by Pedersen showed that a variety of other characteristics are 30 percent to 40 percent determined by a person's genetic makeup, including many of those traits comprising what has become known as Type A behavior. The Type A person _ the hard-driving worker who brings home his work from the office, eats too fast, keeps his foot on the clutch at traffic lights and makes a point of being on time _ has been found to have a higher risk of heart disease before age 65.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Allow Older First Cousins to Marry
DOC.TEXT: Older first cousins who got married in New Mexico are asking the Legislature to change Arizona law so their marriage is legal here. A bill, which would apply to couples over 65, cleared the House recently and was sent to the Senate on a 40-20 vote. Rep. Lela Steffey said she introduced the bill on behalf of Ruth and Henry Hinkley, who were married last year and have been unable to persuade the state Office of Veterans Affairs to recognize the marriage, which could jeopardize their veterans' benefits, Mrs. Steffey said. ``A lot more people support it than I had anticipated because there's no harm to it,'' Mrs. Steffey said. Indeed, at least one other lawmaker said the bill might not go far enough. Rep. Margaret Updike noted that some states allow first cousins to marry without age restrictions. Mrs. Steffey said she chose 65 as a cutoff because she had heard that the oldest woman to become pregnant was 58, and she wanted to ensure there could be no offspring. State law prohibits marriage between parents and children, siblings, uncles and nieces, aunts and nephews and first cousins. It is intended to reduce the risk of children being born with genetic problems. Although the bill was criticized as legislation intended to benefit one couple, Mrs. Steffey said she has heard from several cousins in similar situations. One New Jersey couple learned about Arizona's marriage restriction during a recent visit and delayed plans to move here pending passage of Mrs. Steffey's bill, she said. Mrs. Steffey said she believes that because 29 other states allow first cousins to marry in some situations that there may be many more cousins in Arizona who either have kept their marriage secret or who don't realize such marriages are not recognized here. Mrs. Hinkley, who is 72, has hit roadblocks in trying to care for her 89-year-old husband, who is blind, nearly deaf and has had one leg amputated, Mrs. Steffey said. The state's failure to recognize the marriage also could keep Mrs. Hinkley from receiving benefits should her husband die, Mrs. Steffey said. Mrs. Steffey said she recommended the couple consider moving back to New Mexico. ``She could move back, that probably wouldn't be any big problem,'' Mrs. Steffey said. ``But he couldn't move. He's in extremely poor shape. He's in a nursing home here.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: How to Add Vegetables to Your Diet
DOC.TEXT: Jane Weston Wilson is the author of the lifestyle cookbook ``Eating Well When You Just Can't Eat the Way You Used To,'' Workman Publishing.

Do you remember, as a kid, your mother saying, ``As soon as you eat your brownies you can have your peas and carrots?'' No way. You had to push through some usually overcooked and under-seasoned canned or frozen vegetables to get to dessert. Sometimes salads stood in for the vegetable, but front and center was meat and potatoes. Now for optimum health we are encouraged to eat richly and in greater variety from the vegetable kingdom. How do we proceed? As one friend of mind said over lunch, ``I know Fred and I should be eating more vegetables, but how do you make them interesting?'' If you head to your local bookstore or public library, vegetable cookbooks are taking up not one shelf, but whole units of shelving offering thousands of recipes from every culture, including our own. At our supermarkets more and more space is given over to fresh produce, with exotic fruits and vegetables from around the world, often tagged with a recipe on how to use them. When you stop to think about it, almost all regional and international favorites feature a preponderance of vegetables, grains, beans, even fruits. Meat is a component that is excluded or included; the most appearing on feast days. Whether it's couscous, curries, or cassoulet, the seasonings define the dish. Two of my favorites are vegetable curry and black bean chili. I also enjoy vegetables in different ways at each meal. As entree and as salad (say a stir fry and a slaw), or as a container (squash or peppers filled with grains, beans, vegetables or meat). Fermented black bean sauce or pesto goes over fish, chicken and pasta. Old-fashioned pickled beets and cucumbers, or the new variety of fresh salsas as condiments. And as a year-round entree, vegetable salad. Whenever possible, buy from green farms in your city or farmstands. When you buy at the supermarket, experiment with a fruit or vegetable that is new to you. For familiar vegetables, ask the manager if they are dyed or waxed. Taking creative responsibility for your health is essential.

Vegetable Salad Nicoise Serves 4 { cup zucchini, scrubbed, ends removed, cut lengthwise and then in \-inch slices { cup yellow summer squash, washed, ends removed, cut in thirds lengthwise and then in \-inch slices 4 ounces green beans, ends removed, cut in half 6 to 8 cherry tomatoes, stemmed, cut in half { cup pitted black olives, drained and rinsed 1 6-ounce jar of marinated artichoke hearts, drained, thoroughly rinsed and cut in half { cup vinaigrette dressing
In a pan, in two quarts of water, over medium heat, cook string beans until crisp tender, six to eight minutes. Drain and refresh under cold water. In a large bowl, combine all the vegetables. In a small bowl, whisk the dressing and pour over salad, mix throroughly and serve.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Five Years Worth Investing for Good Asparagus Eating
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

Asparagus has sublime flavor, beauty, lineage _ in a word, class _ and a gardner who achieves a well-established bed gets respect. A would-be asparagus grower needs patience and determination. It takes a good five years to have harvests worth talking about. In a mobile society, this eliminates a lot of people. Who's going to plant a vegetable for some future tenant to enjoy? But if you've settled down, or retired, an asparagus bed is a gilt-edged investment producing abundantly and requiring little effort to maintain. Asparagus ranks as one of the oldest vegetables, little different in its cultivated state from the wild spears of remote ages. Menus recovered from the ruins of Pompeii show the Romans enjoyed young asparagus as a spring delicacy. My own 21-year-old patch, a mere child in the annals of asparagus longevity, yielded 702 fat, thin and medium-size spears in 1989, 586 in 1988 and 607 in 1987. That's a lot of asparagus out of a 15-by-10-foot bed, more than the needs of my wife and me, and we gave much of it to our neighboring son. In terms of waiting, think of asparagus as an apple tree or blueberry bush. Unlike most vegetables, which you plant anew every year, asparagus is perennial. After you've first dug in the roots, they bear year after year. European chronicles tell of 100-year-old asparagus beds bestowed as dowries in marriage contracts. Asparagus thrives everywhere in the United States except areas of the Deep South and West, where winters are too mild. In my garden, 50 miles north of New York City, asparagus starts coming up in late April and yields continuously until mid-June. Then I stop cutting and let the spears grow to handsome ferns, as tall as eight feet, which feed the roots for next year's crop. One of the joys of asparagus is its early arrival. You've hardly started getting the rest of the garden ready for summer and here you are harvesting a delicious vegetable. Another plus is that the spears come up a few at a time. Thus you have prolonged harvests. Once out of the ground, a spear grows incredibly fast _ as much as 10 inches in a day. Six to eight inches is a good cutting height. After that, the spears get woody at the base. Asparagus may be grown from seed, but you save time by planting roots acquired at nurseries or seed houses. Worldwide, about 35 varieties are cultivated. In the United States, the best known are Mary and Martha Washington, introduced early this century. Recently new, all-male cultivars with names like Jersey Giant have appeared and are getting good reviews for larger yields and better disease resistance. Because of the time involved in establishing a bed, however, it wouldn't be practical for some of us to experiment with different varieties. My Martha Washington keeps producing generously. I'll leave new cultivars to new gardeners. The most work you'll probably ever do with asparagus comes at the start _ in planting the roots. In early spring, in a well-tilled, sunny spot, you dig trenches about a foot deep and a foot wide in rows about three feet apart. Pack the bottom of the trenches with well-rotted manure or compost, mounding this up, and spread the roots over the mounds about two feet apart. Then you bury the roots, leaving the crowns two to three inches below the surface. Sixteen roots should be plenty for a family of three. In this first year, you'll get some thin spears. Leave these alone, too. You can start cutting the third year, but it will be a while after that before you have a really prolific bed. In the meantime, your biggest problem will be weeds. How do you remove them without disturbing the asparagus roots? I solved this by mulching the bed with a couple of inches of salt hay, obtainable in bales from nurseries. The mulch stifles weeds, but allows spears to come through. Then it decomposes into fine compost, helping the fertility of the bed. I put on a bale a year. In the middle of June, when I stop cutting, I push the mulch aside and spread some fertilizer around the spears. Then I push the mulch back on. Except for a little dusting to deal with insects, that's all I do. The ferns die back in the fall and I wait for the cycle to begin again with that first great taste of newborn asparagus next April.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, April 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Buying a Hearing Aid
DOC.TEXT: A report from the American Association of Retired Persons has been published to help people who need a hearing aid. ``Far too many people allow a hearing loss to limit their lives,'' said AARP Executive Director Horace B. Deets. ``The purchase of a hearing aid can make a tremendous difference.'' The first step, the report says, is to visit a doctor. Hearing loss can be a symptom of a treatable problem, such as diabetes, and a hearing aid could mask that problem. Hearing aids are sold by physicians, audiologists and hearing aid dealers. And there are three kinds of hearing aids: behind-the-ear models, those that go in the ear, and those that fit in the ear canal. Prices range from $500 to $2,000. The AARP report considers the anatomy of the ear and causes of hearing loss, what to consider when seeing a specialist, questions to ask about hearing aids, and other sources of information.
For a free copy, send a postcard to Product Report: Hearing Aids (D13766), AARP Fulfillment (EE126), 1909 K St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20049.
DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Young Adults Value Ties to Grandparents
DOC.TEXT: Young adults see their grandparents as a stabilizing factor during times of family trouble, especially grandchildren from single-parent households, according to a survey of college students. ``Grandparenthood today is a very present aspect in family life, not only for young children but for young adults as well,'' Gregory E. Kennedy of Central Missouri State University reported. Kennedy surveyed 704 college students under age 23 in 1988 and found that students tended to feel closer to their mothers' parents than to their fathers' parents. They also tended to be closer to grandmothers than to grandfathers. The results were reported in the February issue of The Gerontologist, published by the Gerontological Society of America. Ten percent of those who felt closest to a grandmother identified their relationship as ``intimately close,'' while 26 percent said ``very close'' and 28 percent said ``close.'' Four percent of those who felt closest to a grandfather said their relationship was ``intimately close,'' with 15 percent saying they were ``very close'' and 21 percent saying they were ``close.'' When family background was analyzed, the survey results suggested ``single-parent and blended families experienced grandparents as being more involved and influential in their family than did students from intact families,'' the study said.
DOC.HEAD: Rising Health-Care Costs a Financial Drain on Elderly
DOC.TEXT: America's elderly are losing ground financially as rising health care costs consume ever-larger shares of their income, according to a study by the House Select Committee on Aging. The report said any advantage that the elderly may have by entering retirement with higher incomes than a decade ago will be quickly lost as health and long-term care costs absorb larger portions of their income. ``While virtually all lower- and middle-income Americans feel some pressure from these costs, the problem is acute for people whose incomes rise no faster than overall inflation,'' said committee Chairman Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif. The report found that people retiring in any given year will see health-care costs rise more than 1{ times faster than their income. Out-of-pocket health care costs rose from 12.3 percent of elderly income in 1977 to 18.2 percent in 1988, it said. ``All indications are that this trend of costs outpacing income will continue into the foreseeable future and that health costs are likely to reach 20 percent of elderly income by the early 1990s,'' the study said.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Issues Guidelines for Testing Drugs Likely to be Used by
DOC.TEXT: Elderly

The government has issued guidelines to help ensure that new drugs are adequately tested to determine their effects on older people. ``There is widespread agreement that many drugs, even those likely to be used in the elderly, have not always been extensively studied in elderly patients,'' the Food and Drug Administration said in a public notice. ``As a consequence, there has often been little information available to guide therapy in such patients.'' The agency issued ``Guideline for the Study of Drugs Likely to be used in the Elderly.'' The publicaton was welcomed by Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., who said they were overdue given growing concerns about mismedication and drug misuse among the elderly. ``The health and welfare of millions of older Americans depends on a serious commitment by the FDA to ensure that available drug therapy is safe and effective,'' Downey said.

Editors: Copies of the guidelines may be obtained by submitting a written request and two self-addressed adhesive labels to the Legislative, Professional and Consumer Affairs Branch (HFD-365), Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, Food and Drug Administration, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, Md., 20857. Comments should be submitted to the Dockets Management Branch (HFA-305), Food and Drug Administration, Room 4-62, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, Md., 20857. Requests and comments should refer to Docket No. 90D-0040.

The Bush administration accused 35 nations of erecting unfair trade barriers against U.S. products, the first step in a process that could lead to economic retaliation. The action on Friday was the latest salvo in a more aggressive campaign on the part of the administration, prodded by Congress, to find ways to reduce America's huge $109 billion annual trade deficit. Japan led the list of offenders, with 19 pages of the 216-page report devoted to its barriers against the sale of U.S. products.

A top GAF Corp. executive was sentenced to six months in prison and the company was fined $2 million for stock manipulation convictions stemming from the government's crackdown on Wall Street crime. U.S. District Judge Mary Johnson Lowe said Friday she ordered a prison term for GAF vice chairman James T. Sherwin because his conviction ``should be used as a lesson to others who may be tempted to engage in conduct such as this.''

The perjury conviction of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trading assistant Lisa Jones was upheld by a federal appeals court but her 18-month jail sentence was thrown out. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled Friday the trial judge wrongly gave her a sentence greater than the 10- to 16-month term recommended by new sentencing guidelines. The case was sent back to U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand for resentencing.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods in February bounced back 1.8 percent from their steepest dive in 16 years a month earlier but failed to regain the levels of late 1989, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Friday orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $231.6 billion in February. That figure plummeted 5.5 percent in January, the steepest drop since a 7 percent decline in December 1974, the department said in revising the January figure downward.

A former Labor Department offical chosen by President Bush to regulate the nation's savings institutions won a narrow endorsement from the Senate Banking Committee. Two Democrats joined all nine Republicans on the panel in voting 11-10 on Friday to send the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to the full Senate for confirmation as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision.

Eastern Airlines blasted rumors that the carrier faces liquidation as it tries to overcome growing skepticism about its ability to survive. ``Liquidation is not in the best interests of any group involved in the bankruptcy,'' spokesman Robin Matell said Friday. ``The unsecured creditors would wind up with little at best and maybe nothing in liquidation.'' Eastern, which last year promised to repay creditors 100 percent and then slashed that by half, said this past week it wanted to cut the 50 cents-per-dollar payback plan even further. Immediately afterward, unsecured creditors discussed a potential call for Eastern's liquidation.

Hallmark Cards Inc. sweetened the terms of its proposed buyback of $270 million in junk bonds issued by its Univision Holdings Inc. subsidiary after its first offer received a very chilly response. Under the revised offer disclosed Friday, Hallmark would pay about 49 cents on the dollar for the two series of securities, up from about 39 cents on the dollar under the initial offer that was to have expired early Friday. A financial adviser to the bondholders called the revised offers constructive and indicated the bondholders intended to review them.

A federal judge granted Motorola Inc.'s request for a stay following his ruling that the company violated a key computer chip patent and order to stop selling one of its microprocessors. The stay was granted Friday pending an appeal to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, according to the U.S. District Court clerk's office in Austin. Motorola spokesman Dan Rogers said the company sought the stay of the court's injunction against domestic marketing and sale of its 68030 microprocessor and ``is studying other legal remedies.''

A judge dismissed the suit American Continental Corp. filed against federal regulators, which accused them of hurting the survival chances of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association subsidiary by leaking confidential information. U.S. District Judge Richard M. Bilby agreed Friday to dismiss the case without prejudice, meaning it may be refiled or reopened. But Bilby added that unless American Continental took action by July 1, the claim would be dismissed with prejudice.

Stock prices closed out a sluggish first quarter of 1990 with a mixed showing Friday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 20.49 to 2,707.21. The key market indicator gained 2.93 points for the week. The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen but finished mixed against other major currencies. Bond prices lost ground. Copper futures prices jumped to life-of-contract highs; precious metals retreated; petrooleum futures advanced; and grains, soybeans, livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman Says Defense Backlog Will Protect Westinghouse
DOC.TEXT: A backlog of $5 billion in defense orders ensures the nation's cuts in military spending will have a slow impact on Westinghouse Electric Corp., the company's chief said. Prior to the recent talk of a peace dividend, Westinghouse has had a goal of reducing its reliance on defense, Chairman John C. Marous said. Management last year committed to spending $100 million internally to develop 19 defense programs that have the potential to grow into $1 billion businesses, Marous said. But Westinghouse is counting on only three of those to reach that level. Even so, Marous warned Congress must ensure spending cuts don't cripple development of technology. ``There's no question there's going to be some form of a peace dividend,'' he told Pittsburgh financial analysts Friday. ``I think the real key, though, is how they cut the defense budget because there's two pieces.'' People and bases are one piece, technology the other, Marous said. ``The technology lead this country has today rests primarily in the military and space program,'' he said. ``If we start cutting in the technology area, which politically is the easy thing to do, we're going to have problems.'' Marous said he presented his arguments on technology with Vice President Dan Quayle, who was in Pittsburgh recently. Westinghouse, the nation's 13th largest defense contractor, won't be hurt by defense cuts because it has positioned itself in programs that it believes will be spared the knife, the chairman said. Three years ago, 22 percent of the business of Westinghouse's defense systems group was non-defense. Marous set a goal of increasing that share to 50 percent by 1995 and changed the division's name to the electronic systems group to emphasize the change. Westinghouse plans to apply its defense technology to non-defense businesses in areas such as air-traffic control, Marous said. In the past month, Westinghouse won the job to develop an air traffic control system in Poland and it is bidding for the same job in Czechoslovakia, he said. In other areas, Marous said industrial and environmental services ``is probably the fastest growing business in Westinghouse,'' expanding at a rate of 30 percent a year.

DOC.HEAD: Limo Business In For a Bumpy Ride
DOC.TEXT: Corporate raiders and junk bond traders aren't the only ones to hit some rough bumps. Makers of stretch limousines, a power symbol in the status-conscious 1980s, are struggling as demand has shifted into low gear. Stretch limousine production has dropped off from the boom times during the Reagan years, when production jumped from about 2,500 limousines a year in 1980 to a peak of about 7,000 in 1987. Some 57 coach-building companies, including two in the Chicago area, now stretch only about 5,700 limousines a year, according to Limousine and Chauffeur, the industry trade magazine. Stretch limousines were an ostentatious symbol of wealth in the money decade of the 1980s. ``Some corporations were spending up to $20,000 a week on round-the-clock limo service,'' said Wayne Smith, executive director of the National Limousine Association in Washington, D.C. ``Executives were doing multibillion-dollar deals, and the limo service played a role in beefing up the company's image,'' he said. But a slower economy, troubles in the junk-bond market, the savings and loan fiasco and a slowdown in mergers and acquisitions all have contributed to cuts in corporate limousine service. Some budget-minded companies are trying to prune expensive frills. ``The ostentatious look just isn't good for the corporate image anymore,'' said Joseph V. Scaletta, president of Moloney Coachbuilders in Chicago. Sales are down about 25 percent at Moloney, which makes about 450 stretch limos a year. Scaletta attributes the drop to ``overbuilding.'' But Scaletta believes it is still possible to find other markets. ``Executives aren't going for the super-stretches anymore,'' said Scaletta. ``But now that we are adding cellular phones, fax machines and even small computers, they see the benefit of having a traveling office.'' Another Chicago-area manufacturer, Limousine Werks of Schaumburg, says it has looked to the foreign market. Company president Matthew Baines says sales are up 28 percent over last year, in part due to a recent contract to make stretch Cadillac limousines for Japan. He estimates production at about ``one a day.'' The first limousine was a Model G made in 1908 by Cadillac, said Dave John, Cadillac fleet director in Detroit. In the 1960s, as buyers increasingly demanded custom flourishes, the major auto makers stopped customizing limousines and independent companies, known as coach builders, entered the scene. These companies buy Cadillacs, Lincoln Continentals or other luxury cars as a ``coach builder package'' without a roof. Then they cut the cars in half, stretch them by 8 inches to as much as 100-plus inches and fill them with whatever luxuries customers want, from televisions and mini-bars to chandeliers and hot tubs. A Cadillac Brougham at Limousine Werks costs from $53,000 to $62,000. Mercedes go for $135,000, and armored cars start at $100,000. Changing times also have affected companies offering limousine service. The airport trade is now their bread-and-butter, so they are positioning themselves as an affordable alternative to a taxi. The airport trade accounts for 80 percent of the rides provided by the American Limousine Corp. of suburban Burr Ridge, which has a fleet of 150 cars, said owner George Jacobs, who is also president of the National Limousine Association. But Jacobs believes the limousine will always stand for luxury and romance. He recalls one young suitor who ordered two limousines when he wanted to propose to his girlfriend. ``The first car took him to the lakefront, where he proposed. The second car came to pick up the first driver so the couple could be alone for a few hours,'' said Jacobs. ``We didn't ask any questions.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in nervous trading in Europe late this morning as economic and political concerns pressured the yen, sterling and the West German mark. Gold prices fell. A 6.8 percent decline on the Tokyo stock market earlier today put the yen under renewed pressure and unsettled the world currency and equity markets, traders said. Violent protests in London over the weekend against a new per-capita tax sent sterling falling more than 2 cents against the dollar. News that Germany plans a two-for-one exchange rate between the East and West German mark undermined the West German currency. ``The dollar is largely benefiting from the weakness of the yen and Europe's problems,'' one Milan trader said. ``The dollar isn't being sold, but its not as though U.S. economic data is particularly inspiring.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 2.30 yen to a closing 159.95 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a slightly lower rate of 159.93 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.7030 West German marks, up from 1.6875; 1.5055 Swiss francs, up from 1.4935; 5.7240 French francs, up from 5.6765; 1.9160 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9008; 1,252.50 Italian lire, up from 1,243.25; and 1.1701 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1700. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.6260, compared with $1.6465 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $368.75 a troy ounce, down from $369.25 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $368. In Zurich, the bid price was $368, down from $368.75 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 2 cents to close at a bid $371.16. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.96 a troy ounce from Friday's $4.97.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Savings Insolvent, Reports Huge Losses
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Savings & Loan Association, the once-high flying thrift that invested billions of dollars in high-risk junk bonds, says it lost $379 million in the fourth quarter and $200 million during the first two months of this year and is now insolvent. The disclosure on Sunday increases the prospects for an expensive federal bailout. Columbia had been one of the nation's most profitable S&Ls due to its large portfolio of high-yielding junk bonds, many of which were bought from Michael Milken and his securities firm, the now-defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. In the mid-1980s Columbia's annual earnings approached $200 million. But the deterioration in the junk bond market over the past several months has forced Columbia to write off much its holdings, resulting in huge losses. Columbia said it lost $379 million, or $19.17 a share, in the final quarter of 1989, compared to earnings of $16 million, or 37 cents a share, in 1988. Losses for the entire year came to $591 million, or $30.11 a share, vs. net income of $65 million, or $1.49 per share, the previous year. The losses reflect junk bond-related loss provisions and write-downs of about $500 million in the fourth quarter. The company said that its shareholders' equity, or the firm's value to its stockholders, fell to minus $121 million at Feb. 28, 1990, ``rendering (Columbia) insolvent under generally accepted accounting principles.'' Just three months earlier Columbia had equity of $77.6 million. In a statement, Columbia said it expected ``significant additional loss reserves and other asset writedowns will occur in March 1990.'' It said it had a loss of nearly $200 million in the first two months of 1990 because of further problems in the junk bond market. But Columbia is hoping to avoid federal receivership by liquidating its junk bond holdings. ``We have initiated programs to reduce overhead significantly and to improve our traditional thrift operations,'' Edward G. Harshfield, the thrift's newly appointed chief exectuvie, said in a statement Sunday. Between August and February, Columbia sold about $575 million in junk bonds and other securities, according to the company. Federal regulators had imposed restrictions on Columbia in November because of problems with its $3.8 billion junk-bond portfolio had caused the thrift's capital to be ``substantially inadequate.'' The Office of Thrift Supervision restricted, among other things, Columbia's growth, dividend payment and loan funding. Lending is now limited to residential loans not exceeding $500,000. Columbia's assets for 1989 totaled $9.3 billion, down from $12.7 billion in 1988. The thrift has 950 employees in 29 Southern California offices.

Stock prices fell today as the market absorbed the jolt of another big selloff in Japan. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 18.02 to 2,689.19 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 210 up, 1,143 down and 390 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 41.39 million shares at midmorning. The Tokyo stock market took a 6.6 percent drop overnight, suffering the steepest decline yet in an early-1990 slide that has sent prices to an 18-month low. In recent weeks the decline has had few ripple effects in U.S. markets. Analysts have ascribed it to predominantly local forces in Japan, including rising interest rates and lofty price-earnings ratios. Some observers, in fact, have argued that a bad showing in Tokyo might actually serve to prop up the American market by luring money to Wall Street looking for a safe haven. But lately a good many analysts in this country have confessed to worries that continued erosion in Tokyo might sooner or later start to undermine confidence in other financial centers as well. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris dropped { to 39[; International Business Machines { to 105|; American Telephone & Telegraph { to 41{, and General Electric { to 63}. American General lost 2| to 36. Torchmark Corp. said it had withdrawn an offer to acquire the company through an exchange of cash and stock. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slumped 1.44 to 185.41. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.66 at 359.09.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 431.38 down 4.16 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks Resume as Japanese Leader Pledges Cooperation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 3-4, Bush, asked... to UPDATE with Bush quote
DOC.TEXT: High-level trade talks between Japan and the United States resumed today as Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu dispatched two personal emissaries to try to work out solutions to the huge $49 billion trade imbalance between the two nations. Kaifu called Bush to renew his pledge to seek solutions to the trade disputes that have split the two nations. He told Bush that he was sending the two emissaries to Washington ``to express the prime minister's personal commitment to solving problems,'' the White House announced. Bush, asked by reporters in Atlanta if the trade talks with Japan were in trouble, said: ``I had a very fruitful conversation with the prime minister of Japan this morning and we will see. But I must say I am encouraged by recent progress, but we'll wait and see. More to follow soon on that.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters in Atlanta that the two emissaries, former Japanese Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga and Deputy Foreign Minister Hisashi Owada, would meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. Fitzwater said the emissaries would meet with Bush on Wednesday. The discussions were being held as other U.S. and Japanese negotiators were resuming talks aimed at addressing broad-scale barriers to trade in both nations. The Bush administration is pinning its hopes on making significant reductions in the trade deficit with Japan _ which accounted for almost half of America's total trade imbalance last year _ on the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative, which take place today and Tuesday. There were reports that the Japanese were bringing a new set of concessions with them designed to open their markets to sales of American products. Over the weekend, negotiators said both sides are close to agreement on proposals to expand sales of American-made satellites to Japanese government agencies. The agreement was similar to an accord reached a week ago on the issue of supercomputer sales to Japanese universities and other government agencies. And late on Friday, U.S. and Japanese negotiators announced agreement on steps that would further open the Japanese market to American-made telecommunications products. The new pact was reached just before a Saturday deadline that could have triggered U.S. retaliation. Today's phone call between Bush and Kaifu represented a follow-up to a summit meeting held last month in California at which the two leaders searched for ways to get the stalled trade talks moving again. American negotiators expressed disappointment that three previous rounds of discussions on structural barriers produced little progress. Both sides must produce an interim report by mid-April and a final report before the seven-nation economic summit, to be held this year in Houston in July. The structural impediments discussions are just one of a set of trade negotiations currently underway with Japan. The Japanese are facing a June 16 deadline to open up markets in three specific product areas _ satellites, supercomputers and lumber _ or risk economic retaliation by the Bush administration.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks In Second-Worst Dive Ever, Dollar Surges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Wall Street activity, picks up 11th 11th graf, In London...
DOC.TEXT: The key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange took its second-largest plunge ever today as the dollar surged to a three-year high against the Japanese yen. Analysts said both markets were shaken by a report in Japan's top financial newspaper that major life insurance companies planned to shift funds out of the stock market. The drop in stock prices helped spark a decline on stock markets in New York, London and several Far Eastern cities. In its lead front-page story, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun newspaper said major insurance firms, including Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co., Nippon Life Insurance Co. and Sumitomo Mutual Life Insurance Co., planned to sell largeblocks of shares because the ratio of their stock holdings to their total assets was approaching the upper limit of 30 percent set by the Finance Ministry. The Finance Ministry and at least one insurer denied the report, which nevertheless supported market expectations that major investors would generally move out of the stock market and into bonds, said Jason James, strategist at James Capel Pacific Ltd. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues today shed 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, to 28,002.07, its second largest single-day decline ever. On Friday, it lost 1,045.71 points, or 3.37 percent, in the market's seventh largest single-day decline. Analysts said the decline in the stock market helped push the dollar higher, and the relative weakness of the yen then pushed share prices even lower. An official at Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance said the report was misleading because the company planned to buy 800 billion yen of stocks in fiscal 1990 after selling 200 billion yen's worth of shares. ``We'd reduce our holdings of shares with large losses and those we possess in excessive amount, many of which will be bank shares,'' said Kimitoshi Hasegawa, deputy vice president supervising separate account management at Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co. On Wall Street, stock prices declined broadly in response to the drop on the Japanese market. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 15.99 to 2,691.22 as of 11:30 a.m. EST. In London, analysts said the plunge in Tokyo and violent riots against a new per-capita tax sent prices sharply lower. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was 32.3 points, or 1.4 percent, lower at 2,215.6. Stock prices closed lower in Australia, Hong Kong, the Philippines, New Zealand, South Korea and Singapore, largely in reaction to the dismal Tokyo performance. In the Tokyo currency market, the dollar closed at 159.95 yen, up 2.30 yen from Friday's close of 157.65 yen. It opened at 159.97, up 2.32 yen, and ranged between 159.70 and 160.35. About 30 minutes after trading began, the dollar was trading between 160.10 yen and 160.20 yen, the first time the currency has traded in the 160-yen range since December 1986. ``People had already taken their positions by the time the report was denied, and anyway people were expecting (the shift away from stocks) to come sooner or later,'' said Kaneo Ogino of Goldman Sachs (Japan) Corp. The dollar later fell back on short-covering, Ogino said. The speed and extent of the dollar's rise took many market players by surprise, dealers said. ``Traders were looking at 160.40 yen as a medium term objective over the next few weeks. Many people were surprised when we reached the target today,'' said Mahiko Nagai, an assistant vice president of foreign exchange with Manufacturers Hanover in Tokyo. Dealers predicted volatile trading this week ahead of a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven leading industrial nations in Paris on Saturday. Concern over the outcome of U.S.-Japan talks on ending so-called structural impediments to trade could push the U.S. currency higher, they said. Officials of both countries are expected within the next two weeks to issue an interim report on the talks aimed at identifying and removing business practices and laws that contribute to the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond was at 86.02 by late afternoon, down slightly from Friday's close of 86.11. Its yield rose to 7.35 percent from the previous session's 7.330 percent.

DOC.HEAD: General Development May Seek Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. said today it was unable to reach agreement on obtaining interim credit from its lenders and was considering filing for bankruptcy protection. The Miami-based developer, which has pleaded guilty in federal court to mail-fraud conspiracy in connection with the overpricing of homes it built, has been seeking $60 million in interim credit for three weeks, but talks broke off last weekend, the company said in a news release. ``The company is considering all alternatives available to it, including seeking protection under the federal bankruptcy laws,'' the release said. Company spokesman Otis Wragg was not immediately available for further comment, a receptionist said. General Development, creator of nine Florida communities, earlier estimated it would cost about $400 million to finish developing its land, but only $102.1 million is budgeted for improvements, according to its latest annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. United Capital Corp., a minority stockholder, offered a restructuring plan involving the sales of assets and short-term operating money last week, but General Development did not respond publicly to the offer. General Development pleaded guilty last month in connection with charges it misled customers and overpriced nearly 10,000 homes. Class-action suits against the company involve 60,000 buyers.

Losers outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 246 up, 1,188 down and 408 unchanged. Here, at a glance, are highlights of business-related actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
PUNITIVE DAMAGES
The court agreed to decide whether huge punitive damage awards in lawsuits may violate constitutional guarantees of fundamental fairness. The court said it will consider overturning a $1 million award and three smaller awards to Alabama residents who successfully sued an insurance company for fraud. The case, of enormous importance to American business, is likely to be decided in 1991. The case is Pacific Mutual vs. Haslip, 89-1279.
AUTO SAFETY
The court let stand rulings that protect automobile manufacturers from design-defect lawsuits for not installing airbags. The justices, without comment, refused to revive three such suits against General Motors, one against Honda and one against Nissan. Three federal appeals courts and a California state court ruled in favor of the car makers. The cases are Wood vs. GM, 89-46; Kitts vs. GM, 89-279; Taylor vs. GM, 89-852; and Meier vs. Nissan, 89-940.
AIRLINES
The court left intact a ruling airlines say could make it more difficult for them to merge. The court, without comment, refused to shield Delta Air Lines from binding arbitration that could lead to a monetary-damages award for a flight attendants union. The case is Delta vs. Association of Flight Attendants, 89-459.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Increases By 53
DOC.TEXT: After posting the usual first-quarter declines, the number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs made a turnaround this week, increasing by 53 to total 946. The rig count climbed by a dozen or more in three states, and other areas also posted slight gains, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. This week's increase reversed the rig count's downward slide _ a traditional trend in the first three months of the year. Last week, the count dropped by 15 to 893. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. A year ago, the rig count totaled 779. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Texas had the greatest increase with 15, Oklahoma followed with 13 and Lousiana's count climbed by 12. Wyoming's count was up six, North Dakota's increased by four and Colorado and New Mexico each gained three more rigs. Ohio's count was up two and California was up by one. Michigan lost three rigs and Pennsylvania lost ten rigs.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.8 million tons during the week ending March 24, up 1 percent from the 20.5 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.9 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.5 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 3.4 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3.1 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 241.9 million tons, 6 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Farley Unit Defaults On Pepperell Loan
DOC.TEXT: A unit of Farley Inc. said today it defaulted on a $796 million bank loan related to the acquisition of West Point-Pepperell Inc. The development throws further into doubt Farley's ability to complete its $3 billion acquisition of Pepperell, a giant textile maker based in West Point, Ga. The Farley unit, West Point Acquisition Corp., also said it would be unable to make interest payments due today to bondholders on its $705 million subordinated debt. West Point Acquisition is a holding company created by Chicago-based Farley to accomplish the Pepperell buyout. West Point Acquisition said in a statement that it had not been able to make the scheduled repayment on Friday of the $796 million loan, which it used to make the tender offer for Pepperell last year. Farley officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Lower
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished lower on London's Stock Exchange Monday, shaken by Tokyo's plunge earlier in the day and by renewed domestic political concerns. But a round of last-minute buying helped prices come off their lows, dealers said. A modest comeback from opening lows on Wall Street helped steady nerves in London. ``All in all, it wasn't a bad performance,'' said a trader for a major London brokerage firm. At the London close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 26.3 points, or 1.2 percent, lower at 2,221.6. At its worst, the index showed a 36.3 point decline. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 20.6 points at 1,748.1 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 13.30 points to close at 1,202.22. Volume was 515.2 million shares, up from 453.7 million on Friday. But much of the trading was accounted for by computer-driven program trades, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Copier Concern Names Chairman of U.S. Arm
DOC.TEXT: Hishashi Kubo, credited with the 1981 marketing strategy that gave Japan's Ricoh copy machines a toehold in the U.S. market, has been named chairman of the company's American subsidiary, the company announced Monday. The West Caldwell, N.J.-based company's sales in the United States grew from $15 million in 1979 to $650 million in 1986, when Kubo moved back to the parent company's headquarters in Tokyo to become vice president of sales and marketing. The U.S. company's 1989 sales of about $1 billion ranked it fifth in the lucrative U.S. copier market behind Cannon, Xerox, Sharp and Mita, according to Dataquest, a San Jose, Calif.-based market research firm. All but Xerox are Japanese companies. Ricoh's separate consumer products division, based in Fairfield, handles the company's cameras, video recorders and other photographic equipment. Kubo replaces Keiji Endoh, who has been appointed managing director of the parent company in charge of commercial affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Families' Ability to Buy House Up in February
DOC.TEXT: An index measuring the typical American family's ability to buy a house increased in February as lower prices and rising income offset higher mortgage rates, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said its index rose to 105.1 in February, meaning that a family with a median income of $33,816 had 105.1 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $95,400. The median means half of the families earn more and half less, or that half of the houses sell for more and half for less. The index measured 108.2 in December but slipped to 104.2 in January. ``The February increase in overall affordability conditions, in part, reflects the lower-priced homes frequently available during the winter months,'' said NAR President Norman D. Flynn. ``Although the lower median home price and rise in family income last month had a favorable impact on affordability conditions, the index would have been stronger if mortgage interest rates had remained unchanged,'' he added. The median price for a house dropped $900 from January's $96,300 while median family income was up $108 from $33,708 the previous month, the realtors' group said. The income needed to qualify for a loan on the typical home dropped $192 to $32,160. The interest rate used to compute the index, however, rose from 9.7 percent in January to 10.04 percent in February, the realtors said. The association uses a composite rate reflecting both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages. The changes lowered the monthly principal and interest payment on a median-priced home by $2 to $672 in February. The payment represents 23.8 percent of the median family's income. Flynn said that while overall affordability remains favorable, entry-level buyers face difficulties. ``These individuals are at a disadvantage in that they often can't save enough money for a downpayment and lack any home equity buildup to leverage a home purchase,'' he said. Under February's affordability conditions, a family earning $20,000 would have sufficient income to qualify for a $59,300 home using a $47,400 loan. A family earning $30,000 would qualify for a $88,900 home with a $71,100 loan. The realtors said a family earning $40,000 would have sufficent income to qualify for a $118,500 home with a $94,800 loan and a family with a $50,000 income would qualify for a $148,100 home using a $118,500 loan.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Up in February
DOC.TEXT: Spending on residential, non-residential and government construction projects all increased in February, the government said Monday, helped for the second straight month by mild weather over much of the country. The Commerce Department said construction spending rose 2.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $436.5 billion. That followed a revised 2.5 percent jump in January, which first had been reported to have been a 1.8 percent gain. Spending in December, the fourth coldest on record, had slipped 0.3 percent and analysts attributed the subsequent improvement to warm temperatures. ``Warm weather certainly is helping,'' said Steven Cochran, an economist with WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``If it had been cold, we wouldn't have seen these figures, I'm sure.'' But David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association in Washington, said construction spending began to lose its seasonal benefit in March. ``We expect it to start leveling off, if not decline, because it will no longer have the seasonal boost and also because of increasing interest rates,'' Berson said. Residential construction spending rose 1.7 percent in February to a $198.5 billion annual rate after gaining 2.9 percent in January. Single-family spending was up 3.9 percent to $123.0 to $21.0 billion after a 5.5 percent decline in January. ``The weather effect was very strong in the single-family market,'' said David Seiders, chief economist with the National Association of Home Builders, ``but we expect (housing) starts to tail off in the next few months.'' ``Single-family construction has been on a brief rebound after sliding throughout most of 1989,'' Seiders added. ``We do not expect it to show a longer-term rebound over the year, though. We're looking for it to fall back again.'' Non-residential construction increased 5.5 percent to $106.4 billion after a 6.1 percent gain in January. Industrial, office and other commercial building led the advance. ``A lot of the industrial construction was on the West Coast,'' Seiders said, ``not smokestack stuff, but high-tech facilities. Office building is basically still on a downswing despite its February gain. The government sector, which often is volatile, more than offset its 2.0 percent January decline, rising 2.1 percent in February to $493.8 billion. Schools and other public buildings and highways and streets were the biggest gainers. The total construction spending figure was up 4.8 percent from the level of building a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Manufacturing Decline Eases In March
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. industrial sector remained weak in March but declined at its slowest rate since June, a possible indication that the overall economy may be poised for a pickup, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers released Monday. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks economic trends by polling its members, said its overall index rose to 48.8 percent in March from 48.3 percent the previous month. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is declining; above 50, that it generally is expanding. The March index represented the 11th consecutive monthly decline but was at its highest level since June's 48.8 percent reading, due to an increase in production and new export orders, the Tempe, Ariz.-based trade group said in its report. With the exception of January, the purchasing managers' index has risen gradually every month since November, leading some economists to speculate the economy may have bottomed out. ``It's not so much the economy is getting strong but somewhat steadier,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief financial economist for Nikko Securities Co. International. ``The report raises speculation that the ... worst of the declining phase is behind us. The question remains how strong and sustainable the statistical rebound is.'' Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee, said the slight increase in the index ``may be signaling a leveling-off in the 11-month decline in the economy.'' ``The continued easing in the pace of the economic decline as we exit the first quarter is encouraging,'' said Bretz, who also is director of materials management at Stamford, Conn.-based Pitney Bowes Inc. ``Although we may be forming a bottom, caution should be exercised, since the first robin never makes it a spring.'' Maury Harris, chief economist for PaineWebber Inc., said that although manufacturing makes up a large portion of the nation's gross national product, there are other areas that remain sluggish. ``The construction industry is getting ready to tumble,'' he said. A report released Monday by the Commerce Department said construction spending rose 2.6 percent in February, compared with a revised 2.5 percent gain in January. Harris attributed the increase solely to unusually warm weather across much of the nation and said the industry's overall fundamentals were poor. The production portion of the purchasing managers' survey increased for the second consecutive month during March. It rose to an 11-month high of 54.4 percent from 51.5 percent in February. New orders grew slightly in March but at a slower pace than in February, when they increased for the first time since mid-1989. The new orders index stood at 50.4 percent, down from 51.8 percent. New export orders also rose, the group said. The seasonally unadjusted new export orders index was 59.5 percent, up from 53.0 percent and the highest level since September 1989. Imports increased for the third consecutive month. The number of members importing in March inched up to 78 percent from 77 percent, the group said. But the employment portion of the survey declined for the 13th consecutive month, with the index falling to 45.2 percent from 46.7 percent. Members continued to report layoffs, hiring freezes and early retirement programs to reduce employment. Supplier deliveries were faster for the 11th consecutive month, the group said. Most commodities were in supply, with the exception of bearings, electric motors and some chemicals, it said. Meanwhile, prices of goods fell for the 10th consecutive month, although the pace of decline was lower than in February. The purchasing managers' report is based on a monthly survey of purchasing executives at over 300 industrial companies. Most of the figures are adjusted for seasonal factors.

DOC.HEAD: Fleet Reports $200 Million Increase in Bad Loans
DOC.TEXT: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group said Monday it expects its non-performing loans to increase by at least $200 million in the first quarter, making it the latest bank to be hit by New England's sagging economy. The company said its level of non-performing loans would reach at least $600 million and could go higher as a result of an examination now being conducted by federal regulators. ``We have not estimated what the reserve might be or what the earnings might be,'' said Robert W. Lougee Jr., a Fleet spokesman. He said the company's first-quarter earnings report could be delayed past the April 18 annual meeting, depending on the outcome of the examination. Fleet also said it would sell about half of its credit card portfolio of about $500 million to Norwest Corp. of Minneapolis. The sale and a change in investments for the corporation's pension plan is expected to produce a one-time gain of $90 million before taxes for the first quarter, Fleet said. A $600 million level of non-performing loans would amount to about 2.6 percent of Fleet's loan and lease portfolio of about $22.5 billion. That still is lower than the industry average of about 3 percent, Lougee said. The bad loans had been identified ``largely on our own'' and not at the insistence of federal regulators, Lougee said, although ``we're clearly aware the regulators are here.'' Fleet has been praised for its diversification, with almost two-thirds of its assets outside of New England, and for steering clear of much of the overbuilt condominium market, which rapidly collapsed during the past year. But, ``other segments of commercial real estate have clearly been affected,'' Lougee said, including office parks and small shopping centers. The bad loans ``are spread out in the commercial real estate portfolio,'' he said. According to Fleet's first-quarter filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, about $8.4 billion of its loan portfolio is in commercial and industrial loans and loans to other financial institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Plunge Following Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed sharply lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late selloff rooted in a government crop report and spurred on by bearish technical market factors. Corn and oat futures finished moderately higher while wheat futures closed mixed. Friday's annual Agriculture Department report on spring planting intentions indicated U.S. farmers plan to increase corn acreage by about 3.5 percent this year while decreasing soybean acreage by 2 percent and spring wheat acreage by 4 percent from last year's levels. The market had expected the report to project a larger increase in corn plantings, a bigger drop in soybean acreage and a smaller decline in spring wheat seedings. Session-long weakness in the soybean market stemmed from the report and from signs of an increase in Brazilian soybean harvesting and exports, said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. But she said the market crumbled late in the session when ``we broke some (technical) chart points and that started the technically inspired selling.'' At the close of trading, wheat futures were 2 cents lower to 4 cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.55} a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4 cents higher with May at $2.63} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $1.51\ a bushel; soybeans were 9 cents to 12{ cents lower with May at $5.86 a bushel.
