DOC.HEAD: Junk Bonds Cause $836 Million Quarterly Loss at First Executive
DOC.TEXT: First Executive Corp. said Monday that the plummeting value of its junk-bond portfolio had caused an $836 million loss in its final quarter and a $776 million loss for the year. The insurance holding company, whose subsidiaries include Executive Life Insurance Co. of Los Angeles, announced in January that it anticipated an after-tax charge of $515 million to 1989 earnings due to junk bond losses. It said Monday they were so bad it had added another $344 million. The huge writeoffs caused revenue to plunge 44 percent for the year and left third-quarter revenue more than a half-billion dollars in the red. Los Angeles-based First Executive became the second Southern California institution in as many days to be buried beneath an avalanche of losses from uninsured junk bonds, which pay high rates because they fund risky ventures. On Sunday, Columbia Savings & Loan Association reported losses of $575 million in a five-month period due to junk bonds, rendering it insolvent and in danger of seizure by federal regulators. Both First Executive and Columbia were closely allied with Michael Milken, the financier who pioneered the use of junk bonds in the 1980s while working for brokerage Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. First Executive invested about $6.5 billion in junk bonds. It said that as of Dec. 31, when its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended, the value of that portfolio had fallen to about $1.4 billion below face value. For the fourth quarter, First Executive's $836 million loss, the equivalent of $9.98 a share, compared with a profit of $48 million, or 42 cents a share, in 1988. Revenue plunged far into red ink: from $552 million in 1988 to a negative $541 million in 1989. For the year, First Executive's $776 million loss was the equivalent of $9.67 a share and came on revenue of $1.19 billion. That compared with a profit of $175 million, $1.51 a share, on revenue of $2.14 billion in 1988. First Executive said its assets at the end of the year were about $19.2 billion and shareholders' equity more than $1 billion. Life insurance in force was about $59.7 billion compared with $57.3 billion last year. The company strove to reassure policyholders with its various subsidiaries. ``Executive Life Insurance Co. ... Executive Life Insurance Co. of New York, and other insurance subsidiaries are all strongly capitalized and generating strong statutory earnings,'' said Alan Snyder, the president.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rose Monday amid strong buying of oil products. Market analysts said activity was light to moderate on the New York Mercantile Exchange with much of the buying interest focused on contracts for delivery later than May, the near-month contract. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline finished up 0.72 cent at 66.08 cents a gallon after adding 0.25 cent on Friday. The April contract expired Friday at 59.93 cents a gallon, up 2.26 cents. The June, July and August unleaded gas contracts posted gains ranging from 0.80 cent to 1.01 cents. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.93 to 55.27 cents a gallon following Friday's increase of 0.56 cent. The expired April contract had ended with a gain of 0.85 cent at 57.02 cents a gallon on Friday. No. 2 heating oil contracts for June, July and August delivery rose by 1.32 cents to 1.38 cents. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, advanced 20 cents to $20.48 per 42-gallon barrel, adding to Friday's gain of 25 cents. Later contract months rose by similar to slightly larger amounts. Richard Redoglia, a vice president at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said there weren't any new fundamental developments to account for the buying. He said there was still speculation in the market that future reports will show substantial drawdowns in gasoline stocks, indicated rising demand.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Lower
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly higher Monday against other major foreign currencies despite a wave of profit-taking. Gold prices declined here and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.80 a troy ounce, off 40 cents from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $370.25 an ounce, unchanged. The dollar started out sharply higher on weakness in the Japanese yen, the British pound and the West German mark, dealers said. But they said traders hoping to cash in on its recent rise pushed the dollar off its highs. ``Maybe the dollar has gone up too far, too fast,'' said Robert Ryan, a senior trader for Bank of New York. Another dealer from Europe said, ``There are some people that think the move (against the yen) was overdone. Now, there's talk the Group of Seven will get a rescue package together this weekend for the yen.'' The finance ministers of the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy, and Canada are scheduled to meet in Paris on April 7. A 6.8 percent fall on the Tokyo stock market earlier Monday put the yen under renewed pressure. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 2.30 yen to a closing 159.95 yen. It was quoted at 159.18 yen in London, and at 158.65 yen in New York, up from 158.35 yen Friday. Earl I. Johnson, a trader for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the dollar flirted with the 160-yen level in the United States before falling back. The last time the dollar traded at around that level was in December 1986, he said. Meanwhile, sterling was hurt by concern about recent violent riots in London over Britain's new poll tax. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6300 from $1.6465 late Friday. In New York, sterling fell to $1.6390 from $1.6455. The dollar also rose against the West German mark following reports that the East German central bank won't accept an exchange rate of one West German mark for two East German marks as part of a reunification plan. Late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Friday, included: 1.6985 West German marks, up from 1.6940; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4982; 5.7105 French francs, up from 5.7020; 1,249.25 Italian lire, up from 1,248.75; and 1.16785 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16945. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with rates late Friday were: 1.7052 West German marks, up from 1.6875; 1.5068 Swiss francs, up from 1.4935; 5.7300 French francs, up from 5.6765; 1.9193 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9008; 1,254.25 Italian lire, up from 1,243.25; and 1.1690 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1700. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $368.95 an ounce, down from $369.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold was unchanged at $368.75 an ounce. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 2 cents to close at a bid of $371.16 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.946 a troy ounce, up from $4.945 late Friday. Silver fell in London to $4.96 an ounce from $4.97.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a broad loss in light trading Monday following the news of another big selloff in Japan. Most of the drop in New York came in the early moments of the session, after which prices staged a partial recovery. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 30 points at the outset, closed with a 6.76-point loss at 2,700.45. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 434 up, 1,122 down and 433 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 124.36 million shares, down from 139.34 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 144.56 million shares. The Tokyo stock market took a 6.6 percent drop overnight, suffering the steepest decline yet in an early-1990 slide that has sent prices to an 18-month low. In recent weeks the decline has had few ripple effects in U.S. markets. Analysts have ascribed it to predominantly local forces in Japan, including rising interest rates and lofty price-earnings ratios. Some observers, in fact, have argued that a bad showing in Tokyo might actually serve to prop up the American market by luring money to Wall Street looking for a safe haven. But lately a good many analysts in this country have confessed to worries that continued erosion in Tokyo might sooner or later undermine confidence in other financial centers as well. Network Equipment Technologies suffered one of the day's biggest percentage losses, falling 6] to 23{. The company said its revenues and earnings for the fiscal quarter that ended Saturday were likely to come in significantly below expectations. American General lost 1~ to 36}. Torchmark Corp. said it had withdrawn an offer to acquire the company through an exchange of cash and stock. General Development tumbled 1~ to 4. The company said it hadn't been able to reach a new credit arrangement with its lenders and might seek protection under the federal bankruptcy code. Among actively traded blue chips, General Motors dropped ] to 45{; International Business Machines \ to 105~; American Telephone & Telegraph ] to 41|; Philip Morris [ to 39{, and General Electric \ to 64. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gave up $15.01 billion, or 0.46 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .77 to 186.08. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.34 to 392.84, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.24 at 338.70. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 2.36 to 433.18. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.37, down 2.38.

DOC.BYLINE: Pork Futures Soar On Supply Outlook ^By DAVID DISHNEAU
DOC.TEXT: Most pork futures prices rose their permitted daily limits Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange following a government report that indicated 1990 hog production will continue to lag behind last year's. On other commodity markets, cattle futures advanced; soybean futures fell sharply while grains were mixed; oil futures gained; and precious metals retreated slightly. Live hog futures settled .87 cent to the limit 1.5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in April up .87 cent at 54.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.98 cents to the limit 2 cents higher with May at 55.57 cents a pound. In cattle trading, live cattle were .38 cent to .73 cent higher with April at 78.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent to .48 cent higher with April at 82.62 cents a pound. Analysts said the strong rally in pork futures was rooted in the Agriculture Department's hogs-and-pigs inventory, a quarterly tally of the nation's hog herd. Released Friday after trading ended, the report said the hog herd as of March 1 was 4 percent smaller than on the same date a year earlier. The market had expected a decline of closer to 2.6 percent. The government's estimate of the number of animals kept by producers for breeding purposes during the December-February quarter was also below market expectations. The report suggested pork producers remain cautious about expanding their herds despite higher hog prices, and that the 1990 U.S. hog herd will remain smaller than last year's all year long. ``Whether you choose to believe that or not is another question but that's what the report said,'' said Chuck Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The heaviest buying of pork futures occurred in contracts for delivery next fall and winter. Buying interest spread to the near-month contracts as the back-month contracts reached their daily limits. Tom Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp., said the market might stage a partial retreat after the sudden runup. But he said the bullish attitudes that have driven hog prices steadily higher since early February remain in place. ``There's a large group of people out there who think we're going to see $60 (per hundredweight) hogs this summer and maybe this report gave them the confidence to push their positions,'' he said. Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late selloff rooted in a government crop report and spurred on by bearish technical market factors. Grain futures ended mixed. Friday's annual Agriculture Department report on spring planting intentions indicated U.S. farmers plan to increase corn acreage by about 3.5 percent this year while decreasing soybean acreage by 2 percent and spring wheat acreage by 4 percent from last year's levels. The market had expected the report to project a larger increase in corn plantings, a bigger drop in soybean acreage and a smaller decline in spring wheat seedings. Wheat futures settled 2 cents lower to 4 cents higher with May at $3.55} a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 4 cents higher with May at $2.63{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $1.51\ a bushel; soybeans were 9{ cents to 12 cents lower with May at $5.85 a bushel. Energy futures prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid strong buying on expectations that Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report will show substantial drawdowns in gasoline stocks, indicating rising demand. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 19 cents to 30 cents higher with May at $20.48 a barrel; heating oil was .93 cent to 1.38 cent higher with May at 55.27 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .70 cent to 1.01 cents higher with May at 66.08 cents a gallon. Gold futures edged lower while silver futures were barely changed on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold futures settled 40 cents to 70 cents lower with April at $369.80 a troy ounce; silver was 0.2 cent lower to 0.6 cent higher with April at $4.946 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Dreyer's Introduces Cholesterol-Free, Low-Fat Frozen Dessert
DOC.TEXT: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. said Monday it has developed a cholesterol-free frozen dessert that it touts as tasing like premium ice cream but having only a fraction of the fat and one-third fewer calories. The product, called American Dream, contains less than 1 percent fat and 80 calories per three-ounce serving, the Oakland, Calif.-based food company said. That compares with 16 percent fat, 30 milligrams of cholesterol and 120 calories in three ounces of typical premium ice cream, the company said. Dreyer's said it was able to reduce the fat and eliminate cholesterol in American Dream through a proprietary technology that concentrates protein and ``enables us to use all the same dairy ingredients found in ice cream.'' That distinguishes it from Monsanto Co.'s Simple Pleasures, a recently introduced, frozen dessert that uses the fat substitute Simplesse, which is made from egg whites and milk protein. T. Gary Rogers, chairman and chief executive of Dreyer's, said in a telephone interview that American Dream should attract people who have been avoiding ice cream because of its fat and cholesterol content. He said it will also enable ice cream eaters to consume more of this type of dessert without worrying about cholesterol, which is believed to contribute to heart and arterial diseases. In national over-the-counter trading, Dreyer's rose 25 cents a share to $32.75. Rogers said Dreyer's has used its protein concentration process for its light frozen dessert and yogurt products. He said that although the process is not patented, others have been unable to duplicate it. Joseph Arsenio, an analyst who follows Dreyer's for the investment firm Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, said his firm was enthusiastic about the new product. ``It should appeal to an audience that is very cholesterol as well as fat conscious,'' he said. The company plans to sell the dessert in nine flavors and make it available in quarts and half gallons rather than the pint sizes used for superpremium ice creams. It will be priced comparably with premium ice cream, or about $2.30 for a quart and $4 for a half-gallon, the company said. American Dream should reach stores within six to eight weeks, Rogers said. Dreyer's said it is the nation's third-largest ice cream and frozen dessert maker with sales of $227 million in 1989. Industrywide sales amounted to $9.3 billion last year, according to the International Ice Cream Association trade group. Dreyer's makes and distributes its premium ice cream under the name Dreyer's Grand in the West and Edy's Grand east of the Rockies. It also makes Grand Light, a frozen dessert with 7 percent fat, and Frozen Yogurt Inspirations, with 3 pecent fat. Rogers said Dreyer's will spend $24 million marketing all of its products this year, up from $18 million in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Torchmark Withdraws $6.4 Billion Bid For American General
With AM-Farley-Pepperell, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Torchmark Corp. withdrew a $6.4 billion bid for American General Corp. Monday, a week after proposing the buyout, choosing instead to work to elect its own nominees to American General's board of directors. The Birmingham, Ala.-based insurance and financial services company said it decided to withdraw the offer for the much larger American General because it never received a response to its proposal. Torchmark had sent a letter informing American General of the offer last March 26, saying the Houston-based insurance and financial services company had two days to give an answer. ``Since no response was forthcoming, the proposal was withdrawn,'' Torchmark said Monday, adding that American General had refused to meet to discuss the bid. American General has only said it was reviewing the bid and that directors would discuss it at their next regular meeting May 2, the day of the company's annual shareholders meeting. Torchmark had proposed to buy about half of American General's 126.7 million outstanding shares of common stock for $50 a share, and to exchange $50 worth of Torchmark common stock for each of the remaining shares. The company had said the offer was negotiable. But Torchmark also said it would propose a slate of five independent nominees for the American General board at the May 2 meeting. Three board members are up for re-election and three seats are up for election. ``Independent nominees, when elected, will be committed to independently assessing whether or not a business combination of American General would be in the shareholders' best interest,'' Torchmark said in a statement Monday. American General issued a statement saying it has rejected Torchmark's attempt to propose its own slate of directors because it was past the company's March 3 deadline for nominations. American General has filed a lawsuit in federal court asking a judge to uphold its bylaws and prohibit Torchmark from soliciting proxies in an effort to elect its own slate of directors. A hearing date on the lawsuit has not been set. Torchmark also said it would propose a resolution at the meeting calling on the board to appoint a committee of independent directors to evaluate all acquisition proposals and to hire an investment banking firm to solicit offers. ``We made a generous proposal to consolidate with American General at a 59 percent premium over market price for American General shareholders,'' Torchmark President John T. Rotenstreich said Monday. ``American General said that its board would not consider our proposal until after its annual meeting on May 2, so the annual meeting has become a referendum on whether shareholders want the board to seriously consider proposals like ours,'' he said. He said Torchmark intends to make another proposal only if shareholders express support for a merger by electing the independent nominees or voting in favor of the resolution. At the end of 1989, American General's total assets were $32.1 billion and common shareholders' equity was $4.1 billion. Torchmark reported total assets as of Dec. 31 of $4.9 billion and common shareholders' equity of $795 million.

DOC.HEAD: Takes Out Ad to Sell What's Left of Corp. Finance, Junk Bond Business
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert, the junk-bond giant that crumpled under its own debt, is peddling the remnants of what once were the company's crown jewels with a garage sale that includes client lists and computer gear. ``For Sale,'' reads the top of the two-column advertisements for publication Tuesday in the Wall Street Journal. ``Data, software, and files from our Corporate Finance and High Yield Bond Departments.'' The partial listing includes names, addresses and titles of clients and prospective clients covering approximately 4,000 companies. Also offered are databases on all of Drexel's public offerings since 1970 and about 3,800 publicly disclosed merger transactions since 1983. In addition, the ad states, Drexel is selling a complete ``High Yield Bond System,'' described as a package of computer hardware and software designed to ``provide timely, accurate, comprehensive information on high-yield securities.'' Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said prices of the items would be negotiated and the firm already has received what he called ``indications of interest.'' He didn't identify prospective buyers. ``This is just part of our orderly disposal,'' he said. ``There's no timing involved. The sooner the better.'' Once one of Wall Street's most powerful and profitable firms, Drexel sought bankruptcy protection Feb. 13 after it defaulted on its short-term debt and failed to get more financing. Part of Drexel's demise stemmed from a steep decline in the $200 billion market for high-yield, high-risk junk bonds, which it pioneered and dominated through the 1980s. Its problems were aggravated by a loss of confidence among lenders and the resultant effects of the firm's record guilty plea to securities fraud, which brought in fines and restitution totaling about $650 million. Under an agreement between the company and creditors, three Drexel board members are supervising the firm's liquidation with input from creditors.

DOC.HEAD: K-III Holdings Buys Two Trade Magazines
DOC.TEXT: The publishing concern K-III Holdings LP said Monday it had acquired two monthly trade magazines, Electrical Transmission & Distribution and Electrical Systems Design, from Andrews Communications Inc. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. K-III Holdings, which was formed 13 months ago by several former executives of the publisher Macmillan Inc. and the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., made the purchase through its Intertec Publishing Corp., which produces trade magazines and technical books and is based in Overland Park, Kan. Electrical Transmission & Distribution has a monthly circulation of 37,000 while Electrical Systems Design has a circulation of 16,800. In addition to Intertec, K-III owns Macmillan Books Clubs Inc., which operates professional book clubs, and K-III Press Inc., which publishes information for the transportation industry. Andrews Communications is based in Edgemont, Pa., and publishes newsletters for the legal industry.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Company Reports First-Quarter Earnings Slip
DOC.TEXT: CSX Corp. on Monday reported its first-quarter earnings slipped marginally, as a one-time gain from the sale of its natural gas processing operation was offset by increased expenses and a restructuring program. The railroad and natural resources company reported a profit of $77 million, or 76 cents a share, compared with earnings of $82 million, or 74 cents a share, during the same period last year. During the quarter, CSX sold its CSX Energy Corp. to Enron Corp., resulting in an after-tax gain of $52 million. The gain was partially offset by a $33 million after-tax expense from the restructuring of Sea-Land Service Inc., CSX's container-shipping subsidiary. According to CSX, rail operating income declined to $155 million from $158 million a year ago despite increased revenue, which rose $23 million to $1.3 billion from the first three months of 1989. Strong coal, grain and fertilizer traffic more than offset weaknesses in the automotive and metals sectors, which dropped 24 percent and 7 percent respectively, CSX said. But rising diesel fuel prices helped boost rail expenses by $26 million to $1.1 billon. Also contributing to the higher rail expenses were an expanded locomotive repair program and costs associated with flooding in the South.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Union Approves Temporary Agreement with Eastern
DOC.TEXT: The Eastern Airlines pilots union voted heavily in favor of a temporary contract that makes steep concessions, the union said Monday. ``It was an overwhelming approval,'' said Dan Ashby, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. He said final figures hadn't been tallied for the secret weekend balloting at union offices in six cities. The six-month agreement, retroactive to March 1, gives working union pilots 25 percent pay cuts, increased health insurance contributions, continuation of increased work hours imposed because of the unions' strike, and reduces Eastern's contributions to the employees' retirement funds. The concessions were part of Eastern's plan for emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The airline faces mounting skepticism from unsecured creditors, who last week discussed calling for liquidation after Eastern said it couldn't repay them 50 cents on the dollar as agreed earlier. ``Once again, the Eastern pilots are offering to help,'' Ashby said. ``This vote by no means says there is labor peace on the property. We are very concerned about the future.'' The two sides are in federally mediated talks on a permanent agreement. The pilots say they're willing to make concessions, but Eastern management must commit to hire more pilots back and to making Miami-based Eastern viable. ``This (concessionary agreement) will not save Eastern Airlines. It's just a drop in the bucket,'' Ashby said. Eastern has some 1,800 pilots, more than half hired after the pilots union walked out March 4, 1989, in sympathy with the striking Machinists union. The Machinists remain on strike, while the pilots and flight attendants called their strikes off last November. Eastern has been slow to return strikers to work, saying it has no openings. The newly hired pilots, whose jobs are under court challenge from the pilots union, won't have their salaries cut under the temporary agreement. The union would like Eastern to hire back 1,500 more union pilots. Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said the airline hadn't been informed by the union of its vote. ``We still have a long way to go on reaching a permanent agreement,'' Ms. Ceremsak said. ``Right now, there are no more talks scheduled and we're waiting to hear from the National Mediation Board.'' Separately Monday, Eastern and Delta Air Lines said they settled claims relating to normal business and ticketing transactions prior to Eastern's bankruptcy filing on March 9, 1989. Eastern agreed to pay $16.8 million in cash, plus interest, to Atlanta-based Delta. As a result, Eastern and Delta will renew their cooperative ticketing and baggage agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Announce February Operating Results
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. on Monday reported a combined operating loss of $45.7 million in February and said that was an improvement over results for late January, after they filed for bankruptcy protection. ``We view February results as reflecting the stabilization of our department store operations in the post-filing period,'' spokeswoman Carol Sanger said in a statement. The Cincinnati-based companies filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors under the federal Bankruptcy Code on Jan. 15. Federated lost $29.8 million in February and Allied lost $15.8 million. The sister companies, owned by Toronto-based Campeau Corp., together operate 260 stores and employ 100,000 people in 28 states. The latest results showed increased sales of apparel, shoes, fashion and home accessories, the companies said. Sales of electronic goods and furniture lagged, however, partly because of some inventory shortfalls and resulting delays of promotions, they said. End-of-month inventories were similar to those of a year earlier, the companies said. Vendors' supplies of merchandise to Federated and Allied have nearly returned to normal levels, the companies said. The results were made available to U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern, whose office is assisting U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. in overseeing the companies' operations during bankruptcy reorganization. The companies on Jan. 15 listed debts totaling $7.7 billion, mainly acquired in Campeau's purchases of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Manville Fund Makes Initial Payments
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Clarifies throughout that trust made the announcement sted Manville Corp.
DOC.TEXT: The Manville Property Damage Settlement Trust has completed a review of 14,000 claims for asbestos exposure and has paid $68 million to some of the claimants, the trust announced Monday. The trust, based in White Plains, N.Y., said in a news statement it also has set aside $28 million for settling other claims, and expects an additional $200 million to be available for distribution over the next three years. The trust was established in 1988 as part of a reorganization of Denver-bsaed Manville Corp. by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York. More than 3,000 claimants have submitted claims so far, and the largest 50 will receive over 25 percent of the money. The largest 200 claimants will receive over 45 percent, according to the trust. Of the $1.3 billion claimed, no more than $280 million or 21 percent can be reimbursed. The fund was established to resolve millions of dollars in damage claims against Manville stemming from its days as the nation's largest asbestos producer. The company was forced to file for protection from creditors in 1982 as a result of asbestos-related lawsuits. It emerged from that protection in 1988. Among the largest claimants, seeking more than $2 million, are the city of New York, United States Steel Corp., the state of Massachusetts, the state of Illinois, the state of New York, and the state of Texas. Kurt H. Schaffir, the trust's executive director, said the trust is limited on how much of the final settlement on any claim can be paid, and how much of this can be distributed at any point in time. Reimbursements are limited to fixed percentages for different categories, but trust officials say people should still continue to file if they think they have a claim. ``The rate at which claims are being received has tapered off considerably, and it is quite possible that sufficient funds will be available over the next three years to pay half or more of the maximum payable amounts. We believe that it continues to be very much worthwhile for eligible claimants to file new claims,'' Schaffir said. Manville, founded in 1858, makes building products and packaging materials.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Ask for Speedy Vote on S&L Nominee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, bgng, ``Mr. Ryan xxx to include more comment from Warner; SUBS 11th graf pvs, bgng: Senate Majority xxx to UPDATE with Mitchell saying vote could come on Wednesday; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole predicted Monday that T. Timothy Ryan Jr. will be approved by the Senate despite Ryan's acknowledgement that he used marijuana and cocaine in the 1970s. ``In my view, the nominee will be confirmed,'' the Kansas senator said as Republicans pushed for a quick Senate floor vote. ``The question will be on whether he has the experience.'' Dole asked for a vote this week on the nomination of Ryan, a former solicitor in the Labor Department who is President Bush's choice to head the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Dole and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady huddled over the weekend on how to minimize the damage from the disclosure Friday that Ryan had acknowledged to the FBI and Bush administration officials that in the 1970s he had used marijuana occasionally and had tried cocaine ``once, perhaps twice.'' Ryan, 44, survived a 11-10 confirmation vote in the Senate Banking Committee Thursday. That vote came after he acknowledged during hearings that he has little experience with banking or thrifts. On Monday night, Sen. John Warner, R-Va., rose on the floor of the Senate to defend Ryan, saying he had known the lawyer for several years and had confidence in Ryan's integrity. ``I don't think there's any question of the man's honesty or of his effectiveness,'' Warner said, noting that Ryan brought the past drug use to the attention of investigators conducting a background check on him. ``Mr. Ryan, when approached by the president's staff, disclosed certain facts, which now have been brought out in the press,'' Warner said. He said the nominee ``was up front, and in an honest way he gave all that information to the FBI.'' Warner said Ryan made a mistake in trying drugs, but his error should be placed in the context of the Vietnam War generation. ``No matter how serious the mistake was, it seems to me that that generation was subjected to a most unusual period of history,'' Warner said. Each person should be judged individually, Warner said, adding that Ryan was never tempted to use drugs after ``that limited experience.'' Warner said members of the Banking Committee had access to the FBI background report, including the detailing of past drug use by Ryan's own admission, and still voted to favorably recommend his confirmation. Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., had said last Friday, ``Mr. Ryan clearly lacks the necessary professional qualifications for what is the single most complex and important financial job in our country today. Hundreds of billions of dollars are at stake.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, would not venture an opinion Monday on ``how the substance abuse issue will affect the vote.'' The vote on the nomination could come as early as Wednesday, he said. ``That's a matter for each senator,'' Mitchell said. ``I think there is widespread concern about the thoroughness of his qualifications for such an important job.'' Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill. and chairman of the House Banking Committee's financial institutions subcommittee, questioned how Bush could nominate an acknowledged former drug user. ``The man admitted he was on cocaine; he admitted he was on marijuana,'' Annunzio said. ``What's that say to children you're telling to `just say no'? He sure puts a crimp on the war on drugs.'' The 21-member Senate Banking Committee had access to the FBI files but Ryan's drug use was not raised during his confirmation hearings. After the disclosure by NBC News Friday night, Riegle condemned the release of the FBI material as improper and Brady said Ryan's drug ``incidents were limited and a long time ago.'' The White House also defended Ryan, with spokesman Marlin Fitzwater saying, ``We knew about it beforehand; we felt it was not relevant.''

DOC.HEAD: Institutional Selloff Speculation Triggers Second-Worst Tokyo Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with index down 77 points for morning session.
DOC.TEXT: The shell-shocked Tokyo Stock Exchange was hammered again Monday as speculation that major institutional investors were getting ready to dump stocks triggered the market's second-worst decline ever. The yen also tumbled against the dollar, worsening the stock market selloff in a violent twin reaction to an unconfirmed news report that major life insurers planned to shift funds out of the stock market. The bellwether Nikkei Stock Average of 225 issues dropped 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, to 28,002.07. The plunge was second only to the Oct. 20, 1987, drop that followed Wall Street's ``Black Monday'' crash and saw the Nikkei fall 3,836.48 points, or 14.9 percent. The index rebounded more than 400 points early Tuesday morning but quickly resumed its slump and finished the morning session down 77.19 points, or 0.28 percent, at 27,924.88. The influential financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported Monday that major insurance firms, including Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co., Nippon Life Insurance Co., and Sumitomo Mutual Life Insurance Co., planned to sell large blocks of shares. The newspaper said the sales were required because the ratio of the insurors' stock holdings to total assets was approaching government regulatory limits. Dai-Ichi told a mid-day news conference that it would continue to buy stocks during its current fiscal year, but the report already had shaken the markets. ``The big life insurers are the market's most conservative, long-term and richest investors. The report saying massive selling was likely scared off potential buyers,'' said Christopher Leighton, manager of international sales at Schroder Securities (Japan) Ltd. Although Finance Ministry officials and Dai-Ichi denied the report, it reaffirmed market expectations of a general shift by major investors out of the stock market, said Jason James, strategist at James Capel Pacific Ltd. The initial price declines snowballed amid rapid brokerage selling for individuals who needed cash to meet margin calls and on profit-taking by investors high-priced electrical company shares, traders said. Also weakening the stock market was the continued decline of the yen, which is seen as worsening inflation prospects and chasing Japanese investment funds to ovrseas markets. The dollar finished at 159.95 yen in Tokyo, up 2.30 yen from Friday's close, and at one point traded above 160 yen for the first time since December. 1986. Later in London, the dollar traded at 159.18 yen and in New York the dollar was quoted at 158.65 yen in late trading. The dollar opened Tuesday morning in Tokyo at 159.10 yen. Overseas markets also were rattled by Tokyo's decline, which followed a 3.37 percent drop in the Nikkei average during Friday's session. Stocks fell sharply on London's Stock Exchange, where investors also were concerned about political turmoil related to a new tax. However, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rebounded from its lows to finish 26.3 points lower at 2,221.6. On Wall Street, stocks declined broadly but finished above their lows. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down more than 20 points at one time, finished off 6.76 at 2,700.45. In the broader market, about five stocks fell for every two that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. Market-watchers predicted further weakness in coming days for the Tokyo stock market, partly because of expectations that the yen would weaken further. Dealers predicted currency trading would be volatile ahead of the April 7 meeting of finance ministers and central bankers of the Group of SEven industrial nations. Concern over the outcome of U.S.-Japan trade talks in Washington also could push the dollar higher, analysts said. Officials of both countries are expected within the next two weeks to issue an interim report on the talks, which are aimed at solving the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two nations.

DOC.HEAD: General Development Skips Tax Payments; Considering Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment.
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped General Development Corp. has skipped more than $10 million in property tax payments and is considering filing for bankruptcy protection, the company said Monday. Property tax payments on the nine Florida communities built by the indicted developer had to be postmarked by Sunday, but none were sent, said company spokesman Otis Wragg. ``There are some other payments that are due,'' he said. ``There are of course some grace periods that are involved, but I can't give you a list of them.'' The Miami-based developer pleaded guilty last month in federal court to mail-fraud conspiracy for overpricing homes by the thousands and deceiving the buyers about their true values. General Development has been seeking $60 million in interim credit for three weeks, but talks broke off last weekend without agreement, leading to the announcement that a bankruptcy filing was being considered. ``We felt obliged to make known to the public that this was one of the options that we are considering,'' Wragg said. ``However, we have not made a decision to file for protection, and I cannot speculate as to whether that might be a decision.'' General Development told the Securities and Exchange Commmission earlier that it would cost about $400 million to finish developing its land, but only $102.1 million has been budgeted for improvements. Failure to pay property taxes triggers a two-year legal process that could end with the sale of the land, but General Development could avoid that by paying the taxes, interest and penalties at any time up to the day of sale. ``I don't foresee them losing any property unless they go kerflooey and close up,'' said Gene Morris, the tax collector for Indian River County. General Development owes $709,672 in property taxes, or 0.8 percent of the county tax roll, on about 2,800 vacant parcels and sewer and water plants, he said. In Brevard County where General Development owns 18,000 empty lots, Tax Collector C.N. ``Newt'' Jones was more worried about the paperwork nightmare that a tax sale might cause. The county normally lists about 11,000 items for its annual tax sale. The company owes more than $2 million in property taxes, or about 1 percent of Brevard's annual collections, Jones said. United Capital Corp., a minority shareholder, offered short-term operating funds and a restructuring plan involving the sales of assets last week. But the New York-based real estate company, which plans to submit a slate of new GDC board nominees that include United Capital's chairman, announced Monday that talks had broken down. The talks ended after United Capital rejected a proposal that would have involved immediately dropping its plan to nominate new directors before negotiations on a possible financial transaction would begin, United Capital said in a statement. ``General Development's board seems more intent on keeping control even if they had to take General Develoment into bankruptcy,'' A.F. Petrocelli, chairman of United Capital, said in a statement.
